Ever since I started my marathon of playing through all the Uncharted games for the first time, I've always found each game to be absolutely incredible. Uncharted 4 is no different; I loved every part of this game, from beginning to end. I swear, every Uncharted game is an absolute banger.
As always, the graphics and story were absolutely incredible and left me on the edge of my seat the entire time. (Story spoilers->) [spoiler] Getting to see Nate's story come to an end was an absolutely incredible and surreal experience. I really feel like I was along for the ride and know all of these characters so well, its actually a little bittersweet that I have to say goodbye now. But at the same time, in today's world I'm super glad that Uncharted got a definitive, concrete, and incredibly rewarding and fulfilling ending. You just don't see stuff like that anymore. I remember hearing about how Uncharted 4 is the end of the series, and that unlike some other adventure heroes in pop culture, Nate's story actually has an end. When I heard that, I got excited and worried because I genuinely didnt know if Nate was going to make it out of this one alive - and the cover art wasn't helping me either lol. But Im glad Nate's story ended the way it did, and [/spoiler] I'm so glad I got to play through all of the Uncharted games, they're some of the best games I have ever played!

I also loved the new driving, grapple hook, and piton mechanics that were added to the game! I find it amazing that the game was introducing new mechanics to me so far into the game, and was excited to get to use all of them! I particularly found the driving to be the most fun of the new mechanics; the cars controlled so well and I loved riding around in the plains and jungle with Nate and his crew. I also loved the handbrake and the winch, and am definitely glad Sully spent the extra money to get it lol.

Overall, I found Uncharted 4 to be an amazing game and an excellent way to end off the series! This game, along with the rest of the Uncharted games, will forever be some of my favorite games of all time.

These games are pretty overrated IMO. What makes Uncharted special is the storytelling. There are some wonderful moments in this game involving Nate when he is young, or the scene where his true desire is so perfectly communicated to the player when he spaces out during dinner, or the wonderful epilogue. While these moments are emotional in a way that games generally aren't, the overall direction the plot goes in is extremely predicable, and not unique at all. That's not to say that's an issue, but because the plot felt like something I'd seen plenty of times before in films and games, it began to feel like a slower-pace [i]Tomb Raider[/i] or [i]Far Cry[/i].

Uncharted still had some really fun moments, particularly combat scenarios. I played on Hard (Unfortunately you need to beat hard to unlock Crushing) and it was generally pretty fun. It never felt super challenging outside of specific combat sections where the checkpoint is very poorly designed, or you start with no ammo; in these situations the challenge felt more like it was coming from poor design than well-crafted encounters, which is something I despise. However, those situations were uncommon, and combat was still my favorite part of the game. Traversal sometimes feels uninteresting - the wall climbing is the same industry standard system you've seen in every Sony game, [i]Assassin's Creed[/i], etc. Although crossing larger scale maps in vehicles was more interesting. The puzzles are pretty simple and often boring, it feels as it they're meant to switch-up the pace rather than get you thinking.  I've got to mention the crazy vehicle sequences, which were extremely over-the-top, but still entertaining and fun to play. One of the best of these was in The Lost Legacy. 

To sum it up here is what I'll say; these Uncharted games are fun, and quality. However, don't expect them to be the unique masterpieces that the Playstation crowd and many others have made them out to be. Uncharted is more like a Fast and Furious movie; you're going to have fun and be entertained by it's massive action set-pieces and emotional moments, but the overall story is nothing special and many elements of it are worse than many current action films in the same genre.

The Thieves' End: A Masterful Conclusion to the Uncharted Saga

Rating: ★★★★★

I have had the pleasure of immersing myself in the intriguing world of "Uncharted Legacy of Thieves," and I feel obligated to share my overwhelmingly positive experience with this amazing game. As a long-time fan of the Uncharted series, this latest installment, "The Thieves' End," not only met but exceeded my expectations in every way.

The first thing that struck me was the flawlessly written narrative. The plot creates a tapestry of mystery, emotion, and adventure, demonstrating Naughty Dog's storytelling prowess. Every twist and turn in the plot is skillfully accomplished, keeping players on the edge of their seats and emotionally invested in the destiny of their favorite characters.

The gameplay, which has been a trademark of the Uncharted series, reaches new heights in "Legacy of Thieves." The seamless blend of exploration, puzzle-solving, and adrenaline-pumping action is nothing short of spectacular. The level design's attention to detail, combined with the straightforward controls, makes every second of gameplay enjoyable. From daring escapes to furious firefights, each set piece demonstrates the developers' devotion to provide an unrivaled gaming experience.

What distinguishes "The Thieves' End" is its exceptional replayability. I felt drawn to return to the game, not only for the magnificent visuals and intense gameplay, but also to explore deeper into the storyline. The story intricacies and character development are so complex that a second playthrough just adds to the overall experience. It's a rare accomplishment when a game not only survives but thrives under the examination of numerous playthroughs.

Then there's the finale, a suitable and emotionally poignant end to the Uncharted series. Without giving away any surprises, I can confidently say that "The Thieves' End" delivers the closure that fans have been waiting for. It ties up loose ends, delves into the characters' relationships, and provides players with a great sense of satisfaction. Naughty Dog has actually created a finale that honors the franchise' past while setting the path for a new era in gaming.

In the end, "Uncharted Legacy of Thieves: The Thieves' End" exemplifies what a video game masterpiece should be. Naughty Dog's farewell to the Uncharted series is fitting, with a beautifully woven plot, outstanding gameplay, and the capacity to engage players throughout several playthroughs. Whether you're a seasoned fan or a beginner to the brand, this game is a must-play.

Unten in Deutsch:

English:
The UNCHARTED™: Legacy of Thieves Collection is like the Hollywood blockbuster of video games - a rollercoaster ride full of adrenaline, spectacular stunts, and a pinch of sarcasm that makes it all the more flavorful.

The story is so gripping that you almost forget you're just sitting on the couch and not traveling the world on a wild treasure hunt. Nathan Drake and his crew are so charismatic that you could listen to them for hours, even if they were only talking about the weather (which they never do, because they're too busy chasing lost treasures).

The gameplay is so action-packed that you feel like you've taken on a role in an action movie - you run, jump, climb, and shoot your way through breathtaking locations as if there's no tomorrow. And the puzzles are so tricky that sometimes you almost wish you could just take a break and grab a bag of popcorn to ponder over them.

All in all, the UNCHARTED™: Legacy of Thieves Collection is an absolute must for anyone looking for an adventure that's as entertaining as a blockbuster movie - just for playing!

Die Story ist so fesselnd, dass man fast vergisst, dass man eigentlich nur auf dem Sofa sitzt und nicht auf einer wilden Schatzsuche um die Welt reist. Legacy of Thieves contains two games, A Thief's End and The Lost Legacy.
The first of these follows Nathan Drake across several continents to recover the loot of Captain Henry Avery. Nathan traverses thick jungles, cliff-sides, and cities, courageously battling other would-be treasure seekers, including one of the main characters of The Lost Legacy, Nadine Ross.
Beautiful landscapes, challenging puzzles, interesting dialogue, challenging combat, this game has it all.
A fantastic adventure, showcasing the spectacular landscapes crafted by the teams at Naughty Dog, Sony Santa Monica, and the other collaborators in the creation of this game.
The soundtrack by Henry Jackman includes many exciting pieces, including the title theme, A Thief's End, a piece that never fails to perfectly convey the feel of this game.
The whole experience of this game was a real pleasure to play, and I'll never forget the feeling of riding far too fast through a jungle in a jeep, fending off potential rivals to the treasure with a sniper rifle, or [SPOILER] dueling Rafe amid the flaming ruins of a ship of gold, nor the real vertigo of climbing across a cliff face, fifty meters over the dense jungle of a forgotten island.
I absolutely recommend this game, every inch feels handcrafted, and the mechanics are intuitive and smooth-feeling. You won't forget this one.

February 4th, 2024: This port isn't in the same, playable state that it first released in. Mouse and Keyboard are currently unusable as input devices, and stuttering has gotten considerably worse. Buyer beware.

Both Uncharted 4 and Lost Legacy are action/adventure titles, inspired by the classic Indiana Jones films and the original Tomb Raider games. There are healthy doses of combat, exploration and platforming, which prevent the titles from ever feeling stale.

The cover-based, third-person shooter combat in these two titles is as good as the series gets. The enemies’ aggressive nature forces you to move from cover to cover frequently. If you try to hunker down in one spot, you’ll soon find yourself flanked or flushed out by a grenade or rocket launcher. Melee combat has also undergone an upgrade, making it easier to pound a foe’s face in if they get too close. And whenever possible, stealth is also a viable option. Though it's not as refined as the likes of Metal Gear Solid or Hitman, creeping up on an unsuspecting baddie from behind and snapping their neck feels immensely satisfying.

While the gameplay is virtually identical between the two titles, Lost Legacy feels more fluid than Uncharted 4. The latter isn’t sluggish, but it’s clear that Naughty Dog refined the controls between titles. Or perhaps Chloe handles better because she’s lighter and nimbler than Nathan. Whatever the case, the controls in Lost Legacy are exceptional, and easily the best of the entire franchise.

Uncharted: Lost Legacy (4.1/5):

"Uncharted: Lost Legacy offers a thrilling adventure that manages to capture the essence of the Uncharted series while introducing new characters and locales. The visuals are stunning, with detailed landscapes and realistic character animations that make the game visually immersive.

Chloe Frazer and Nadine Ross make for a dynamic duo, bringing a fresh perspective to the Uncharted universe. The storyline is engaging, filled with unexpected twists and turns that keep you on the edge of your seat. The pacing is well-executed, balancing intense action sequences with moments of character development.

Gameplay-wise, Lost Legacy maintains the series' signature mix of exploration, puzzle-solving, and exhilarating combat. The addition of the open-world environment adds a layer of freedom, allowing players to tackle objectives in their preferred order. However, some may find the game slightly shorter than its predecessors.

Overall, Uncharted: Lost Legacy is a worthy addition to the franchise, offering an exciting journey with impressive visuals, captivating characters, and a satisfying blend of action and exploration."

Uncharted 4: A Thief's End (4.1/5):

"Uncharted 4: A Thief's End marks the conclusion of Nathan Drake's epic journey, delivering a fitting end to the beloved character's story. The game's graphics are breathtaking, showcasing the capabilities of the PlayStation 4 and providing a cinematic experience that rivals Hollywood blockbusters.

The narrative is emotionally charged, delving into Drake's past and exploring themes of family and redemption. The voice acting is top-notch, bringing the characters to life with believable performances. The relationships between characters are well-developed, adding depth to the storytelling.

Gameplay in A Thief's End retains the series' trademark blend of climbing, puzzle-solving, and intense gunfights. The addition of more open-ended environments allows for strategic approaches to combat, giving players a sense of freedom. The multiplayer mode adds replayability, though some may find it less engaging compared to the single-player campaign.

While A Thief's End delivers a satisfying conclusion to the Uncharted saga, some might argue that certain sections feel drawn out, affecting the overall pacing. Nevertheless, the game succeeds in providing a memorable and emotional farewell to Nathan Drake."

Both games offer a solid 4.1/5 rating, providing exciting experiences with a few minor shortcomings that do little to detract from the overall enjoyment.

Uncharted: Legacy of Thieves Collection is a magnificent port of a PlayStation masterpiece.

This game is the final chapter of the Nathan Drake saga with a small side adventure starring Uncharted 2's Chloe Frazer. It's hard to recommend this if you haven't played the first three Uncharted games, which are not available on PC at the time of writing this review but you are given the chance I'd recommend playing them first.

The stories are fun adventures starring fun and fleshed out characters from the previous games along with some standout new ones. The main game being set across the globe from Europe and Africa and Lost Legacy taking place completely in India, but both games include stunning imagery and locations with tons of lost civilisations to climb around on. The main game's story is also a heartfelt sendoff to the character of Nathan Drake told amazingly by the actors and story direction.

The gameplay itself is more smooth and exciting than it's ever been with the added tool of the grapple rope which has been added to the combat, traversal and puzzle solving bits of the game. The combat has been much improved from previous instalments with more focus on stealth mechanics that are a successor to The Last of Us' stealth gameplay. The gunplay especially has seen welcome improvements with more fluid movement and a wider variety of weapons. The puzzles and traversal have seen bigger improvements with the refinemnt of the climbing system and the introduction of the rope.

All in all Uncharted: Legacy of Thieves Collection is the ultimate package of the final chapter in the Uncharted series and a flawless port of one of the best games of the PS4 generation.

The UNCHARTED: Legacy of Thieves Collection is a masterclass in storytelling and adventure gaming that brings two iconic titles, UNCHARTED 4: A Thief's End and UNCHARTED: The Lost Legacy, to the PC with stunning enhancements. This collection not only pays homage to the legendary Nathan Drake saga but elevates it to new heights, making it a must-have for fans and newcomers alike.

First and foremost, the visual upgrades in this collection are nothing short of breathtaking. The transition to the PC has bestowed these already impressive titles with enhanced graphics, smoother frame rates, and faster load times. The meticulously detailed environments, character models, and cinematic sequences showcase the incredible talent and dedication of the developers at Naughty Dog, making the UNCHARTED world more immersive than ever before.

The storytelling in both A Thief's End and The Lost Legacy is a testament to Naughty Dog's storytelling prowess. The characters, led by the charismatic Nathan Drake, are richly developed, and their relationships unfold with emotional depth and authenticity. The narrative arcs seamlessly blend action, intrigue, and humor, creating an experience that feels like playing through a cinematic masterpiece.

Gameplay in the UNCHARTED series has always been synonymous with thrilling action, and the Legacy of Thieves Collection continues that tradition. From heart-pounding shootouts to exhilarating chase sequences, the gameplay remains as engaging as ever. The addition of new features like the Photo Mode allows players to capture and share their favorite moments, further enhancing the sense of personal connection to the story.

Exploration is a cornerstone of the UNCHARTED series, and both titles in this collection deliver expansive and meticulously crafted environments. Solving puzzles, discovering hidden treasures, and navigating through awe-inspiring landscapes contribute to the sense of adventure that defines the UNCHARTED experience. The Lost Legacy, in particular, introduces players to a new protagonist, Chloe Frazer, providing a fresh perspective on the series.

The musical score, composed by Henry Jackman, enhances the emotional impact of the story and adds an extra layer of excitement to the gameplay. The sound design, voice acting, and attention to detail in every aspect contribute to the overall immersive experience that makes UNCHARTED: Legacy of Thieves Collection a standout in the world of video games.

In conclusion, the UNCHARTED: Legacy of Thieves Collection is an absolute triumph, showcasing Naughty Dog's dedication to delivering unforgettable gaming experiences. Whether you're a longtime fan of the series or discovering the adventures of Nathan Drake for the first time, this collection is a treasure trove of excitement, emotion, and pure gaming brilliance. Strap in for an unforgettable journey – the legacy continues!

My lack of recommendation come mostly due to how there is not an option to buy these games separately let alone the ability to download them separately. You have to buy both games and both games will install. With the consideration that I find A Thief's End to be the weakest Uncharted game and The Lost Legacy to be the most mediocre one, the only question I'd have for you if you're interested is, "Did you play 1-3, and are you just itching for more."

I played both games on PlayStation and to summarise my opinion of both. 

ATE is a bloated overrated mess of an experience bogged down by a story that drags its feet in an attempt to be an introspective deconstruction of Nathan Drake when he really never needed it. 
The introduction of his long lost brother out of nowhere is as hilariously stupid as it is in any media that introduces a long lost relative out of nowhere. 
The antagonists are, by far, the worst in the franchise, Featuring a rich kid named Rafe who has the intimating presence of a wet noodle, and Nadine, or as i like to call her, C**t. She's like someone really wanted their OC to feature in someone else's story and so just stuffed her and insufferable personality in as hard is they could. 
The Supernatural elements that were present in the older games a gone. They insist on there being a curse but it's clear it's intended as a more metaphorical aspect and is just speculation by the characters. 
More than any other game in the series, the amount of 'downtime' has significantly increased. This game has a lot of moments where character's just walk and talk with very little in the way of platforming or exploring to break it up. If forced walking section aren't your thing, then be cautious.
I will complement the game where it's due. Naughty Dog does know how to make their games visually impressive. everything from locations to set pieces are top notch and if you come to Uncharted Specifically for the spectacle, then you wont be disappointed... at least, once you get to them. 
There is also the gameplay, an aspect of Uncharted I find that seems to improve across the board with each game at the specific cost of the brawling system. Now that the gunplay, stealth and traversal are as smooth as they've ever been, it almost feels like the the melee system is embarrassed to exist. like they needed a game mode for when you have to duel someone without guns and they lazily came up with this Sh*t. An even more baffling decision when you consider that they use it for the final boss of both games.

Which brings me to TLL and the reason I bought this bundle... on sale of course, I don't hate myself. See when I first played TLL, I enjoyed it just enough to not have strong feelings about it. It's much like the first uncharted game, only more tame. the setting is a local area so there's no globe trotting. Chloe is basically Nathan but girl. Nadine is moderately less insufferable than she was in the previous game. Long lost brother Sam shows up to not be a long lost brother trope. And the villain has some actual gravitas to him. 
Even the story and dialogue isn't terrible... for the most part... So in the trilogy you had Nathan, Sully and Elena. A trio that worked because Nathan and Sully had the mentor dynamic and him and Elena had flirtatious romance brewing. Here... the dynamics are just awkward. It starts off fine but once Sam joins, all the characters characters turn into quip dispensers because that's all the writers could think of for, people who don't like each other need to work together. There is also flirting that's cringy because even the story wants you to think it's cringy. These character's don't seem like they'd be remotely interested in eachother but they insist on sprinkling a little of it in there.
The game itself is saved by being a sweet, short, classical adventure. Something the fourth game should have been taking note of.


So TL,DR: If I didn't REALLY like these games then the Idea that I bought them a second time should be madness. Well yes, because the only reason I got this bundle was because a mod came out for TLL replaced Chloe with Lara Croft and since I'm a Tomb Raider fan whose opinion of the reboot Trilogy has only gotten more and more sour as the years have gone by, I get to have this wonderful hot-take. 

The best modern day Tomb Raider experience is a mod for a mediocre Uncharted game.

The story and presentation of this game (and really all naughty dog games) is unmatched. Voice acting is excellent. Dialogue is excellent. Set pieces are excellent. Graphics are excellent. Characters are excellent. Plot is excellent. The gameplay however... is pretty meh. Still worth it if you want to play 2 pretty great movies though. Definitely enjoyed it.

Elena + Nate is my favourite couple of all time!! UC4 has THE most satisfying story (especially if you followed all uncharted games) and the best writing of any game I've ever played :')) characters' conversations made me laugh and smile, and I loved the themes of obsession and family.

The gameplay holds up really well: shooting and melee is satisfying, the grappling hook is now a staple of every modern game, climbing is intuitive, and the environments and locales are still as wonderful and beautiful as ever. 

A series, and especially for UC4, a game, I will continue to keep revisiting over and over: it's my happy place.

Before i start off this review i just want to give a little context. This review is mostly regarding the PC port and not the game itself, the game itself is one of my favorite games of all time and is a masterpiece in storytelling. But unfortunately the PC port just isnt amazing. I crashed to desktop 10 times within my 12 hour playthrough which is just unacceptable for a story-centric game like this.

While troubleshooting the issue thinking it seems a lot of people have similar crashes that i do, so it isnt just a one off thing that only im experiencing. Another issue ive ran into was the fact the game really wasnt intended to run above 60-120 frames, im lucky enough to have a high end GPU so getting 150+ FPS in this game isnt that difficult even at ultra. My guess is the engine cant handle that amount of frames so stuff starts to get wonky at times, like the bridge in the Madagascar section bugged out and sent me into orbit multiple times until i locked the game to 30 to get across the bridge.

Im going to recommend the game just due to how good the story is, but remember to lock the game at 60 before diving in as that can really help solve a lot of the weird technical issues this game has like crashing and physics glitches.

While I like this game, I don't think it's the masterpiece that I expected going in. Too many little problems that combine into frustration at times, I think. The way the character moves is just weird and clunky sometimes despite how smooth the game usually is. The amount of times terrain crumbles underneath me, or as I grab it, just gets tiresome after the first dozen times. The disorienting way Nathan peeks out of cover sometimes and throws off my aim. The way I can fall to my death when he refuses to grab a ledge, only for the exact same jump to work flawlessly when I respawn.

Those little things aside would probably be ok. The game looks great, and I find myself really enjoying sitting back and watching cutscenes, as well as the story generally. The truly damning thing, I think, is performance issues. I'm writing this after my game crashed out of nowhere. Just finished a cutscene, started exploring, less than ten seconds later crash to desktop. Crashes aren't usual, I will say, but I have had lag at times, and during a chase the game literally stopped while a little loading percentage popped up on screen, multiple times in the same chase. It just makes for a not ideal gameplay experience, which is a shame given the amount of work that clearly went into it all.

Edit after playing Lost Legacy: I still feel mostly the same about the game. Same performance issues, same little janky problems popping up in gameplay. I do feel Lost Legacy improved the flow of the game somewhat, and was a more enjoyable, perhaps more focused, experience, but still gets let down by a lack of QA.

Uncharted 4 is a very good game, but with a couple of exceptions. 

The addon, The Lost Legacy, is laughable. You play as two unlikable women running around in backwaters India, beating up hoards of men, often several at a time. You can really tell where Naught Dog went off the rails with their identity politics nonsense, esp. seen later in TLOU2. Uncharted 4 was their last strong game IMO, so I will focus my review on that (The Lost Legacy is NOT recommended).

The combat and cover mechanics are definitely of the casual console game-type, ie. being rather imprecise, locked to specific movement and cover patterns, which will get frustrating and feel clunky for a PC gamer. But otherwise, the overall attention to detail is absolute top tier, with impressive action sequences.

We get a "strong" female antagonist against Nathan Drake, who completely wipes the floor with him every time they get into a fist fight. However, when you start fighting her, the controls become unresponsive, so you are clearly not allowed to properly engage her. Why give the player a main opponent you can't fight back against? Identity politics is dumb.

The visuals are mostly stunning, but there is this fake-looking chromatic aberration and film-like filter, which distracts from the visuals. In certain chapters, where this filter is mostly off - like in the childhood chapters and epilogue, the game immediately looks much better. Unfortunately there is no way to turn this off (yes, I tried the hex edits). So unnecessary.

All in all, highly recommended, with a few caveats, if you like adventure games.

What's there to say that hasn't been said about this game. Truly a timeless masterpiece that never gets boring no matter how many times I play it. And even then after all these years I still get that empty feeling inside of me after I finish a truly great game, knowing that it is all over. 

Uncharted 4: A Thieves End starts by showing us (the players) the retired treasure hunter Nathan Drake and his normal life. A simple life that many would treasure but Drake feels the absence and thrill of the adventure that gives him the rush that he misses. After seeing his dead brother still alive and somewhat well, Nathan is asked by his brother to help him find the lost treasures of Henry Avery, a famous and well known pirate that stole the gold off a ship called the Gunsway. Nathan is swung back into action trying to save his brother from a drug lord known as Hector Alcazar whom has an interest in the treasure considering that he saved Nate's brother from a panamanian jail whilst being his cellmate. 
Without spoiling too much of the story, Nathan realises that the thrill of the adventure is no longer important to him and no matter how many lost cities he discovers, how many fabled treasures he uncovers or how many historical figures he finds will be as important to him as his family and his wife Elena. A beautiful game that is an emotional rollercoaster but ends in a fulfilling way.
Uncharted 4: A Thieves End is the thrilling conclusion to Nathan Drake's story but the end leaves us with the want and thirst for more, even though it is the end. I can't help but feel as if though they tease us with the continuation as Sam Drake or even Nate's daughter Cassandra. As stated before this game is truly one of a kind and there's nothing like it. A timeless masterpiece that everyone can enjoy!

Disclaimer: I have only played the first game in the collection so far.

As a MASSIVE FAN of the Tomb Raider reboots, I can't help comparing this game to those--especially considering how each franchise has borrowed from the other over the years. With that out of the way, Uncharted 4 was a terrific experience. While the gameplay has a lot of similarities, Uncharted stands out as its own kind of adventure with more of a buddy file/action film vibe, as opposed to survival horror. The game is more linear and cinematic, and there's a lot of characterization and character growth. All-around, the writing and the acting is wonderful--brought to live by incredible motion capture. These characters feel real to me. 

The Tomb Raider games had a lot more exploration and customization options for weapons and skills, but Uncharted chooses to keep the pressure on and the action moving at a break neck pace. It's not that there aren't moment where you can take in the view, its just that the emphasis is on the action, especially the combat. In fact, get ready for a lot of that.

While its entirely possible to clear some encounters with stealth, you are limited to close range take-downs. No compound bows or silencers here (unless I missed something). Then there are encounters that force you to rely on guns, grenades, and cover mechanics. But its also often possible to disengage and re-enter stealth.

What's really fun is when the action scenes collide with the combat, leading to some very unique and memorable battles that feel organic with only a sparse amount of quick-time input (thankfully). 

Finally, the graphics, sound effects, and music are all amazing. And the default difficulty was spot-on. While I died a few times in combat, I rarely died during exploration. If i could change one thing, I might have like more challenging puzzles, but then again, I'm thankful they were always interesting and never tedious. 

I had a great time, and I hope the first 3 games in the series make it over to PC so I can check them out!

Uncharted 4 alone is one of my favourite games of all time. It's a little different then the others in the series if you are familiar with them, telling a little more "grounded" story focusing more on just treasure and relationships rather than the supernatural aspects the others had (among other things). That being said, it's like Indiana Jones and The Goonies had a baby, being a large scale adventure all about pirate treasure in a cave (you will see what I mean). The characters are really what shine in the game, although the graphics and game play are nothing to scoff over. The witty banter is a huge highlight and the characters feel deep and real. Overall, easy recommendation to anyone that enjoys nice and fun adventure. Uncharted The Lost Legacy isn't as good, but it is still good. The absence of our star, Nathan Drake is a apparent, but Chloe handles her own well enough and has some pretty enjoyable moments with her partner Nadine. It was released as a standalone similar to games like Mile Morales, but it definitely feels more like a long DLC rather than it's own game. Still a great game, and considering you get both in this bundle, worth the pick up. If it is on a good sale, even better.

This is my first Uncharted experience, and it blew me away. Definitely in my top 5 favorite games now. Here are a few positives and negatives:
      POSITIVE  1) The characters and dialogue are so well written and voice acted. Feels like you are watching genuine people, and they are all well done. My favorite out of the two games though is Chloe Frazer from Lost Legacy. Great character, cool voice and likeable. 
                        2) This is one of the most immersive games I have played. The visuals are stunning, and I was often blown away by the incredible set pieces and vistas, as well as the care taken to numerous small details like movement animations. Felt like I was playing an awesome movie I would love to see.

      WEAK NEGATIVE 1) Combat for me was infuriating at times. Lots of cool weapons though and everything handled well. But I don't know how many times I wanted to duck in cover and rolled into the open instead. The ai in this game is very tough - which is a positive, but holy man, prepare to die a lot. I played first half of A Thief's End on Hard difficulty, and had to lower it as I was getting spanked. Again, this isn't a bad thing necessarily, but it sucks achievements are linked to this. I can't imagine how infuriating Crushing difficulty would be. 

I highly recommend you play this game. Perfect for back seat gamers also - your significant other won't mind watching this.

This was my first time playing a game in the Uncharted series. The main game, A Thief's End, was really good. Great scenery, made it feel like watching a movie at times. The parkour and stealth aspects were also fun. Had just enough puzzles to keep it interesting. It was weird not having a map, but you do eventually find your way each time. I liked how the game would eventually give you a prompt for a hint if you got stuck too long. The voice actors for Nathan and Sam were great. CONS: At times it looks like an open world type of game, but you can't interact with random objects, except to kick over goblets, pots, etc. And you can't stray far from the predetermined path.  I didn't bother trying to find all of the hidden treasures. I'm not sure anyone could find them all without looking up hints. 

The DLC content, The Lost Legacy, was quite the opposite. It was weird playing Chloe. They could have easily had you play as Sam, which would make a logical pairing from playing as Nathan in the main game. On top of that, they pair you with the ever-annoying Nadine from the main game. These two women are so over-the-top macho it's comical. At least they could have given your character the option to push Nadine off a cliff somewhere. Speaking of scenery, it all starts looking the same in Chapter 4, which goes on WAY too long. It becomes too much of, "find these objects or you can't advance". There are also too many tedious puzzles in this one versus the main game. The overall story line was also convoluted and hard to follow. Swing and a miss for the DLC.

I must say, it has been an exhilarating experience that exceeded my expectations. 
One of the standout features that left me in awe was the breathtaking landscapes. The meticulously crafted environments not only served as a stunning backdrop but also added a layer of immersion that made every moment memorable. The hidden monuments and cities scattered throughout the game added a sense of mystery and discovery, keeping me engaged as I explored the hidden corners of each location. 
The graphical fidelity of the collection is nothing short of impressive, especially considering that the game was initially released in 2016.
The narrative impact of A Thief's End was profound, pulling me into the emotional depths of Nathan Drake's journey. The storytelling was top-notch, and the character development left a lasting impression. On the other hand, The Lost Legacy excelled in delivering intense gameplay and a sense of adventure (and more from Nadine). Playing both parts together is highly recommended for a complete and fulfilling experience.
From a technical perspective, the game runs exceptionally smoothly on PC. The controls feel responsive, and the overall performance is a testament to the effort put into adapting the game for the PC platform.
Whether you are a fan of the series or a newcomer (as I was), this is a must-play.

Naughty Dog is one of the few developers in the world with an Iron Clad record of releases. Uncharted 4 is no different; video game cinematic spectacle at its absolute peak. This game felt like a trilogy of the best action movies in cinema while also retaining classic level design that makes Naughty Dog stand apart in the current climate of AAA games. With constant callbacks to design choices from games like Crash Bandicoot, Jak and Daxter and the Last of Us while combining them with completely new styles of game design was truly sublime. Voice acting is also top notch, you would be hard-pressed to find better performances somewhere else. Phenomenal game, must play.
I want to recommend this, but is crashes all the time. ALL THE TIME.

Having been spoiled by more open worlds, the rails that Uncharted puts you on makes the game feel like a series of set pieces interspersed with cut scenes. It is a shame that there is no sort of character progression to gain abilities or skills since that would help give the game some depth that it very much needs.

On a high spec PC it looks beautiful. The sound design is great, the controls are fine. The plot is bonkers, but that is to be expected!

There are a few graphical oddities, such as when the auction is going on and every time the scene cuts to a camera view with NPCs in it, their arms start off pointing out from the elbow and then move into position. Sometimes the roap just flaps around as if trying to find gravity. Not exactly AAA quality.

My main gripe is around steam deck performance and visuals. The game uses FSR 2, and it needs to run at leas then full resolution to keep close to 60 FPS. The FSR upscaling doesn't include later updates that remove the fuzzy halo and streaks that are very noticeable and distracting in this game. It seems to be that model complexity is too high (on the lowest setting). This isn't an issue in, for example, the Spiderman games where you can get a smooth and pretty game on deck.

Last grump is combat. Stealth kind of works, guns are just about fine, punching people feels like you are negotiating with the character to punch and block.

I am sure I will finish the game, but four hours in, I am regretting buying it.

Probably a massively unpopular opinion but Uncharted 4 was surprisingly uninspired and sometimes even a chore to play through for me. Apart from the memory lane visits and occasional fun action sequences, it was rather baffling how little the game actually had to offer when it came down to it. Repetitive platforming, ridiculous narrative choices, obvious twists, etc. Am I just getting old and cynical? Or were the previous Uncharted games just simple and fun compared to this washed up nostalgia trip.

Let’s start with the story. For some reason, the writers thought it was necessary for this tale to have three (!) introductory chapters in a row: a medias in res action teaser (called “prologue”), a flashback chapter (chapter 1) and an actual prologue (chapter 2). If you’re looking for an off-putting way to immediately numb your audience with convoluted “we’re clever artists”-writing instead of having us actually play a game that gets us hooked from the get-go: this is it, you found it. Everything about that long intro just screams creative arrogance and doesn’t bode well for the rest of the experience. The whole “lost brother”-trope that they try to pull off falls hilariously on its face as well, as this is a painfully clear way to try and provide a new hook to the story by suddenly introducing new background to a character we have loved for an entire trilogy already. Somehow we are expected to believe that all of this information was always present and that is was never brought up during the three previous games, all the while undermining established character moments from those earlier instalments in the series.

And spoiler if you haven’t played the game yet, but absolutely one of my all time biggest pet peeves: fake flashbacks. The entire Hector Alvarez chapter, which is also actually some kind of prologue (yes, another one) for Sam, ultimately gets played off as a lie. So an entire chapter of gameplay is supposedly a figment of someone’s imagination. Are you kidding me? That’s such a cheap way to get your viewer on board with something, because naturally you consider everything you can actually PLAY as truth within your gaming experience. That’s the equivalent of having characters in a horror film go through something horrific only to reveal it was a dream afterwards, just to get value from the scare that the scene brought with it. Sam’s reveal of this betrayal made me ridiculously angry, not only due to me being against fake flashbacks in principle, but also because it’s just that lazy and pathetic “you lied to me”-moment that you’ve seen in dozens of films already. Quite laughable to be frank.

Uncharted 4 also takes pride in its complex relationships between characters. To be fair, those definitely are present and make the story more worthwhile. I definitely enjoy the interesting take on a fortune hunter coming to terms with his own mortality and responsibilities in life. The only problem with that is that the narrative really banks on these emotional scenes that resemble real life, while at the same time having you mass murder hundreds of nameless goons with assault rifles and rocket launchers during the action sequences. It's the tonal shift between deep character driven drama and yolo arcade shooter that really makes this game rather unbalanced. How am I supposed to get into an affecting cutscene in which Nate refuses to kill someone, when I know for a fact that I’ve been savagely killing people without even batting an eye a couple of minutes before? What, now you care? Because this character has an actual name? I know that stuff like that is an inherent vice of games in general, because of course a lot of unrealistic nonsense is involved in the medium. But as I mentioned, it’s the contrast between these shoot ‘m ups and cinematic filmlike character building that makes for an unbelievable cocktail in which I basically have to choose which style to focus on in order to make sense of these two juxtaposed realities. If the characters and story are also unrealistic, there’s no conflict. But exactly because they present these characters as real people with real issues in the cutscenes, the writers turn it into conflict. Last of Us does this way better for example, by making the nameless enemies in combat segments actually also feel like real people. The interactions and implications within the context of the story make those characters feel alive and make it seem realistic and believable that you are doing these horrible things to these people. Killing enemies in Uncharted makes you feel nothing, which really makes no narrative sense when combined with the emotional gravitas of every action and decision they try to imply during the important character driven cutscenes.

And in essence, what is the plot of this game? Going from one location to another so that the bad guys can arrive out of the blue to thwart your plans. It’s always the same thing: new clue, move to location, solve a thing, “aha we are also here!”-moment of the villains, escape. That’s the pattern that happens over and over again until the final climax breaks the cycle. The antagonists have the most impeccable sense of timing and always manage to be at the exact same location as our heroes. Supported by a seemingly inexhaustible supply of Shoreline mercenaries that just keep coming and coming, even in public without ever once suffering the consequences of international and local police forces that maybe should keep all these insane events in check. It’s all so predictable and silly. Even the platforming sections with the iconic climbing frustrate me to no end because it’s always the exact same thing: keep climbing until a brick or a branch unexpectedly comes loose. “Phew that was close, got to find another path”. It’s such empty rinse and repeat nonsense that needs to distract you with impressive set pieces such as the car chase in Madagascar (it is fantastic though) in order to convince you of the impression that you’re actually playing through a masterfully crafted story. I don't buy it sadly.

So yes, I do not consider this the so-called masterpiece many seem to think it is. I don’t even regard this a somewhat great game by Naughty Dog standards. Uncharted 4 is an superfluous and lacklustre addendum to an already excellent and finished trilogy, that more often than not likes to revel in how fantastic it thinks it is. It reeks of the same hubris that can be found in Last of Us 2. Neil Druckmann can make beautiful and brilliant games, but he really lets it go to his head when the public and critics blow his trumpet as the genius “auteur” behind it all. Resulting in the videogame equivalent of autofellatio.

Positives: the puzzles are fun and well made for an action adventure game. These parts usually involved me just having a lot of fun instead of rolling my eyes at the next ridiculous thing the story threw in my lap. The game is of course also one of the most gorgeous looking creations out there and the voice acting is superb.

"Uncharted 4: A Thief's End" stands tall as a monument in the world of gaming, setting a new standard for immersive storytelling, gameplay mechanics, and visual excellence. The fourth installment in the acclaimed Uncharted series, developed by Naughty Dog, this game isn't just a journey; it's a masterpiece that encapsulates the pinnacle of gaming experiences. At its core, what makes Uncharted 4 an unparalleled gaming experience is its ability to seamlessly blend a captivating narrative with breathtaking gameplay. The game's protagonist, Nathan Drake, embarks on a quest filled with thrilling adventures, uncovering hidden treasures while facing personal and moral dilemmas. The storytelling prowess of Uncharted 4 is unmatched, drawing players into an emotionally charged, cinematic narrative that feels like a blockbuster action-adventure film. One of the game's standout elements is its impeccable attention to detail. From the lush, meticulously designed landscapes to the smallest nuances in character expressions, every aspect of Uncharted 4 is crafted with a level of care that elevates it to a level beyond ordinary gaming. The environments are not just backgrounds; they are living, breathing worlds that players can immerse themselves in, exploring ruins, solving puzzles, and engaging in heart-pounding action sequences. Moreover, the character development in Uncharted 4 is exceptional. The relationships between characters feel genuine and evolve throughout the game, adding depth and emotional weight to the storyline. Nathan Drake's internal conflict between his adventurous spirit and the desire for a settled life with his loved ones resonates deeply, making players empathize with his journey on a profound level. The gameplay mechanics of Uncharted 4 are a testament to the game's excellence. The fluidity of movement, exhilarating combat sequences, and cleverly designed puzzles contribute to an engaging and dynamic gaming experience. Whether navigating treacherous terrain, engaging in intense firefights, or solving intricate puzzles, every moment feels meticulously crafted to keep players on the edge of their seats. The graphical fidelity of Uncharted 4 is nothing short of breathtaking. The attention to detail in character models, environments, and animations creates a visual spectacle that pushes the boundaries of what is possible in gaming. The game's stunning visuals not only enhance the overall experience but also serve as a testament to the technological prowess and artistic vision of the developers. In essence, Uncharted 4: A Thief's End isn't just a game; it's an opus, a culmination of storytelling, gameplay innovation, and technical brilliance. Its ability to captivate players, evoke emotions, and deliver an unparalleled gaming experience cements its position as one of the greatest games of all time. With its seamless blend of narrative depth, gameplay excellence, and visual splendor, Uncharted 4 stands as a shining example of what gaming can achieve, setting a benchmark for future generations of games to aspire to. I’d never played an Uncharted game before, but I’d certainly heard about them. Both these games ([i]A Thief’s End[/i] & [i]The Lost Legacy[/i]) had spectacular & beautiful scenery, some interesting (though not thrilling or difficult) puzzles and some fun gameplay BUT they were both let down by my pet hate: suddenly wanting you to play by different rules.  This is really common in boss fights, but there were also examples of weird platform gaming in parts of these.  Maybe this was fine at the time, but it just seems bad now.  The absolute worst was the final sequence of [i]The Lost Legacy[/i] where you have to [spoiler]run up the top of a train falling off a bridge from a very restricted view above and in front of you.  We’re at the end.  Honestly, a cinematic and a jump would’ve been fine[/spoiler].  Very tricky with a keyboard and not fun to repeat again and again.  Just a really sh*tty way to end a game.  Even the fab Claudia Black couldn’t make up for that.

The final vista was also pretty bad/sketchy.

NPCs were OK in open areas, but really had a knack of getting in your way if you were exploring a smaller area.  The hint system and the NPCs are really intrusive and patronizing.  You could be just enjoying the area or searching for something and the game will decide you don’t know what you’re doing since you haven’t moved ahead in 10 seconds, so the NPC will straight out tell you where to go.  This sabotages a lot of the fun of working things out yourself, so that even when they’re not doing it, you’re wondering how long you’ve got before the NPC starts nagging you or playing the game for you.  This is an inexplicably poor decision by the devs.

OTOH there were several critical moments when I had no idea whatsoever what I was supposed to be doing.  For instance, when the dialogue was obliterated by the need to survive some gunfire.

On the whole, the characters were super whitebread in [i]A Thief’s End[/i] ([spoiler]Nathan has a daughter and grey hairs by the end[/spoiler]), but I still kinda bought into the brothers’ story and I mostly liked the disjointed way it was setup.  [i]The Lost Legacy[/i] is a bit different, having two women protagonists, but it’s a bit hard to warm to Nadine after she was one of the main enemies in [i]A Thief’s End[/i]—even knowing she ran a mercenary army [i]should[/i] give you pause.  I felt like the relationship was very carefully balanced so it could be read as lesbian, but with plausible sisterhood deniability.  Seemed a bit cowardly to be honest.

It mostly played fine under Proton, but music was very often stuttery; dialogue & FX were fine.  Quite a few cinematics played in bizarre way with models glitching around, sliding sideways or disappearing entirely, but choosing Restart Cinematic from the menu fixed it every time. [h1] Legacy of Bugs [/h1]

As it stands now, I can't recommend it.

Cut-scenes are often laggy & jittery -- and there's commonly sudden frame-drops for seemingly no reason. Sometimes in cut-scenes sound-effects that should play once end up looping forever. Sometimes the voice-lines & subtitles in cut-scenes just don't trigger for some reason, even though I can clearly see the character's lips are moving. Characters will get stiff & still move around during every other cut-scene; like they're statues -- actual T-pose shit. Sometimes characters will move independently from their clothes.
All this is a huge problem, especially when this game is 50% cut-scenes.

During game-play it can suddenly jump from ~100FPS to 7FPS, and then back to 100FPS after 2 seconds... for seemingly no reason. It's really weird. I've tried messing with the settings but nothing seems to influence it directly. And it happens like every 15-30 minutes.
That weird mouse-smoothing & mouse-acceleration while aiming with KB/M controls is god awful. It makes me feel sick & yucky. It's so hard to aim, and I also get really dizzy for some reason.

And why did I have to wait 40-fucken-minutes for the shaders to load once I finally got into the game for my first time? Loading... loading... loading...
No other game I've ever played has done that nor needed that. Why?
Really... I got a job, got married, had kids, got divorced, died, and came back to life by the time the shaders were done installing.
All of this to realize that the game runs like dog ass.

I'm enjoying this game so far, no doubt. But I can't recommend it whatsoever as it stands now. Wait for a future patch.

My adventure with Uncharted series began with Drake's Fortune back in 2007 on the PS3.

Following Uncharted: Drake's Fortune, I've played Uncharted 2: Among Thieves and then Uncharted 3: Drake's Deception. The PS3 trilogy by far was one of my favorite action/adventure games on the console from 2007 through 2011.

In 2016, I've played Uncharted 4: A Thief's End on the PS4 and I was amazed by the world Naughty Dog has created for Drake. From its graphics to art style, the music and gunplay, everything from the original trilogy was perfected.

In Uncharted 4, we get to play through Drake's late 30s - early 40s. As he marries Elena, they both decide to leave ''treasure seeking'' behind and start a ''normal'' life together. (Nathan first meets Elena in Uncharted: Drake's Fortune.) But things don't go as planned and soon Drake finds himself in pursuit of his long ''lost'' brother Sam Drake.

Upon Sam emerging from his long departure, he asks Nate to help him settle his ''debts.'' Little does Nate know things are about to turn out. Accepting Sam's favor, Nate gets dragged into his past life and Elena isn't really happy about this. Soon enough she gets involved in their adventure along with Sullivan.

In the Epilogue, Nate's story comes to a conclusion and because of this, Uncharted fans were kinda upset. To continue the Uncharted series, Naughty Dog decided to carry on the adventure with Chloe in Uncharted: The Lost Legacy in 2017.

Chloe first met Nate in Uncharted 2: Among Thieves. They have a romantic relationship in the 2nd game. She is one of the main characters in the series.

In Uncharted: The Lost Legacy, Chloe and Nadine team up to seek the great treasure of the ancient Hoysala Empire in the South-Western coast of the Indian peninsula. Samuel Drake (Nathan Drake's brother) also has an appearance in The Lost Legacy.

When Naughty Dog released the PC version of Uncharted 4, they bundled it with The Lost Legacy and named it Legacy of Thieves Collection. If you've never played the original trilogy before, I highly recommend playing those before playing Uncharted 4 and The Lost Legacy. Because you'll be missing out on a lot.

I would hope to see Uncharted series continue at least with Chloe and Nadine or with Cassie. I know Nathan would be out because he is settled with Elena. I think Samuel Drake would be old too. Also I would highly doubt that Sullivan would still be around given his age.

Overall, I'd rate Uncharted 4 & The Lost Legacy both a solid 10/10. Thank you Naughty Dog.

This is a great game. I didn't play the earlier titles.

The bad part first: the combat is by far the worst part, you could cut 90% of it and IMO the game wouldn't suffer for it. It's not terrible, but since the rest of it is so good, it stands out like a sore thumb, The other part is the PC performance, this game can go from 60 FPS to a slideshow and back on my system (which, comparisons sake, runs RDR2 really well in similar settings). I didn't like the typical "hallway exploration" other Sony titles like GoW also suffer from, but that's maybe personal taste.

That's basically it, the rest of it is superb on every level. The very likeable characters, the models, the voice actors, the little animations, the locations, the grand adventure, the ancient secrets, temples and mechanisms, the vistas, gorgeous graphics, it's amazing. If you're an 80s kid, this is like The Goonies and all the Indiana Jones movies distiled into one glorious romp. (Other than the combat), I enjoyed every minute of it.

The first hour includes a gunfight at sea in the middle of a tropical storm, a childhood flashback where I sneak out of a Catholic orphanage, followed by fist-fighting in a Panamanian prison, and finally a heartwarming depiction of married life in the suburbs, where I attempt to beat my wife’s high score at Crash Bandicoot. You literally use a Playstation 1 on the TV. 

That is within an hour or two of the opening scene.   

The game is amazing. I mean Uncharted, not Crash Bandicoot. The story is movie-level (a great movie), the gameplay is equal parts combat and platforming/exploration, and the visuals easily rival games released this year (on max settings with Nvidia DLSS at 2k on a 32-inch HDR monitor). 

Unlike some people, I had no technical issues and the game easily stayed above 60 FPS in even the most intense scenes. But I’m using a new G16 laptop (12th Gen i9, 3070 ti, 32GB ram, SSD). A few months ago, I did try playing this game on a G7 from 2018, and it stuttered badly even on 1080p at medium settings (8th Gen i7, GTX 1060, 16GB ram, HDD). Hopefully that will give you some idea of the performance requirements.

You will not regret investing time in this. Especially if you are tired of open-world checklist-type games, or whatever the latest Call of Duty is, or another battle royale. 

Just an all-around spectacular experience.

Even the shameless in-game product placements—like everyone using Sony phones—are cute.

I recently had the opportunity to dive into the highly anticipated game, Uncharted: Legacy of Thieves. As a long-time fan of the Uncharted series, I was excited to experience the remastered versions of Uncharted 4: A Thief's End and Uncharted: The Lost Legacy. While the game succeeds in delivering a visually stunning and immersive experience that captures the essence of the original titles, I must express my concern regarding the presence of several bugs that significantly impact the overall gameplay and user experience.

First and foremost, the most glaring issue was the frequent occurrence of game crashes. Throughout my playthrough, I encountered multiple instances where the game unexpectedly froze or crashed, forcing me to restart from a previous checkpoint. This not only disrupted the flow of the narrative but also led to moments of frustration as I had to replay sections multiple times.

Additionally, there were several instances of character animation glitches, with characters getting stuck in awkward poses or exhibiting unnatural movements. These issues detracted from the otherwise seamless storytelling and character interactions that are a hallmark of the Uncharted series. The immersion-breaking nature of these glitches was particularly disappointing, as it hindered the emotional impact of certain scenes.

In conclusion, Uncharted: Legacy of Thieves, despite its unquestionable merits in terms of storytelling, visuals, and gameplay mechanics, is marred by a notable number of bugs that hinder the overall enjoyment of the experience.

[h1]My first UNCHARTED experience [/h1] 

[h3]UNCHARTED 4[/h3]
 Here I was officially introduced to Nathan Drake, main character of UNCHARTED games. Charismatic, adventurous, athletic, humorous. Archaeology and treasure hunting are his main interests in life that lead to the big adventures. Big dangerous adventures.

 We take our time to go deeper in Nathan’s childhood, get used to controls and start an incredible journey.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3033880082 
[h3]UNCHARTED: The Lost Legacy[/h3]   
  Chloe Frazer takes the main character's place. Almost the same as Nathan - charismatic, humorous, has an eye on treasures. Later in the story we learn that she wasn’t randomly chosen. Chloe previously appeared in Drake’s adventures. 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3085697850
 [h3]About both games[/h3]

  Fair to admit that games have spectacular views. Every small stone feels incredibly realistic. Developers managed to create beauty. However, better to say - capture the true beauty of nature. Environment made me feel like I’m right there. Each time I was immersed into the story. Completely absorbed. Literally didn’t notice how time went by. I’m thankful for the huge amount of details. 

  Made me want to learn archaeology and be fit like main characters to try climbing. I’m not into very old cultures, but I was totally interested and entertained. 
  
  Unfortunately, same as with Tomb Raider series, story is not the strong side of these types of games. Don’t try to find logic and rationality. These are about process - gameplay. Riddles, puzzles, treasure collecting. Light evening movies.

I express my respect and respect to the entire team that worked on this game. You have truly created a masterpiece. Thank you for that.
ps. I wish there were more great adventure games like this.

Updating the review a year later: Overall I have good memories of this game and so I decided to revisit it and finally try the dlc. At first I thought that it fixes some issues that I had with the main game - you are not getting lost since after prologue you get a map, the fights are rare and with silent pistol the stealth can be enjoyable, and you get a car to move around the map fast, and the story is pretty condensed and doesn't overstay it's welcome... That is before I finished the map and what waiting me wasn't a finale - as it turned out it wasn't even half way done. Overall I think I kinda enjoyed it, but it was soooo slow. Kinda same issue as with the main game - it's longer than it should be. very gorgeous - especially on an 2k oled hdr screen - but I still cannot recommend it due to the all the fillers and level design without obvious way forward (although it was better in the dlc, so much better than it was almost good. almost. I still found myself occasionally lost. Once I was even stuck due to the bug (the elephant didn't have a prompt, probably because my companion didn't follow me), but haven't realized that it was a bug since it is something I came to expect from the game xD). Both the dlc and the main game would've been perfect IMO if the cut them in half, added sprint button, added some way to locate the way forward (even some basic compass would've helped). As it is now - it's a game that wants to be the cinematic tomb raider, but it pales in comparison to the normal cinematic games (like dark picture anthology, detroit, quarry) and the tomb raider. hell even walking simulators like Firewatch gives better "movie" experience than this... Original review:
I wasn’t expecting much, I heard that it was “an expensive Tomb Raider rip-off”, “good playable movie, bad game”. but I didn’t expect it to be THAT bad. The gameplay is terrible and the way the story unfolds isn’t much better. It would still be better if it was an interactive novel like Dark Picture anthology instead of trying to be a jack of all trades and successfully failing.

Pros:
+nice visuals
+minimalistic hud
+good visual cues for collectibles
+extremely good aim-assist and lock-on, it’s extremely pleasurable to play with a controller (although it is better off if you play with a keyboard)
+buying this game makes bloodborne more likely to get a PC release
Cons:
-story is lazily written. They turned a 7-8 hours game into 19-20 hours game by filling it with… well, fillers.
-plot and characters are quite boring
-Marry Sue like protagonist (i.e.Spoiler::for the whole game we don’t have access to any blades or knives but at the end he suddenly learns how to use a sword)
-traversal is boring, characters move too slowly for how big the map is. Also no Run/Crouch button.
-gameplay is extremely repetitive and boring, you will be doing the same few scenarios over and over again without even feeling accomplished.
-controls are unintuitive (in some unique situations you need to figure out what button to press or how to move your character from a tight spot. Spoiler:: I am talking about when you need to figure out where to move your character's hands to get out from under the car or when you need to evade Rafe’s blows a few times to progress the scene. you are not given any hints and you can only die a few times figuring out how to do this)
-hint button works only after a long time progresses - I was finding out the way out by aimlessly walking around before that happens.
-levels are designed poorly. they lack visuals cues for which way to progress, and those visual cues that are present most of the time leads to a dead end with no reward (Tomb Raider would’ve had a treasure or resources at those places). Also the levels themself (if you disregard the dead ends) are extremely linear.
-climbing feels like a slightly downgraded version of Tomb Raider. You have many similar ways to overcome obstacles like Lara Croft but worse.
-game wants to be realistic when it would make it more pleasurable for the player for it to be unrealistic and then becomes unrealistic in place when it could’ve given more enjoyment by being realistic.
-combat is terrible. it essentially “kill those goons, take their weapon, repeat”. Stealth is optional and only extends your playthrough without any benefits and you won’t even enjoy it (I usually like stealth in games).
-no replay value. I don’t want to ever replay this game or to play the dlc. Even rewatching the movie is a better choice.

Why I don’t recommend this game? I just don’t see a point in buying it if you can buy the new Tomb Raider trilogy on sale for half of this game’s price. And you will have enough money left to buy a few good indie games. It might have been a good choice for ps4 (especially given that there wasn’t an abundance of choice due to absence of reverse compatibility with ps3 games), but this game has no place on PC. If you want to play sony game that isn't Spider-Man, I recommend you to take a look at Days Gone. Not many people have played it, and I wouldn't normally recommend it (it has many cons as well), but at least I enjoyed playing it, unlike Uncharted 4.

Download size is 125~ GB, which is something they easily could've avoided by piling the two games into a bundle, or sold them separately at half price.

Either way, hell of an experience, and I hope the series continues, and if it does, that it stays this great.

"Uncharted: Legacy of Thieves Collection" is a compelling remastered package that includes two of the most acclaimed titles from the Uncharted series: "Uncharted 4: A Thief's End" and "Uncharted: The Lost Legacy." This collection offers an enhanced experience for both newcomers and returning fans, and here are the reasons why it should not be missed.

First off, the remaster brings technical improvements to both games, with enhanced graphics that make the already stunning visuals even more impressive. With the power of more advanced consoles, players can enjoy higher resolution textures, improved lighting, and smoother frame rates. These enhancements make the cinematic experience of the Uncharted series even more immersive and visually impactful.

The storytelling in both games is of the highest caliber. "Uncharted 4" concludes Nathan Drake's treasure-hunting saga with a deeply personal adventure that tests his limits and his relationships. "The Lost Legacy," on the other hand, shines a spotlight on fan-favorite Chloe Frazer as she seeks the Tusk of Ganesh in India. Both narratives are filled with humor, drama, and moments that will stay with players long after the credits roll.

Gameplay in the "Uncharted" series has always been a mixture of exploration, puzzle-solving, and high-octane combat, and the "Legacy of Thieves Collection" refines these elements. Climbing and traversal feel fluid and thrilling, combat is tight and engaging, and the puzzles are cleverly designed to challenge the player without frustrating them.

The set pieces in both games are another high point. From a high-speed car chase in a crowded market to a stealth mission in a lush jungle, every scenario is crafted to be both a gameplay challenge and a narrative spectacle. These moments are enhanced by the remastered collection's improved performance, ensuring they look and play better than ever.

Character development throughout both games is stellar. Nathan Drake's journey in "Uncharted 4" explores his past and tests his relationships, while Chloe Frazer's character arc in "The Lost Legacy" adds depth to her backstory and personality. The supporting cast is equally strong, with each character adding to the richness of the narrative.

The sound design and musical scores in both games are outstanding, with immersive audio that brings the world to life and a soundtrack that enhances the emotional and action-packed moments. Voice acting is top-notch, delivering performances that are some of the best in the medium.

Multiplayer is another aspect where "Uncharted 4" shines, offering a fun and competitive experience where players can engage in various game modes. Although "The Lost Legacy" does not include its own multiplayer mode, it does come with access to "Uncharted 4’s" multiplayer suite, extending the collection's replayability.

In conclusion, the "Uncharted: Legacy of Thieves Collection" is a definitive way to experience two of the best action-adventure games of the modern era. The enhancements to graphics and performance, combined with unforgettable storytelling, engaging gameplay, and cinematic moments, make this collection an essential addition to any gamer's library. Whether you're swinging into the world of Uncharted for the first time or returning for another playthrough, this collection represents the series at its peak, and it's an adventure that is not to be missed.

A separate review for Uncharted 4 + The Lost Legacy

Uncharted 4 - 9.5/10
I love this game. It's probably within my top 10 video games I've played. But its definitely not perfect. 

What I love about the game are the characters, Nathan Drake, Sam Drake, Sully, Elena, and Rafe, are all absolutely fantastic characters. Nathan Drake is one of my favourite characters in media. Sam is a fantastic side character that plays such an important part in the narrative. Sully, though limited with his screen time, is an amazing character to have when he's here. And Elena is great too. All of the characters are very well acted and totally believable.
Nolan North (Nathan) and Warren Cole (Rafe) give some of the best performances in video game history, along side the best video game voice actor Troy Baker as Sam Drake. 

The overall narrative is very gripping and engaging. The movement is very addictive. The graphics are jaw dropping.
The combat is decent. The dialogue is perfect and hilarious throughout the entire game.

The big bad in each game has always been really evil bastards (warlords, generals, etc.). You know, really evil guys. In part 4 it's a guy who's a bit sad that the Drake brothers didn't want to join his team. So that part of the story was also a letdown.

The final letdown was the ending; as this is the final installment of the series I hoped for a really cool ending, but it was just meh.

The game is still well made, but compared to the previous ones I liked this one the least.

If I could explain the game in one sentence: "A mixed bag of experiences."

The animations and graphics, while not cutting-edge by today's standards, still manage to impress. They haven't aged particularly well, but they get the job done.

The story in Uncharted 4 is a highlight, showcasing Naughty Dog's mastery of cinematics and dialogue. It's an engaging narrative with well-crafted characters that keep you invested throughout. However, there's a glaring dissonance between the compelling story and the gameplay (why is there SO MUCH shooting? how come all these wonders laid undiscovered for so long?). When you find yourself engaging in the exciting actions for the umpteenth time in a single hour, the thrill starts to wear thin.

One major downside is the mouse & keyboard controls. They can be clunky and frustrating at times, which can hamper your overall experience. Fortunately, there is a silver lining—you can disable QTEs in favor of holding buttons, making those moments a bit more manageable.

In the end, this is a worthwhile experience for fans of the series or those looking for a solid story-driven game. Buy on sale.

Uncharted 4 was one of my favourite games when I played it on a PS4, and it's still an absolute must-play adventure game. That said, this port has multiple issues that make the overall package less polished than the same game I played a few years ago. I'm playing on a high-end 4K 120 FPS setup with HDR which may have contributed to some of these issues. Those problems include:

 [list]
    [*]Occasionally scene transitions between chapters will not fade in/out correctly between each other. In these cases the scene presents as a cut to black with the audio continuing as normal which takes you out of the story immediately.
    [*]During gameplay, I noticed flickering brightness which seemed to vary with camera angle. Also, sometimes the entire image will flash rainbow artifacts.
    [*]Some visual effects (like smoke effects and some explosions) and cutscenes appear to playback at 30 FPS / a lower FPS than used for gameplay (120 FPS in my case).
    [*]Occasional issues with audio cut-outs. I don't consider the "Audio Latency" option in settings to be a reasonable mitigation as it introduces more delay between video/audio than acceptable IMO.
    [*]Shadow quality, even on the "Ultra" setting, is still quite aliased. This shows up best in the 2nd half of the game in forested environments where trees above the player cast shadows on the ground in front of you.
[/list]

These issues are being tracked on PC Gaming Wiki and hopefully a fix is identified in the future: https://www.pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Uncharted:_Legacy_of_Thieves_Collection

Compared to my experience playing this game on a PS4, it was disappointing to have what was ultimately a buggier experience than the original game. However, this PC port (and throwing high-end specs at it) can offer much higher resolution + FPS + DLSS-enhanced picture quality as well, which looks fantastic.

Overall I recommend, but it sucks to have these caveats existing at all in what I think is a 10/10 game otherwise.

Note: This review is specific to the Uncharted 4 content within this game. I have not yet played Lost Legacy.
