I'm glad to see at least these two Uncharted games come to PC. The franchise is one of my favorites. I enjoy the mix of action and platforming, and especially the ability to use stealth in many situations. A good purchase if you enjoy the Tomb Raider reboot games.

A Thief's End was a nice ending to Nathan's story. I enjoyed the time spent with the characters, and it left them in a good place. Nathan's previously unmentioned brother showing up was sudden, but after a little while he fit right in for me. I liked the callbacks to the previous games in the form of the cabinet of treasures, it brought back some memories.

The Lost Legacy actually edges A Thief's End out by just a hair as my favorite Uncharted game. I initially wasn't sure about having a protagonist other than Nate, but it worked great. It still felt like an Uncharted game, which is the important thing to me. The visuals were great as usual, and the semi open world areas were a good addition. I wouldn't want too much more area than what was there though. The story was fairly typical for the series, but enjoyable. I wouldn't mind them being a little longer, I clocked in around 6.5 hours for the story, including grabbing some treasures along the way. I also managed to use stealth through many of the levels that allow it.

A Thief's End ran great the whole way through. The graphics quality was a big jump from Uncharted 3, and the PC port also helped make things just a little nicer as well.

I had a bit of trouble with The Lost Legacy during my playthrough, mostly freezes and crashing to desktop. Every time it happened was around water, so could be something to do with that. I found that limiting the fps to 30 allowed me to get past the area, and I could remove the limit until the next crash. Other than that the experience was good.

If you've played other Adventure / Treasure Hunter games (think Tomb Raider), then you'll probably find this a mediocre addition to the genre.  If, however, you played Uncharted 1, 2, and 3 and would like to see how the story ends, by all means play this.

Uncharted 4 is a lot less over-the-top than the previous titles. The most extreme scene here is falling while a building, a pirate ship, or the ground collapses around you. No falling off a mountain on a train, climbing to escape a sinking cruise ship, or ensuring you don't die while falling from a plane. Uncharted 4 is quite bland in that regard. Plus the enemies are nothing more than a well-funded wannabe archaeologist and his pet army--nothing impressive and far more boring than I would expect from an Uncharted title. The locations, however, are just as spectacular as any scene in the earlier games. I thought the main story was also enjoyable as each chapter slowly revealed a great pirate legacy gone bad, thought the individual character interactions were quite dry with Nate's brother Sam possibly being the least enjoyable companion Nate has ever had. Uncharted 4 adds three new climbing mechanics and seems to focus the entirety of climbing around using those mechanics. Combat adds stealth, which actually makes the combat worse. Now you have very circuitous battle arenas instead of a straight path through enemies. Stealth combat feels like a bad clone early Assassin's Creed titles. Puzzles are toned down considerably, with maybe only two puzzles really requiring any effort. I think I would summarize Uncharted 4 as a mostly-enjoyable, gorgeous adventure that has toned down all the extreme elements that made the Uncharted series stand out from other games in the genre leaving players with a Tomb Raider knock off that isn't nearly as good as any previous game in the series.

Lost Legacy is a mini adventure following but unrelated to the events of Uncharted 4.  I like that Naughty Dog tried something new here. The semi-open world in Chapter 4 was a fun diversion full of optional puzzles. I also appreciate the new lockpicking mechanic. The rest of the game is basically what I expect from Uncharted: enjoyable banter between characters, amazing locations, and fun puzzles.

Uncharted: Legacy of Thieves Collection was a very fun experience and I am very glad I finally gave it a try.

While I have never played an Uncharted game before, I caught up on the story with some recaps online, and I really wish I had the hardware to play those, but it left me very excited and able to understand what was happening in the base game of Uncharted 4: A Thief's End. I thought the story was fun, the gameplay was easy enough for me to understand and have a thrilling time jumping around and solving puzzles, the music was awesome, the acting was memorable, and the presentation of everything kept me very invested.

Graphically, this game looked amazing, though I did suffer some small technical issues. My NVIDIA Geforce told me my optimal settings for my PC was max settings, though to get the game to run smoothly on my 2060 GPU I had to turn everything down to minimum settings, which was a weird contrast. I'm not sure what went wrong there, but everything still looked great at those settings. I also did suffer from frequent loading times, giving me a clue as to when a larger action section would commence, though I understand I don't have the best hardware. Also regarding the included spin-off, Uncharted: The Lost Legacy, the Xbox controller I was playing with wasn't very responsive and I needed to tweak some settings in Steam itself in order to get things to work, and that was a little annoying.

But with those client side complaints out of the way, I still echo what I said above that I really enjoyed both games included. Uncharted 4 was definitely the more grand and fulfilling experience with an exciting story and characters, and I really enjoyed living in a modern adventure setting that reminded me of great action movies, I really enjoyed the journey it let me take as the protagonist. I really liked exploring the land, finding weapons, clearing some henchmen, locating treasures, and solving puzzles. So many settings felt unique and fully realized, and it made me not want to take long breaks, I wanted to jump back in every chance I could up through the end. The Lost Legacy spin-off was also very fun, while not as deep or emotional to me personally, and I am aware there are probably some great character moments I missed due to not playing the previous games, I still had fun for the same reasons. I liked playing as both Nathan Drake and Chloe Frazer, I felt awesome accomplishing what I needed to as both characters, but obviously the base game takes precedent and is probably more keen on grabbing your attention, but I would definitely give both a chance, I was glad I did.

So despite some small technical issues, I highly recommend this Uncharted experience. I really enjoyed a fun and easy single player story, and I hope they continue bringing more console exclusives to the PC market, mainly Steam since it is the most consistent and accessible platform for me. I am eager to play more someday, whether it would be from Naughty Dog or not, I'm so glad I get to experience these console games and I hope the future is bright for more accessibility like this.

Uncharted 4 A Thief's End Review

Back in the day, Uncharted 4 experience was a technological and cinematic advancement within PS4 era BUT as the time has passed by, this game has not aged the way I imagined.  

Unch 4, like any ND game is a straightforward linear adventure that focuses on a cinematic experience with high production values, while it succeeds in most ways it also falls short in many due to its limited space in each sequence. 

While uncharted 4 packs the most varied adventure Nathan Drake has ever experienced, it comes with many awkward plot holes that leaves the the entire franchise in a awkward position. Story pacing also does not help to enhance or cover up these grey areas, rather they feel like filler to extend the length of game. 

Gameplay is a your simple, linear action adventure that also drags too long for what it tries to tell. however, chapter to chapter the experience unfolds in different ways. That said Uncharted 4 suffers from excessive use of repetitive mechanics.

Game opens up with a look in late game, then jumps back to Nate's past (when he was kid in orphanage) to explain a little bit of his relationship with Sam and then once again, it jumps back to future that unfolds Nate's married life with Elena to picture his daily life. This is a couple hours in the game and pretty much you have done nothing but navigating corridor to corridor or moving from point A to point B.

The entire prison scene is a messy, boring section that sets up the gang on a journey to look for Avery. The long standing Drake's family dream to locate the long lost Paradise of Pirates. Initially being a mother's dream has now turned into Sam's life long obsession brings the entire game together (excluding Chloe) to conquer this long standing dream. HOWEVER, as good and as emotional and as dramatic this sounds like, Nate is not clearly keen on this and the only reason Nate sets foot on this path is to rescue Sam from his debt (which is a made up story just to get people petty on him). There is no sense of family with this brothers and its ODD that Nate broke his promise of having a adventure free life. this happens while game tries to show Nate is thirsty for one last crazy adventure which contradicts with the entire setup. 

Next on the line is Sally booking a trip to a private auction house that a key piece of puzzle to find Pirate's Paradise (now called Libertalia) is there. This is one of the best chapters in the game.

the next chapter the boys take it to a old graveyard where they assume they can possibly seek clues to where libertalia is. this is where, shoreline is introduced properly to the game and Drake's brothers enemy, Rafe and Nadine are also explained. Rafe is not really an interesting cuz he is often not close to even being a threat to game. He does not have any dominating presence, he appears as opposite side of Sam, another fellow being obsessed finding Henry treasure. Nadine tho, introduced as Shoreline leader, receives a bit more story and development through the game itself and poses herself more in spotlight than Rafe. 
This section of game also introduces the player to stealth and it takes you around a boring stroll of caves and clifs and the usual platforming that just drags too long before exploring a crypt with some interesting puzzles. 

The next chapter, takes the gang to a more open area where you use a car to traverse the linear but bigger areas with a few rooms for exploration and treasure hunting. luckily you are free of excessive platforming and the car physics are actually amazing. I truely enjoyed exploring this land as it is rich with details, dialogues and places to see. There are multiple arenas in this map where the game allows you to have your own way of approaching the enemy which is a fresh change from its usual linear pace.

The next chapter has Nate and Sam setting a trip to a collection of Island where Henry  had included in the previous chapter This chapter is another open worldish map with focus on Nate and Sam riding the boat around island to look for clues. Unlike previous chapter, This chapter is another boring, only exploring chapter. While it is visually pleasing and the vistas are beautiful but essentially combination of platforming, exploring.

I will avoid more spoilers between but the next chapter is where Nate's globe journey has come to an end and he has landed in the island where Libertalia is built. This is where the game truley embraces the old souls of an Uncharted game long forgotten in early hours due to heavy narrative and platforming. While we do not see a decrease in platforming, the island is rich in narrating and showing how pirates settled down, in beautiful and lush with flora and amazing lighting and its filled with few interesting battle sections which includes enemies on different levels of rocks and platforms which demands you to be quicker and take more risk in positioning yourself. Nate reunites and Sam and they discover Libertalia, the long lost pirate land. While it takes a while to pick up the pace once again the Libertalia is worth all the wait to this point. 

Nate and Sam are fascinated as the player is with the majestic architecture of the Libertalia and it is such a joyous ride to see the life of pirates, their houses, districts, letters and notes left and much more to see. 

The next chapter takes place (FINALLY) With Nate and Elena. Tho, the story never explains how Elena found Nate, it is finally awesome to see my fav duo are once again back together. This short adventure is the best part of Uncharted IMO. It explores the much needed development that we were seeking between Nate and Elena and it also advances the story with Sam and Nate as he finally draws a line between him and his relationship. You get to solve puzzles with Elena, take out enemies together, drive car, cross through crumbling ruins, explores last diner of Avery and take a stroll through their luxury life and streets before heading to where treasure is. Honestly, this part was the most memorable part of campaign. 

The game last chapter takes Nate to where Henry ship is and the game concludes with a gimicky and lame boss fight between Nate and Rafe. While its concept is exciting to witness as it portairs two pirates  in a ship ravaged by war of their own, the fight itself is underwhelming. 

This campaign is filled with ups and downs and the gameplay is really dependent on the chapter you are. I just feel like the story is too messy and there are a lot of bad boring fillers and the excessive use of platforming eventually makes brings many dull and boring moments. 

In contrast, Lost Legacy fixes some of this issues by telling a very seamless story which involves Chloe and Nadine on treasure hunt in India vs a much more well developed, tho cliche antagonist, Asav. Nadine character never really catches up tho. She is lame, bad and unexplained. While eventually we find her motives, it never really makes sense why Chloe went after the once leader of shoreline who is now a weak character in the series. 

Lost Legacy majority is spend in a massive open world areas with much more denser main and side content to explore and there are more challenging puzzles than main game. Lost legacy eventually takes you on a amazing tour within Indian temples and there are many memorable set pieces and locations. I cant beleive, but this DLC offers much more polished gameplay than original game. While the plot is not as complicated, it focus on Chloe as a treasure hunter and it takes on an amazing character with much less dull and filler moments.

Uncharted has always been a cornerstone of Sony's first party line up and it easy to see why. Nathan Drake's journey to find the lost treasure of the pirate Henry Avery's Gournsway Heist leads him across the globe, gets in the way of his happily married life with journalist and fellow adventurer Elena Fisher and his legitimate salvaging job that allows him to remain somewhat connected to his old lifestyle, and reunites him with a ghost; his brother whom he thought had past years earlier while finding an early clue to the treasures location.

As a story, it holds up rather well, being an Indiana Jones style rip-roaring adventure across the globe, with a colorful and fun cast of characters. Nathan Drake himself is most easily described as "like a Nathan Fillion character"; case in point, Nathan Fillion himself stars as Drake in a fan film on youtube if you want/need a brief primer for the character... we don't need to talk about the movie. His brother Sam fills in an older brother archetype, while matching Nate's charm with his own sardonic wit. Sully doesn't wanna be here, but is because he loves Nate like a close nephew. Pacing is nice, allowing for some slow moments alone, huge fast gunfights, tense moments, and satisfying payoffs. its pretty long and It also doesn't pull a late-game supernatural twist like the previous games in the series do (the lost treasure of El Dorado made those who opened it zombies, The Chintamani Stone AKA the Philosopher's Stone turned those who used it into Yeti things, 3 featured like psychedelic water or something, i dont remember lol.)

Gameplay checks the boxes of "good singleplayer game" these days--encounters start with a period of stealth which allow you to scout enemies, takedown enemies quietly, and plan the engagement. those encounters are spaced out by sections of climbing and exploration, puzzle solving, story dialogue, and the odd vehicle section with a more open map.

soundtrack is generally great, but as a fan of the series, i can't help but feel its a slight downgrade from Greg Edmondson's soundtracks for 1-3. Nathan's Theme in particular to me is just much worse and lost all sense of the "epic adventure" feel it used to have. other than that, it fits the vibes, takes a backseat when needed, and works well.

Perfomances are excellent across the board, with Warren Kole (Rafe) and Laura Bailey (Nadine) delivering the IMO best performances, but Nolan North (Nathan), Richard McGonagle (Sully), and Emily Rose (Elena) are excellent reprising their characters, and Troy Baker is, as usual, also fantastic as Sam.

Cons are minimal, it lacks some replayability because its a very linear game, its missing some of my favorite characters from the series (Charlie Cutter is mentioned but like Chloe, is missing from this one). TBF, this also contains the Lost Legacy which stars Chloe as the protagonist working alongside Nadine, but i haven't played much of it. its also missing its very strong multiplayer component for like no reason. for that reason alone i'd recommend waiting for a sale, but its not a full price game on its own and again, includes Lost Legacy, which was big enough to be its own game instead of a DLC, i can't say the regular price isn't fair.

At this point I have to accept that Naughty Dogs' games are not for me.

I had the original trilogy and this game on the PS4 for YEARS before I started them. And when I did, just like with The Last of Us, the extraordinary presentation for me was degraded by utterly abysmal gameplay, especially combat. I like a fun action movie once in a while, even the wise-cracking sort that was the inspiration for the non-stop-talking Drake brothers, but in those case I actually WATCH a movie.

Funnily enough I am a huge fan of narrative games as my review history will prove, but those are usually unique, rewarding experiences that leave lasting impressions. Uncharted 4, both on Playstation and on PC, is a solid but unrewarding movie experience with frustrating combat and too much snark to be entertaining in 2023. Instead, all characters are mostly annoying, especially Nathan lying to his wife to go adventuring with his brother. Lack of communication and honesty is my biggest pet pieve in entertainment (movies, books, series, etc.) and it is just lazy, lazy, lazy story-telling.

The beautiful scenery of the game could still make this a fun ride. Not every movie/game needs to be unique and groundbreaking, play-it-safe action adventures do have their merit as well -- BUT, remember this is a game, so it has so-called "gameplay" sections. In the case of Uncharted 4, these are in pretty much repeating order:
1. parcour that has the animations morph the characters into the right place without realism through a railroaded world, 
2. a mediocre "puzzle" that is too obvious to even engage more than 2 brain cells, 
3. a cover shooter section with conveniently placed half-height walls, explosive barrels and dozens of braindead enemies that spawn seemingly out of nowhere in endless supply until a specific number of them have died, 
4. repeat at 1.

During all of this, Nathan (and Sam) never shut up with the wise-cracking banter. Just like the three aforementioned sections, the game desperately tries to uphold a breakneck speed and constantly assaults the player's senses to stop them from actually thinking about anything that's happening. Because if they did, the nonsensical timelines, dialogue and character motivations would rear their ugly head. Naughty Dog has a reputation for excellent stories, but in all the games I played, I only see Hollywood-blockbuster-level adventures with mass market appeal -- well, I guess that explains the reputation... Maybe it's my fault, spending too many hours of my youth, watching almost every iMDB Top 250 movie, but it's just disappointingly shallow to me. Without all the hype I might have a different opinion...

Something which I would not have a different opinion about is the combat, though. I already mentioned the lazy setup, but what really frustrates me is the revolting "accuracy". They ported the game to the PC, looked at the mouse and said "Nah, too accurate" and slapped a randomizer on the algorithm to ensure that almost every enemy requires a full magazine or more to die because even though the reticule is pointing squarely at the head the game feels it is "more realistic" to miss half the time. I hated the combat on the Playstation, but it is no better with mouse and keyboard. Others may like the "incentive to move around", but I truly hate the combat in Uncharted (any game!). It is the single biggest reason why I usually stop playing after about an hour.

Many words, again, for a non-recommendation. I want to continue playing, as I finally want to finish this game after having bought it almost ten years ago, but it tries really, really hard to make me regret it.

Edit: Tried again two months later after a few indie titles and BG3. What a bad idea. I didn't last more than 20 minutes before I rage-quit. What a disappointment.

[h2]I tried so hard to give it a positive review, but I'cant  [/h2]

Uncharted is my favourite game franchise, I bought the PS3 only 'coz uncharted. And don't get me wrong: this game is a masterpiece, and it trully deserves a 10/10 review. [b] But there are soo many issues with this port... [/b]

[h2] The good... [/h2]
1. [b] I enjoyed the story: [/b] its not a 10/10 motive, but the character development is as good as other uncharted games, the drama, the dialogs, I was hooked from beginning to end.

2. [b] It looks beautiful: [/b] maps, effects, textures, its just stunning, and its an old game already. 

3. [b] The grappling hook mechanic is the best of its kind [/b], the way it interacts with objects and the map, its just incredible, you wouldn't understand it until you play it, more games should take inspiration of the physics and mechanics of it.

4. [b] The music is just on the spot [/b] The action / combat music is soo good, how it changes depending of the aggression of the enemies, it adapts to the combat situation and is so good. The general OST is also really good.

5. [b] It completes part of the mysteries of the older Uncharted games [/b] Who is Drake? Their parents? Did he had family? Evth has an explanation now. Its an incredible follow up + prequel. 

[h2] The bad... [/h2]
[h3] Bugs...[/h3]
1. [b] Characters randomly T posing in cinematics.[/b] And if it happen too often, it will interrupt the dialog, and no more sounds/text, you'd need to restart from checkpoint.

2. [b] UI crashes [/b] 
Drake can squish trough a really narrow spaces/holes to uncover new areas... It can happen than when approaching the place, and pressing the "E" button, the game UI hides, and nothing happens (no animation), you cant open the menu coz the UI is hidden and you can walk everywhere slowly but cant do anything. Only way to continue is open task manager and kill the game and restart from save. Once loaded, you will be in the other side of the hole.

It happened twice during my playthroug (spoiler alert):
First [spoiler] underneath the cathedral chapter 8 [/spoiler]. second time [spoiler] In the same chapter, later on when getting closer to the final puzzle[/spoiler].

3. [b]The 87% loading screens of death. [/b]
This game loads randomly before (or during) actions scenes, it can happen that the game just pauses and keeps loading forever, with taking minutes for each 1%, and then stopping at 87%. The UI doesnt work, only wayt to play is closing the game and restart from save.
 
[h3] Optimization issues...[/h3]
[b] LOADING... [/b]
The game loads every now and then: it takes from 10 secs up to 1 minute to load. Sometimes it can crash how I said in the bugs section.

Well lets talk about [b] the well known Uncharted 4 car/truck chase.[/b] That scene is 10 minutes of pure adrenaline. Its probably the best chase of all time in video-games I'd even say that i has better action than most action movies, its legendary (just search it in youtube, its incredible).

Well that part [b] is unplayable in PC:[/b] every 20 secs the game stops mid chase to load for some seconds up to minutes. Its just unplayable, it gave me like 30 loading screens in that chase. A chase that on ps4 was 10 mins, it took me 30 minutes to complete on PC 'coz loading screens.

[h3] Is there anyway to fix this?[/h3]
Well I tried to play this game on 2 different computers:

The first one, a really old PC with a 1050ti, i7 10k series processor, and a SSD. And had all the issues listed above, ran on low graphics at 40-50 fps, with some major fps drops close to loading screens.

The second time, I played it on a PC with an RTX 2080, an i9 9k series, and a M.2. And it looked better, FPS over 60, but the issues didn't disappear at all, the loading screens were still there and were as annoying as before, no changes.

[h2] Summarizing [/h2]
I just cant give a perfect score, and to be honest, it kinda breaks my heart to give this review.

I will continue playing this game, 'coz I already paid for it, and no way i'd get a refund at this point. I havent finished yet.

[b]On Playstation consoles[/b]: this game is truly a [b]10/10[/b] masterpiece.
[b]On PC: 3/10[/b], its not worth to play with all these issues.

Uncharted 4: A very good game. 8/10. Story, writing, voice acting, graphics, and location changes were the highlights here. Climbing was serviceable, but better than most other climbing games to be honest. Puzzles were very simple, combat was a side note, and there were a handful of bugs (most likely due to high frame rate). Performance was pretty great overall.

The attention to detail and overall cinematic game design was very immersive at times. Pistol fully out of ammo after a gunfight? You can see it in the next cut-scene with the release all the way back. Small actions like collectibles and branching paths gives you a little freedom, and with unique voice lines to match. You can tell the level design was hand crafted to give you gorgeous views as well, even picture taking locations as well for further emphasis. Hats off to the devs.

Overall, would highly recommend as a pure action game with really engaging characters. I beat it in around 11 hours, so its not too long either.

Lost Legacy: A very solid addition to the franchise. Largely the same feel as Uncharted 4, with same guns, mechanics, and enemies mainly. Pretty short, around 6 hours to beat. Characters had plenty of engaging dialogue, if not a little bit over the top on sarcastic comments (they were non stop the entire time).
Game crashes within first few minutes of gameplay, which is especially disappointing given that it makes you wait an hour for the shaders to compile. Requested refund.

I've played early Uncharted from the very first to 3 in my childhood PS3 days.
It always follows the same formula. Climb your way, find stuff, solve puzzles and survive ambushes in hit 'n run style. However, there wasn't a single moment where I would say this to be repetitive.

Naughty Dog is one of my favorite developers out there and one of the reasons why it prevents repetitiveness would be its stunning visuals and graphics. There were times where I simply stood still and admired the view, it was breath taking.

Next reason to break the repetitive climb simulator would be the story campaign combined with its pacing. It provides a rich dialogue and backstories of our fellow Drake and its members to make us understand their actions and reasons. The quick time events are so amazing that I don’t recognize any sloppy teleported movements, at most I only see some minor motion tween corrections before certain actions/cutscenes when it comes to interacting with objects (most games have that anyway).

The new character introduction, that being Drake’s brother Sam felt a bit forced, although they included a large amount of backstory to make up for it.

I have to add that the other game “The Lost Legacy” felt really rushed. The traditions like for example finding treasures in hidden areas was replaced by being inside lockboxes, behind breakable walls or simply being found out using the magic bracelet. The story removed Drake for the first time and replaced him with Chole who was only a temporary character in some of the Uncharted games and Ross from Thieves End which lacked proper explanation on how these two got together.

But that’s no way to leave a negative review. I paid 30€ for the price of two games of which I used to pay far more for only a single Uncharted title back in the day. I do however miss the multiplayer content, especially its co-op it used to have.

[h1]A Thief's End[/h1]
Uncharted is my favourite adventure franchise in gaming
especially while uncharted 2 raised the bar so high back then and is the best in the series aside from this.
This game changes the uncharted formula of insanely epic yet dumb sequences, over the top action to a much more realistic and grounded approach and i loved it.
Naughty dog is second to none when it comes to creating lifelike virtual experiences and this game being 7 years old now is still one of the best looking games ever made.
The gameplay is as fluid and smooth as it can be and
The Animations make the characters feel truly alive.
The environments feel like big playgrounds to freely move and shoot around in however you want.
The story feels like a grand journey again with decent character development and alot of cool moments with flashbacks as well as twists and turns. The writing and voice acting again makes the characters and the story feel really alive as well as cinematic. 
The ending is pretty satisfying and gives Nathan's story a proper conclusion.
I wish there were more iconic and insane set pieces like the previous titles had but this version has its own charm and its one hell of an experience.
definitely one of my most favourite games ever.

[h2]Lost Legacy[/h2] 
I didn't know what to expect from this but after playing this i am surprised how little attention it got and how much more it deserved. The story revolves around Chloe and Nadine from the previous uncharted games and is set after the events of Uncharted 4. The story depicts india and hindu culture extremely well and like never before in a huge title like this. I was blown away by how much research and efforts they did to showcase and blend the mythology in this game with the stories and the stunning environments even cooler than a lot of Uncharted 4 environments. The game does a really good job at making us care about Chloe and gives her depth as a character. The story is not as well written and is mostly very predictable but keeps you hooked as it goes on and the villain is pretty good this time. As an Indian, i love hearing them talk about stories of Ganesh and Shiva and they handled it with utmost respect and dedication.
The gameplay and mechanics carry over from 4 and they are just as smooth and enjoyable here.
The Final hour of the game is my favourite with nonstop, insane and chaotic action. This also has a very satisfying ending for the most part concluding this short yet epic adventure.

Sony, I will gladly sell my soul to you guys just keep bringing more of these masterpieces to PC

This game positively surprised me.
I honestly always kinda.. just dismissed this game as a console exclusive tomb raider knockoff. Guy with a douchy haircut does stuff Lara does better. It being a console exclusive made it easy to dismiss.
But.. while it still is very much a tomb raider knockoff, it was actually pretty good.

Story is serviceable - it is intruiging but way too hard to believe. In Tomb Raider, you could kinda hand wave "how did they build all this" by it being built by an ancient civilisation over who knows how many years. But being built by pirates over what looks like one or two decades? Without anyone noticing? Not being found despite being very visible from the sky? With some clues built right in the middle of a city? I can only stretch my suspension of disbelief so far.
The antagonist being a literal private army, too. I dunno why but I have a less hard time to believe a bunch of religious zealots going after a fabled artifact than a private army searching a lost treasure. It being a treasure as welll always sat in the back of my mind. "So at this point I'm maybe a hour ahead of the private army. So if I find that treasure now, something which would need a whole team and plenty of time to pack up and secure, what then? just taking a coin and leaving the rest for them?"

But I may be a bit unfair. It's par for the course that such stories/games are unbelievable.

The combat is horsecrap tho. I can't be 100% sure but I'm pretty certain enemies sometimes spawn behind you. Several time I advanced on the enemy, scouted them out while hidden etc., searched out a good position, initiated combat.. just to suddenly being shot at from the side or behind. Not that great for a cover based fighting system if the cover is not working because they do a nothin personnel. Their grenade throwing game is on point too. you can sit on a small platform and the enemy can be like 20 meters way, if they throw a grenade, it will land on your platform, right at your feet, every time.

The game is one game with /two/ complete stories. There's about thirty hours total of running, jumping, climbing and swinging.  There's a few relatively simple puzzles, and some pretty basic and simplistic gun-play.  There's a bunch of cinematics, but the game doesn't lean into quick-time events like other cinematic-heavy games. There's only one puzzle that /really/ sucks, and only one 'race'. If anything, the common complaint that the game is just a climbing simulator are kind of fair. There's a lot of the game that you can progress through just by holding the stick in a generally-up direction while pressing jump repeatedly.

The stories are pretty good, if you're willing to do the usual suspension of disbelief required to believe that a mechanism made of wood would still be functional after hundreds of years in a dense jungle. If you're willing to forgive that someone can jump fifty feet down, and catch themselves on a narrow ledge with their fingertips repeatedly, you'll be okay.

The game is weirdly linear, but is artfully designed to hide that. It skates an interesting knife edge. Most often, there's brightly-colored ledges that describe a painfully obvious path up a cliff. But there are other times when if feels like you're allowed to go wandering off in the woods, and yet I've found that even then you're being subtly manipulated to a destination, so that it is actually quite difficult to get lost.  Death, too, is generally rare, and is more likely from you misjudging the direction of something more than ... I don't know, skill? The game is pretty good at offering hints about what's grabbable and what isn't.  But when it all goes wrong, the auto-save is usually VERY close, and more than fast enough.  Death is not expensive, and therefore not to be feared.

Both stories have driving sections, and they're some of the best ever seen in a game that wasn't trying to be an off-road driving simulator. 

The voice acting is top-notch, with some of the best voices in the business taking time behind the mic. Fortunately, the writers have given them good things to say, too.  You can easily fall in love with all the characters, and there were a few places where I laughed out loud at their wry responses to things.  The models are also very good. These came from the PS4 era where they were showing off their ability to do hair, so many characters benefit from a well-grizzled look. Clothing gets wet after a character jumps into water. And, of course, they will often exclaim "Ah! Brisk!" about it.

Oh, and speaking of the PS4, one of the platform features of it was a flaky flashlight. You'd have to shake the DualShock controller to get the light to work again. This is implemented on the XBox360 controller with just wiggling the stick. Otherwise, the port is pretty clean and successful, and other than the flashlight silliness I didn't notice any controller mapping problems at all. 

The biggest complaint I have is that the game fails to stream correctly during some of the longer driving scenes. The game will come to a sudden pause, a loading screen will pop up, run for an unpredictable stretch of time. Don't think you can use this time to take a break, though, because it will suddenly unpause and throw you back into the action without any warning.  Then, a few seconds later, it happens again!  I think this is a defect, and I hope they fix it before you buy it.

Everyone knows this game is amazing. Know what else is also amazing? Churros. Churros are amazing, and here's how to make them:

· Water: This recipe for churros starts with a cup of water.
· Sugar: White sugar goes into the churro dough and into the cinnamon-sugar topping.
· Salt: A pinch of salt enhances the flavors of the other ingredients.
· Oil: You'll need vegetable oil for the dough and to fry the churros.
· Flour: All-purpose flour gives the churro dough structure.
· Cinnamon: The fried churros are rolled in a cinnamon-sugar mixture before serving.

1. Boil water, sugar, salt, and vegetable oil. Remove from the heat, then stir in flour.
2. Transfer the dough to a pastry bag and pipe into strips.
3. Fry the strips in hot oil until they're golden.
4. Drain the churros, then roll in cinnamon-sugar.

Uncharted: Legacy of Thieves Collection is a great port of the two PlayStation 4 games, Uncharted 4: A Thief's End and Uncharted: Lost Legacy. It features improved graphics, higher frame rates, and support for mouse and keyboard controls. The game is still as engaging and satisfying as ever, and it looks and plays better than ever on PC.

Here are some of the pros and cons of the PC port:

Pros:

Improved graphics
Higher frame rates
Mouse and keyboard controls
Support for ultrawide monitors
New difficulty modes
Photo mode

Cons:

Some technical issues
No DualSense support
Pricey

Overall, Uncharted: Legacy of Thieves Collection PC is a great port of a great game. If you're a fan of the series, or if you're new to Uncharted, I highly recommend checking it out.

Here are some of the technical issues that have been reported:

Stuttering
Frame rate drops
Crashes
Audio issues

Naughty Dog has released several patches to address these issues, but some of them persist. It is unclear when the game will be fully patched, but Naughty Dog has said that they are committed to fixing the issues.

If you are considering buying Uncharted: Legacy of Thieves Collection PC, I recommend waiting until the game has been patched further. This will ensure that you have the best possible experience.

Here are some of the things that I liked about the PC port:

The graphics are stunning. The game looks better than ever on PC, with improved textures, lighting, and shadows.

The frame rate is smooth. The game runs at a locked 60fps on most systems, which makes the gameplay feel fluid and responsive.

The mouse and keyboard controls are well-implemented. The controls are responsive and easy to use, and they offer a lot of flexibility.

The support for ultrawide monitors is great. The game looks amazing on ultrawide monitors, and the extra screen space is helpful in combat.

The new difficulty modes are challenging but fair. The new difficulty modes offer a great challenge for experienced players, while still being accessible to newcomers.

The photo mode is a lot of fun. The photo mode is a great way to capture your favourite moments in the game, and it's easy to use.

Here are some of the things that I didn't like about the PC port:

Some technical issues. There are a few technical issues that have been reported, such as stuttering, frame rate drops, and crashes. These issues can be frustrating, but they are not game-breaking.

No DualSense support. The DualSense controller is not supported, which is a shame. The 

DualSense controller's haptic feedback and adaptive triggers would have been a great addition to the game.

Pricey. The game is a bit pricey, but it is worth the price if you're a fan of the series.

Overall, Uncharted: Legacy of Thieves Collection PC is a great port of a great game. If you're a fan of the series, or if you're new to Uncharted, I highly recommend checking it out.

Title: "A Captivating Adventure Like No Other - Uncharted 4: A Thief's End"

Uncharted 4: A Thief's End is a true masterpiece that showcases the pinnacle of storytelling and gameplay in the world of video games. Naughty Dog has once again delivered an unparalleled gaming experience that leaves players spellbound from the very beginning.

The game follows the journey of Nathan Drake, a charming and adventurous treasure hunter, as he embarks on a quest that takes him across the globe in search of unimaginable riches. From the lush jungles of Madagascar to the sun-soaked landscapes of Italy, each location is exquisitely detailed, making the world of Uncharted 4 feel alive and immersive.

The storytelling in Uncharted 4 is a triumph, seamlessly blending action, humor, and emotion into a captivating narrative. The character development is top-notch, with Nathan Drake evolving beyond the witty and daring adventurer we know, becoming a more complex and relatable protagonist. The interactions between characters are authentic, and players are emotionally invested in their struggles and triumphs.

The gameplay is a harmonious fusion of exploration, puzzle-solving, and intense combat sequences. From heart-pounding gunfights to exhilarating parkour and climbing sections, the gameplay remains engaging and polished throughout. The attention to detail in animations and environmental design is exceptional, further enhancing the sense of realism and immersion.

Moreover, Uncharted 4 boasts some of the most breathtaking graphics in gaming history. The visuals are nothing short of breathtaking, and the game's attention to detail and cinematic presentation push the boundaries of what a video game can achieve.

A Thief's End is not just about the action; it is a celebration of human relationships and the choices we make. The game poses profound questions about life, love, and legacy, leaving players contemplating their own journeys long after the credits roll.

The musical score deserves special mention as well. The soundtrack perfectly complements the atmosphere of each scene, heightening emotions and adding an extra layer of depth to the experience.

While Uncharted 4 may be the final chapter in Nathan Drake's story, it serves as a triumphant conclusion to an iconic franchise. The game's ending is a fitting tribute to the beloved characters and the unforgettable adventures they have shared.

In conclusion, Uncharted 4: A Thief's End is a gaming masterpiece that shines as one of the finest examples of storytelling and gameplay artistry. It is a thrilling, emotional, and unforgettable adventure that will forever hold a special place in the hearts of gamers worldwide. Naughty Dog has set an incredibly high bar for interactive storytelling, and Uncharted 4 remains a timeless classic that will be cherished for years to come.

This is from somebody who has not played any Uncharted games before but played (and enjoyed) the Tomb Raider reboot series. So, comparisons will be made.

The game gets a strong recommendation from me. It's a good game that I got a lot of fun out of for about 30 hours, 20 of those in "A Thief's End" and the rest in "Lost Legacy". If you've played one of the Tomb Raider reboot games and are looking for more along those lines, then I would naturally not recommend this one but the other Tomb Raider games. But this is certainly a good game to play after those. Or, if you had your gripes with the Tomb Raider games, you might prefer some of the areas where Uncharted takes a different approach. Those instances are not without merit.

I've played both parts on moderate difficulty. Gameplay and mechanics aren't overly ambitious or fancy by current standards but have a good enough amount of variety. Especially in "Lost Legacy" where they build on and extend what the other game had by introducing picking locks, C4 as a new kind of explosive that behaves a little bit differently, it is totally sufficient. Driving your Jeep is quite fun. And what's more: It all just seems to work without any hitches. I didn't have any technical difficulties whatsoever except for 2 crashes during a sequence late in "Lost Legacy". But it may well have been my PC running hot, because a few hours later everything worked just fine. I had none of the Tomb Raider glitches like where some ledges are just not reachable on a 4K resolution and you have to lower the resolution to get past certain areas. Everything just worked and the controls are consistent enough to become second nature in a short time.
Puzzle difficulty is rather mild, a tad bit higher in "Lost Legacy" than "A Thief's End" but not by much. It never took me very long to figure out what to do. No consultation of a walkthrough required. Sometimes game hints or cues from your companions make things almost a bit too easy. Similarly, visual cues for where to go aren't as on the nose as in Horizon Zero Dawn, for example. They don't ruin the immersion, but finding your way around also never gets too hard. In "A Thief's End" everything is a linear sequence of chapters with a linear sequence of places to explore. In "Lost Legacy" there is a chapter where you can branch out and explore various small ruins in a larger area in arbitrary order. There even is a little side-quest which earns you a an actual mechanical reward (the Queen's Ruby) that helps with the finding of Treasure. That part is a little reminiscent of how the Tomb Raider games handle areas, so yes, I liked that. Also that Queen's Ruby made me a lot more interested in actually hunting for collectibles than I had been in "A Thief's End". So, it was a well-balanced, meaningful addition.
Combat is interesting, if not the part of the game I care about most. And because I don't, I don't miss the crafting, improving gear, or buying gear, which is totally absent from the game.
Graphics hold up decently, quick-time-events are rare enough for me to consider them fine the way they are (not generally a fan). Oh, and you can save wherever and whenever you like. No need to first find a campsite if somebody calls you away from the computer. (Dare I mention Cenote on Deadly Obession difficulty in SotTR?)

When it comes to story-telling, my take is more nuanced. I'm OK with linear stories. I'm actually quite happy Uncharted stays away from the supernatural. The blend of actual historical background and legends is quite nicely done and can inspire some fun reading after playing the game. And I also appreciate that the protagonists don't even _claim_ to be archeologists while trampling through archeological sites. I also don't mind that there are moments where you shouldn't really think too hard about what's going on. (Like when your companion above you needs to go look for a crate to toss down to you so you can climb up, rather than just pull you up by the rope you're using all the time.) If you can't abide some logic flaws, you're not even getting through a single Tomb Raider game. 
The characters here feel perhaps a bit more real. In the Tomb Raider reboot series, Lara is full of inner turmoil and soul-searching to a point where in the third game you come close to wanting to shake her and tell her to finally get over her daddy issues. (Fortunately she kinda does.) The struggles of the protagonists here seem very toned down in comparison. The stakes also are not as cranked up to eleven. There is a motivation that's not saving the world from destruction. The downside of that is that I wasn't really invested in the story of "A Thief's End" for quite a while. I somehow couldn't get behind a brother who wanted to risk his life a gazillion times each day for weeks to save himself from a potential death in three months time. It was only after about two-thirds of the game, when Elena joins the fray, that things started to make sense again. Then, I could feel the urgency. And with that context the first part of the game had moments that verged on an annoying paperchase. You find a map to place. And in that place you find a map to another place. Then you follow that map to a tower and find directions to two other towers. In one of those you find a map of an island. You go to that island and find clues to another island. Then you go to that place and find out you need to go to another place on that island, and then the treasure isn't there anymore, either. By that time I was completely with Nathan and didn't even care about the treasure anymore. I just wanted to get off the stupid island. But of course that's not how the game played out. Still fun, but a little dragged-out. I liked the writing of "Lost Legacy" much better. I was on board from the first scene. However, it is a game that takes ten hours less to complete. So, it can be expected to be more concise and to the point.

So, if you can get through the scavenger hunt bits of the middle of "A Thief's End", it's a great bundle. At any kind of sale totally worthwhile spending 30 hours with Nathan, Sam, Elena, Chloe, and Nadine.

I love games like the newish Tomb Raiders and Uncharted generally, but something is just 'off' with Uncharted 4. Sluggish combat that feels great in a semi-realistic setting like TLOU does not work very well in a clearly gameified setting a la Uncharted's world. 

Nathan can swing like Tarzan on drugs, but you can die to a respawned enemy that suddenly is on the same ledge you had just been on. On that point, the AI is showing its age in a terrible way. Awkward cover mechanics, constant grenade spamming, and generally frustrating shooting sections become horrifically tedious by the *20th* chapter of the story. 

I wish ND could have stripped some of the clearly dated aspects out of this game before re-releasing it, but I got it on a heavy sale so I'm not too upset about the entire experience. 

TLDR; I know this is sacrilegous to say but, if you can, just play this on the easiest or normal difficulty. You'll enjoy the experience far more and just take in the story more than the insanely frustrating 'game' that holds it back.

DLSS is causing problems for me (available on my profile).
Saving after a certain chapter's start made me enter noclip with inverste controls for some reason.

Mandatory speedrun as one requirement to beat the game : A pain in the a** !

The ending/epilogue were a big let down. It half solves the adventure of this game with an ending that felt like a sequel bait in the way that would help expand the universe and who could be a protagonist if the series keeps going. There's no sense of resolution.

I'd recommend it IF and only if :
You played through the trilogy.
You're really good at this type of game.
Good at speedrunning.

If that's not the case, i recommend checking it out on PS4.
The trilogy didn't age well but still incredible games regardless.

[h1]Uncharted 4: [i]A Thief's End[/i][/h1][b]Exciting plot![/b] game from the [b]Naughty Dog[/b] franchise. The title, the first game in the saga for PS4 (now on PC) marks the return of [i]Nathan Drake[/i] in an adventure full of twists, charming graphics and a multiplayer mode that excites and surprises.

The plot of [b]Uncharted 4[/b] is very similar to other chapters in the series. This time, [i]Drake[/i] sets out on a new adventure to help his brother, [i]Sam[/i], recover a treasure so he can pay off a debt. However, even with the help of his old friend, [i]Sulivan[/i], it will be necessary to act stealthily so that his wife Elena does not find out, since Nathan himself had promised to retire from his career as an explorer.

[b]In the midst of all this, there is an intense search for treasure, twists, surprises (predictable for some), moments of emotion and a good dose of humor. A perfect script for adventure films...[/b]

That sounds good to fans and anyone who has played the other chapters in the series, as there are also references to previous adventures, as well as the return of iconic characters such as [i]Sulivan[/i] and [i]Elena[/i]. However, for those less patient and who don't care to follow much of the story, the long dialogues of Uncharted 4 can be uncomfortable.

[b][i]Sam Drake[/i]'s debut in the franchise also deserves praise. The inclusion of the protagonist's brother fits like a glove to give reason for a new plot, in addition to presenting a character so similar to Nathan and at the same time loaded with personalities. As well as villains and other characters, whose roles are important to the plot.[/b]

[h1]Small changes allied to a consecrated gameplay[/h1]
Uncharted's gameplay has always been one of the franchise's strengths. The way Drake climbs, jumps, grabs and moves is efficient even for those who are not so skilled with the controls, making the games in the series a good choice for those who have just bought their first console.

The successful formula remains in Uncharted 4, with some timid evolutions. The main one is Drake's hook, which makes the character reach higher platforms and advance great distances. All of this in the best Indiana Jones style.
There is also a greater focus on stealth. In many cases, it's more efficient to sneak up and take out your enemies one by one rather than simply opening fire on them all. For this, there are elements that help this approach, such as the high lawn, small alleys and higher platforms.

[h1]Paradisiacal look that convinces and delights[/h1]
The look of Uncharted 4 is by far one of the most beautiful of the current generation. The way in which the characters were reproduced is incredible, whether by physiognomy, facial expressions and even by synchronizing with the audio of the dialogues.
The whimsy extends to the scenarios. It's hard not to play without "printing" the screen repeatedly throughout the entire adventure. 

The places where [i]Drake[/i] travels are paradisiacal, either because of the context or the quality that [b]Naughty Dog[/b] exposed in the game.

[h1]Perfect lighting effects[/h1]
Finally, the lighting effects also contribute to the game's striking visuals. Be it the refraction of sunlight in the sea as Drake dives, the moon's glow in the night scenes or the limited illumination of a torch in caves and darker rooms. They all complement Naughty Dog's fantastic visual work.

[b][i]Drake[/i], [i]Sam[/i], [i]Nadine[/i] and [i]Sulivan[/i] enchant and make some of the most important dialogues have the atmosphere that the scene asks for. Whether with sarcastic jokes, orders or with a melancholy tone at certain plot points.[/b]

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]Uncharted 4 was worth the long wait and easily emerges as the best game ever released for PS and PC. The game brings the good old mechanics that consecrated the series, with timid evolutions that just add up. The graphics enchant for their quality and even the multiplayer mode, which has already been harshly criticized in other versions, becomes an excellent game option. [b]Uncharted 4[/b] is a must have!

I'm a founder and CEO of 2 organizations and I have a lot going on around me.
You'd think that everything that is going on sharpens the brains and makes you more and more experienced.
Well, here's the fact: working too much for your brain is like overusing the knife. It will get blunt and incompetent for work unless you sharpen it from time to time.
Playing a game like this = perfect rest and perfect refresh for the brains. 

Only cons I'd say as a lover of realism is that the game is quite unrealistic, but after my recent experience from Ukraine, I'm not so sure about that even.
There's a scene where you winch the car, you pull the winch but you slide off the cliff (not a spoiler since this was in trailer) and then a rock falls on the hood but the car is somehow still working. You'd imagine there's no way a car would be working after a hit like that. 
Here's a real life fact:

I was delivering an SUV to Georgian Legion operating in Ukraine all the way from Georgia. This was a supply mission running through 5 countries: Georgia, Turkey, Bulgaria, Romania, Ukraine.
The SUV its self was a piece of shit with no heating or isolation, It was January so my partner and I had our asses frozen all the time. We rushed the way, driving over 2500KM with no stop except for gas and border checkpoints. The vehicle had multiple issues including the leak from the transmission so we were in hurry to reach safe heavens so we could fix it and be done with the supply mission.
Our progress was halted in Romania where there was a huge snow storm. There were 3 routes leading up to the border point but all 3 were sealed off due to heavy snowfall. We idled for a few hours and then we finally made it to one of the routes. snowfall was still huge and the entire road had turned into a big ice skating route, but at least it was passable, the Romanians had pushed most of the snow towards the center of the road so there was a huge snow berm dividing us from the opposite traffic lane. Due to extreme freezing conditions, the snow berm had turned into an ice berm.
At one point, we saw the vehicle incoming from the opposite side. It was the only vehicle driving at that time (who else would be out in a crazy storm like that)... It was a huge bus which either slid or the driver had fallen asleep but it crashed into that berm with high speed, shooting a huge chunk of ice right at our car on our front left side!
It was a massive freakin hit. We had one heavy ass SUV but the hit pushed us towards the right edge of the road from the center. It was so noisy and so jolting that I was sure that was our end. I stopped and got out, expecting to see the entire front side and the entire left side gone with at least a major leak from the radiator. Turns out I had a wrong idea about realism - the car didn't have a scratch! The only thing that happened is that all the chunks of snow and ice got into our air intake so I had stand out and clean all of it with bare hands in the middle of a freezing snow storm. 

The SUV drove just fine after that though! So I guess a hood of the car being hit with a huge rock and then the vehicle still being perfectly operational isn't so unrealistic after all.

Just played Uncharted 4.
The best way to evaluate this game is to compare it to Tomb Raider.
The graphics are great. Tomb Raider 2013's shanty town blows it out of the water, but you can't fault Uncharted 4 for being a PS4 game, except that I can given that Tomb Raider was on xbox 360.
The gameplay is great. There are relaxing intriguing puzzles, and tense, difficult combat sections. There's pumice rock you can cut into and climb later, like Tomb Raider. I think Shadow of the Tomb Raider later steals the rope swinging mechanic though.

Where this game takes off is the story, the pacing of the game. Not only is there a beginning middle and end, but there's a backstory, beginning, real beginning (Madagascar), great city level, great boat level, great elongated ending, [spoiler]an epilogue[/spoiler]. This game is just super consistent. Pretty natural pacing. Even though everyone's racing towards the treasure, you still get time to look around and dick around. Shining your flashlight in people's faces makes them squint. Rolling into water makes your clothes wet (though that has been a thing since uncharted 1 I think). Characters will respond if you go off script [spoilers](Your... other left?)[/spoilers]. The driving mechanics, while not realistic, is pretty fun. You can get a good drift going by tapping the handbrake. The gunplay is good, making you run out of ammo pretty quickly and having to pick up other guns. You can fight while doing basically anything: swinging, climbing, sliding, falling.

After playing through Far Cry 5, I don't even know why I bothered with that game. This game sets the bar for what a AAA game should be. It isn't perfect, but it sure beats Tomb Raider. Tomb Raider has the graphics, controls, and movement down, but it's just so uninteresting and they always throw in magic at the end to make the entire story worthless.

Explosions and gunfire? A legendary treasure? Escaping a crumbling UNESCO world heritage site? A mass-murdering but amusingly sarcastic hero? YES! ITS TRUE! An Uncharted game finally came to PC!

tl;dr
Game play similar to Tomb Raider, but nowhere as dark or gruesome.
Enjoyable dialog like Guardians of the Galaxy or No One Lives Forever (if anyone remembers that oldie but goodie, which I wish someone would remake), but even better.
Skill of storywriting was reminiscent of Red Dead Redemption 2, but not nearly as epic (if you haven't played RDR2, do).

Amazing script and acting in both games. Well-acted, bantering dialog, similar to Guardians of the Galaxy, but with more depth. The story progression perfectly supported the game and the dialog tied into the gameplay so well that it significantly enhanced the experience. When my wife looked up the game and told me it was released before the movies, I was incredulous.  The movie's casting and acting were surprisingly faithful to A Thief's End.

Graphics were lovely.  I don't have a top of the line rig but even so the sets were beautiful, full of rich texture and detail.  I found myself stopping just to look around and appreciate the view more than once.  It was enough to make me take notice of Naughty Dog and to look for their association on other games in the future.  I can't speak to the environmental sound, unfortunately, since I typically play at night and keep the volume low so the rest of the family can read or sleep (I hate headphones).

I found A Thief's End to be a bit better in gameplay though Lost Legacy held its own. The latter was a bit easier I think, with handholds easier to find and usually more obvious paths.  The first large treasure hunting area of Lost Legacy at first was disappointing because there was enough content there (and repetition) that I thought it was the only game location. But after leaving that area, my hopes lifted and the growing friendship (and maybe more?) between the two leads made me want to keep playing for hours on end.

The gameplay itself was quite fun, but was admittedly the weakest component of the game. It had enough treasures scattered about to encourage one more playthrough, though probably not more than that.  PC controls were not awesome and I died many times from accidental key presses or getting caught behind cover or trying unsuccessfully to get out from cover.  The controls and the stickiness of cover mode together made stealth mode much harder than it needed to be; I rarely finished an area without having to fight my way out.  And fighting was also hampered by the same.  Puzzles were challenging but not so constant as to annoy.  One puzzle was frustrating enough that I finally went to game forums for the solution. But most could be figured out with enough persistence.

In all, solid game and I recommend it unreservedly.  I wish they'd make more like it, as long as they release it on Windows!

Upon release this was a fairly solid PC port which did not need much in the way of patching from what I recall, except for one KEY issue I experienced on multiple machines, and oh boy was it a MAJOR issue unfortunately... The mouse input when playing with KB+M was terrible. Even with 120 FPS it was as if the mouse only moved or updated at perhaps 10 or 15 hz / times per second making gameplay with KB+M absolutely brutal. It worked perfectly with any controller, and I would say in a lot of ways Uncharted plays best with a controller, but I really wanted to try it out KB+M, that + high FPS was the main reason I bought it here on PC after playing it already on PS4.

Well, as of July 2023, finally, this game has been updated and fixed the mouse input and I can FULLY recommend it to PC users. Especially right now on sale for $39 CAD, that is a great price for this game.

The graphics are beautiful, especially on PC. It is very well optimised and always has been. The gameplay is fantastic, consisting of climbing, puzzles, shooting, driving, and epic set pieces that take you for a real ride at times. Animation quality is beyond anything else that any other game offers. And the story is great too with characters that feel like real people.

This game is Naughty Dog at their finest, and I am so happy that it is finally fixed on PC regarding the mouse input.

A 100% buy for anyone who has never played it. Besides, if you do feel like you MUST play them in order, honestly, the first Uncharted game is not even that great, has not aged well at all. #2 and #3 are masterpieces like this one, but #1 can overall be skipped. A AAA title which focuses on storytelling, character development and drama over mindless, repetitive shooting? Almost too good to be true.
In some ways, it is.
The good parts are the climbing (which has a lot of depth) and the gunplay, where you can easily die if you're stupid but can feel like a badass if you're willing to put in the effort to learn how to use the environment to your advantage. Climbing, swinging and sliding your way around enemies to shove bullets in the back of their heads is therapeutic as heck.

Major downsides are that the game only has so many tricks to pull off and they quickly become stale. The "Oh look you gotta jump over the conveniently placed slide section to get to the crumbly wall! Oh no! You the wall crumbled and you gotta go down the slide" gag gets stale quickly. The other major downside is the game is incredibly linear outside of shooting sections. You can easily tell when you are about to enter a shooting gallery because the game throws choices at you regarding your movement. The rest of the game is a single, "correct" path that if you deviate even slightly you'll at best make no progress, at worst die for no reason. The best example is right early on in the game when you come back from the old Panama prison to the new one. You gotta go through a roof hatch on top of a single storey shack to end the segment. I dropped gently off the roof next to it and presumably died of a heart attack in the 2 feet I fell.

Almost every aspect of this game gives me a mixed feeling. I enjoyed it but there were many things that caused frustration for me. Maybe I'll change my mind later and give it a "Recommended".

Graphics.
Everything that's close to the player (characters, weapons, vehicles) looks fantastic, especially faces and facial animations in cutscenes, but I cannot say the same about most of the surroundings, some pieces look like they are straight from 2003. I am not a graphics expert but my guess is that there's something wrong with the lighting. I do realise that the game was originally designed for PS4 but then why does the frame rate drop to 70 in some areas? The devs could have done a better job when porting the game to PC.

Music. Story. Acting.
Not much to say here, all three are amazing. I really enjoyed watching Nate's and Sam's story.

Controls.
It's a typical console game, so if you play on KBM, you'll realise how clumsy the character movement is.

Gameplay (non-combat).
A lot of monotonous climbing (by the way, when you drive a car, you also do the climbing, just in the car), too few interesting puzzles, especially puzzles with large mechanisms, like in Tomb Raider. I remember just one, with a huge bell in the church.

Gameplay (combat, Crushing mode).
This is one of the most annoying shooters I have ever played. You are always low on ammo (in most cases you can get ammo/weapons only by looting enemies, but enemies carry all kinds of rifles and pistols, so there's never enough ammo to fill up your pouch) whereas your enemies not only have unlimited ammo but also they don't even try to pretend it's not like that, they just give you a bullet hell (infinite heavy suppressing fire, instant reloads and high accuracy) they push aggressively, throw grenades which almost don't miss and stick to the surface right where you are hiding, even if it's a cliff. and the further you progress, the worse it gets; so in the final chapters, prepare to suffer and cry "Oh, God, why" a lot. The problem is that you don't really have anything to fight back because aiming feels like Nate is 90 years old, so headshots, which are the key to survival, are unpredictable; besides, enemies dodge bullets like the Agents from the Matrix, literally :) Also, the console like mechanics make thing even worse, because when you roll over, you often stick to the wrong side of a cover exposing yourself to the enemy and can get killed quickly. That said, surviving a gunfight is all about luck (and a bit of skills).

Female characters.
I am not familiar with the Uncharted series but here's my first impression. Elena - has the voice of a cowboy from Texas, also the way she talks. When Nate and Elena were sitting on a couch, it looked like Elena was a Chad and Nate was a shy girl. Absolutely not feminine and unattractive character. I would say, get a divorce, Nate. Nadine - beats up Nate, then later beats up Nate and Sam, two strong men - well, that's how it works in real life, right? And you know what's even more fun? Both times you confront her, those are not cutscenes, you actually play Nate but he somehow just forgets how to fight, so the game makes you feel helpless and watch how a strong woman kicks your butt. Chloe - has a voice of a 60-year old smoker and kills men with her bear hands and even fights against three. As far as I remember, in Tomb Raider (the new trilogy), you could feel how difficult this was for Lara, so only stealth and only with some kind of weapon. This is dog's poo.
Personally found the shooting parts of the game and the driving parts to be annoying but 10/10 honestly wish I could forget and replay all over again

Uncharted is my favorite game series of all time, so my review will be bias. Therefore, I'm just going to focus on the Legacy of Thieves collection itself instead of concentrating on each individual game. This collection is great. It is optimized for PC really well, and runs great. Uncharted 4 is much better than Uncharted: The Lost Legacy. However, both are excellent. If you are a fan of action/adventure games (and sliding down gravel hills) this is a must have.

This is my first play-through of this game (only played Uncharted 4 so far) without playing the Uncharted games before. All I have to say is "Wow", what an experience this game is. I don't know what it looked like with the old graphics, but I was amazed how beautiful this game is. I was fully immersed in the jungle, city, temples and all the history of pirates. I bought this because of summer sale 2023 and I do not regret it. Here's my opinion about the game for the first time.

Pros 
- Amazing story and cinematic
- Amazing graphics
- Game is not too hard, but not too easy (including puzzles)
- Finished the game in around 12 hours playing it at average speed inspecting everything that I could find
- Voice acting is great
- Playing multiple character is great
- Car mechanic is great
- Whenever you find a sneaky place or unusual route, there will always be a gift (treasure)

Cons
- 1 game crash & 2 blue screens during my time playing.
- The sliding on gravel is not the best mechanic & a little bit glitchy
- Puzzle & jumping around buildings is a little bit redundant at the end of the game
- Sometimes it's confusing what rocks you can and cannot climb on
- When you pause for long time or open the game again, I couldn't find a reminder of the quest I was suppose to do (if you don't remember) or you missed the dialogue

I had a lot of fun playing Uncharted 4 and I can't wait to try the new one!

It almost doesn't made me feel that I haven't played the previous games. So yeah you can play both Uncharted 4 and Uncharted The Lost Legacy without playing the previous games, which is nice! I would say that this collection is well worth getting even at full price, and on sale, a must-have. I have played these games multiple times on Playstation, but still wanted to get it for PC to play again. This collection offers you two games that may be in the same genre gameplay-wise, but are quite different in story and tone. 

Uncharted 4 is a sendoff to Nate. His last ride. The story is thoughtful, emotional and leaves you with a warm feeling in your heart. The graphics and visuals and fantastic too, and the game mechanics are genre-defining (So much so that the entire 2013 Tomb Raider reboot basically just copied Uncharted, haha!).

Lost Legacy is a standalone game featuring Chloe instead of Nate, but it is an underrated gem. Lost Legacy is fun, visually gorgeous an explores ancient history in a setting that is rich with it, but somehow never used - India. It has all the good stuff from Uncharted 4, but even nicer visuals and vistas. While Uncharted 4 may need you to have a little context from the past 3 games before it to really immerse yourself in the story, Lost Legacy has no such requirement and can be hopped into straight away. The only con to Lost Legacy really is that it is a bit short. Regardless, Chloe keeps the game entertaining for the entirety of it and I do hope that Chloe features in full-length games as a protagonist in the future, she's such a good character.

Only played Uncharted The Lost Legacy. Couldn't get into Uncharted 4.

Uncharted 4 starts with a vomit inducing scene on a ship, the "lightning" doesn't work and only makes the screen white. After that you are transported back in to the past and play as Nathan Jr. - which is soooooo boring. I don't care, I want Action.

Uncharted The Lost Legacy is a good game. It's just _way_ too short. 7 hours for 30 bucks? That's a joke. Chole Frazer is an amazing Protagonist though - if only that Nadine girl wasn't so whiny all the time. All the time bitching, crying, complaining. It gets so tedious. The best part of the game was when I was on my own. That Sam Character was supposed to be comedic relief I guess, but he was just annoying af.

Overall the game has a nice mix of shooting and exploring. Although it's very linear. In the beginning when you explore the valley you may think that this is an open world game - but that part is just way too short. Also the climbing is sometimes not very intuitive.

You get the feeling that the developers ran out of content. There was one particular scene near the end which made it abundandly clear, that they had to fill the game somehow. So they give you some tracks, a stonewall and a cart. At first you need to drag around the cart, which takes about 1 minute. Then you climb over the stone wall, only to find a room, where you can not progress. Instead your "buddy" climbs up the ladder, which then breaks. So you need to go back over the wall, bring the cart back to it's original position, so your buddy can throw down a crate on which you can climb up. That scene was so annoying and unnecessary.

The final fight was also kinda boring. Didn't feel like a real "boss" fight, it was just button smashing galore. Overall I'd rate my experience with Uncharted 4 1/10 and Uncharted TLL 6.5/10. Not sure why this game gets so much praise, it's not a masterpiece. It's a good game, just way too short. Claudia Black really is carrying this game, her performance as Chloe Frazer is top notch.

Uncharted 4
I have played all the Uncharted games, and U4 as well, many times on the PS before. All great games, but Uncharted 4 is simply the best. Yet only if you played the previous ones and you are connected with the characters and engaged in their struggle. I strongly recommend to at least watch the story for the previous ones, to understand the character's background and chemistry. The game looks stunning and is full of action with an occasional puzzle to solve - 'tis the closest thing you get to being Indiana Jones in a videogame. But it also tells a brilliant, emotional story, with characters that talk and act like real people and you get to care for them very fast. And while the story is not very original, it is presented in a very down to earth and human way - which is rarity in videogames.

Lost Legacy
on the other hand, is soulless, dull fanservice. The action is here, yes, but the levels look all the same, all the puzzles are actually only two puzzles repeated over and over and the dialogue takes a huge fall in witt and logic. Towards the end the plot even diceides that the main heroes need to save the world with their bare hands - Avenger style... and they go and do so, with little to none motivation. Characters already established in the franchize act out of character and are presented only as 21st century holywood stereotypes. There is even a line, very unnecessary line, of dialogue at one point, about one of the heroines breaking a man's legs for looking down on her... Don't get me wrong. I like Chloe from U2 and 3, where she already is a strong woman type of character. Here it is just unnecessarilly overdone all the time. And I came to like Sam in U4. But here they literarely made him an idiot.  It is simply embarasing...

I'm finally able to complete Lost Legacy now that I don't have a PS4 and missed it at the time. The story and gameplay are not as good as The Last of Us, but the environments are gorgeous and it's a pleasure to play this shooter with mouse and keyboard. 

That said, there are minor issues with the mouse at higher polling rates. They're mostly fixed now that they added raw input, it's better but still not super smooth.
