This is one of the best game developed by Naughty dogs... It was my dream to play and complete this game from such a long time... But check your internet connection and all the drivers if they are updated on time or else it will lag horribly (specially in gaming laptops)..

When it's action packed, it's very fun. Those big set pieces really are great. The problem is  when it's not action packed it's a bit boring, and that's 75% of the game. The start of the main game has you play through two prison sequences that are almost identical, and then a flashback that is nothing but climbing and then a tutorial swimming section that adds nothing to the story before the adventure really gets going. Towards the end right as story starts to pick up, they throw you into another flashback that is nothing but climbing.

The tone of this game is all over the place as well. These games always had an issue with the main characters going from mass murdering thieves in one scene to charming protagonists the next. The first three worked because they were all fantasy stories that had supernatural monsters. They were essentially Indiana Jones games. These two games don't have a supernatural element and they attempt to feel too realistic, but it just doesn't work.

It's a decent enough adventure and I would normally recommend picking it up on sale, but on top of everything that I mentioned, the game seems to have a memory leak as it crashed every half hour on a machine with a 5900x and a 6950xt running fairly cool, I played this game for 30 hours so it crashed 60 times.

I have not played any Uncharted games before . So i came late to the party. But let me tell you : This game is a 9/10. One of the best games, that i have played this year. Spectaular sequences with a lot of action. One scene you slide, throw a rope, jump forward, while killing enemies. There are also very cool chase scenes. These sequences also have a lot of emotions. Even if you, like me, never played any uncharted game before you feel attached to the story. The combat feels very fluid and the jumping is fun and engaging overall. The puzzles are not too bad either. They are overall all managebale if you dont mind trying..There  can be some stuttering issues. Overall Uncharted 4 : A Thiefs End is a great adventure with stunning action.

I am not somebody who enjoys bashing AAA games. If I happen to dislike one, I'll usually admit that it's me, not the game.

Not here, though. Seriously, this series is supposed to be a system seller for the Playstation? Why??

I have only played "A Thief's End" so far, and only for a couple of hours. But I'm so bored already that I can't bring myself to playing any further. Here are a few reasons why:

The characters. I can't get myself to like them. Not even Nathan Drake.

The gameplay. I mean, is there even gameplay? Most of the time, I'm running around, either looking for an icon to pop up, so that I can press the button I am supposed to press (usually the game will tell me which one). That's not gameplay.

There are the climbing passages, and yes, they are mildly entertaining. Yet still, at the end of the day, they are about me finding out which way the game wants me to go without telling me.

And then there are the fights. The gunplay is terrible. The camera leaves a lot to be desired. And the opponents are usually dozens over dozens of more or less identical characters attacking you. That the game loves to spawn them right behind you just adds to the annoyance.

In between are cutscenes. Lots and lots of cutscenes. Looong cutscenes. That you cannot skip. They are probably supposed to draw you into the story. But as that one is as shallow as the characters, this doesn't really work. Some of them were so boring that I dozed off in front of the PC. I can't think of a single game that ever did that to me.

On the plus side, the graphics are amazing. This game really looks stunning at times. But that can't make me ignore the fact that I find the game boring.

It's not that I dislike console ports in general. I did enjoy God of War. I absolutely loved GTA V and RDR 2. And I really had high expectations for Uncharted. But the latter turned into one of the biggest disappointments of my long gaming career.

And this time, I don't think it's me.

If you are a fan of games like Tomb Raider, then you are apt to really enjoy the two titles included in Uncharted: Legacy of Thieves Collection. They are crafted with incredible detail and the scenery is breathtaking... mountains, valleys, ancient ruins, etc. The story spans across both games with some characters appearing in both. I found the story engaging, the characters likable, and the voice-acting excellent. 

Although the stories are different, the two games are very similar in terms of game play. Both have a great deal of peaceful exploration with an occasional burst of skirmish. Most combat in initiated by you needing to enter a guarded area. Thus, you have options in terms of stealth, weapons, and strategy. There are some pretty intense combat sequences towards the end of both games but these were survivable for me.

I played on 'Explorer' mode which makes the game much easier for those not adept at action gaming. There are sections that involve a lot of climbing and swinging from ropes and these were quite forgiving. I struggled with using a controller to drive a 4x4 Jeep which is your mode of travel for several chapters. Especially when under fire, I tended to drive pretty badly. But, the game has very regular save points and you just try again when you fail.

Collectibles are scattered throughout the games (journals, treasures, photo ops, notes, optional conversations.). Many of these are not visible from the main path and you may need a guide to find them. However, none are required for game completion.  There are a number of interesting mechanical puzzles which involve activating old machinery. All required puzzles were reasonable and enjoyable to solve. There was one timed optional puzzle that made me crazy but, in the end, I prevailed.

I found Uncharted to be easier than Tomb Raider. The leaping and swinging in Explorer mode was simplified and I fell to my death much less often. Weapons and ammunition are abundant and I never ended up stuck without a way to defend myself. 

There are a wide range of achievements which include speed runs, driving precision, and completing the games at verous levels of difficulty. From the begining, 100% was not in the cards for me but I did try to finish with a reasonable percentage. The game allows you to circle back to chapters and encounters to pick up missing items and achievements. You also have access to all weapons and unlimited ammunition as 'bonus' items once you complete the game.

Overall, I really enjoyed Uncharted and highly recommend it to those who crave an action/adventure with a focus on exploration. Although there are some tricky scenes, there is no horrific boss fight at the end of either game and I was able to complete them with minimal frustration. My only regret is that Uncharted 1,2, and 3 are not available for the PC!

I've just completed Thief's End and had an enjoyable experience. 

The game-play is mostly smooth, but not without some minor gripes. The action and combat is very good, you have a decent level of options when taking on the enemy such as the usual stealthy bush hiding, or all guns blazing Arnie style.

My complaints are minor but here goes:

1. The roll and 'take cover' buttons are one and the same. This becomes annoying as you try and roll the f*** out of a sticky spot when getting flanked by enemies, only to have Drake take cover behind a box but on the wrong side.

2. Imagine performing a series of jumps, climbs, swings etc. As you are shimmying along a ledge the camera angle changes by just enough to cause the direction that you've been holding to be interpreted as the opposite direction. I see how this would work if you start from a stand-still then move the camera and push left or right, but when you're already in motion and the camera  changes why would the game do this? 

All in all a fun game but not one that I will ever revisit.

While I enjoyed Uncharted 1&2, I have been more critical of later games by Naughty Dog, including Uncharted 3 and The Last of Us. On PS3 I was not happy with the amount of combat in those games, which was also quite frustrating to execute. So I did pick up "Legacy of Thieves collection" at a discount, intending to play on easy difficulty, to see if ND could win me back. I must say after now having finished "A Thief's End", I was pleasantly surprised! On easy difficulty, combat is serviceable and does not block progress noticeably, even though it is still my least favourite part of the game. Climbing is a bit much at times, but besides that, it's all quite nice. I did not bother too much with side content/hidden treasures, but kept a steady pace through all beautiful environments. Always nice with games that allows the colours to stand out. It is a nice story wrap-up for Drake and Elena, well-acted across the board. The puzzles that are by no means hard but impressing by AAA-standards. Overall more like the first Uncharted games.

So, "A Thief's End" is definitely a step-up for Naughty Dog in my book and my favourite game out of the Sony PC ports. Initially it may have felt like a 3/5, but it grew on me up until the end, so I will bump it up to a 4/5.

A near flawless port of the formerly PS4 exclusive Uncharted games, with the number of bugs I encountered across both games being in the single digits. Noteworthy given the hit or mostly miss world of console to PC ports. 

As for the games, what's to say? It's more Uncharted. Granted with a boatload of subtle, but effective, QoL additions, two extra contextual mechanics to spice up the series' trademark climbing sections, and heavily expanded stealth mechanics that elevate stealth into a proper alternative to combat.

The two games really are both sides of the same coin. While I appreciated 4's more grounded story and setting, I found myself yearning for the mystic and swashbuckle of the PS3 games. Cue Lost Legacy and its slew of ancient massive ruins jam-packed with inexplicably functional puzzles and death traps. Puzzles, incidentally, I consider to be the best in the entire series, both visually and mechanically. Unfortunately while generally good, LL's writing is much shallower thanks mostly to its short runtime and much smaller scope. 

In short, if you liked the PS3 trilogy, this collection is a no-brainer. If not then these games likely won't change your mind.

Uncharted 4: A Thief’s End and Uncharted: The Lost Legacy are fantastic games. The care, detail and creativity that went into crafting the world, the narrative and the puzzles for both games is simply unrivaled, elevated by the fact that both games - contrary to its predecessors - don't feature any supernatural enemies. The gameplay, which is the same for both games, feels very responsive and intuitive and is easily mastered. I do not recall encountering any bugs, game-breaking or otherwise, during the 123 hours I spent playing the games, so you can rest assured that you buy a functional product when adding the Legacy of Thieves Collection to your library. All in all both games are, apart from a few minor complaints (see below), a brilliant addition to your collection if you like playing narrative-driven games.

The game is not perfect however, and there were a few minor things that somewhat annoyed me during my playtime. To start off, the crosshair that you have when using a gun that does not have a scope is way too big, which makes aiming accurately harder than it has to be. I suspect the game makes up for this by making any shot you take while a part of the enemy’s body is in the crosshair an automatic hit, but it feels a little weird and I sometimes got kills that theoretically should have been impossible, which slightly ruins the immersion of the game. Another point of annoyance was that a few achievements are oddly specific and therefore very hard to do, and since I am someone who likes to get all achievements in the game this annoyed me to no end, especially when I had to keep reloading checkpoints for half an hour just to get enemies in the right place for the achievement to be doable. 

The only major issue I had with the games is that the end credits, for both of them, are unskippable if you want the achievements for beating the game to pop. This is simply unacceptable, especially when you consider that the credits for both games take over 10 minutes to finish. The only somewhat redeeming feature about it is that the end credits of The Lost Legacy start with a banger of a song (M.I.A. - Borders), but other than that having unskippable end credits is a terrible executive decision and I hope that it does not return for future installments in the franchise.

Before I commence this review so you have a baseline to asses how it will play on your system.
my Rig is a CPU Ryzen 5800 X3D. GPU AMD Radeon RX6700XT  Ram 32 GB 3600 MTS.
In game Game Graphics @1440p set to Ultra everything. Average FPS was between 130-90 depending upon the scene.

So for me the game looked stunning (used HDR) and played smoothly. I used a controller as that was how game was designed to work so avoided the mouse polling issue reported for this port (stuttery  & 10 FPS when moving camera etc ).

With that out of the way. I have played the previous games ( just a few times  :-)   ). 
So this is the final chapter for Nathan Drake as an Adventurer Rogue thief . You find out more of his back story discover he has a Brother. So you get to know him more as a character overall.
Story is the usual wild yarn of "Lost" Hidden unknown treasure" leading to a touch of globe trotting, crossing paths with this time not 1 but 2 protagonists after the same thing . The stage is set.

The characterisation is excellent the dialogue is believably human. The deliberate bad jokes are still here and wise cracks some making me laugh out loud ( done in a in joke knowing way by Naughty dog regarding the Uncharted series).

Visually I found it stunning and many time stopped to take screen shots and photos . The details of some items are insane considering they are just irrelevant other than set dressing for places.

The pacing of the game I thought was a decent balance between story / action / and plot moving forward.
Though if you do not like platforming you may find traversing areas a pain as there is a lot to do BUT that is what Uncharted is about, traversing suicidal terrain like some human fly. There are new mechanics adding a couple of different mechanisms getting from point A to Point B  (sliding , and grappling rope) which open up extra game play options especially in combat situations.

For me what elevated this above many similar games was the  Random NPC dialogues you could eve drop on, here I am talking about the shoreline mercs. some discussing previous jobs, some talking about is this job worth  sticking with, even saw one taking photos of another Merc who was doing different poses with his Rifle, I was playing stealth sections so all this was going on with me unseen . This added to the immersion into this world. Is it essential No but it counts and is applied to most aspects of this game. I am not adding specifics to avoid spoilers.

PLOT ARMOUR...we have a KAI Leng in UC4 a protagonist we chat touch this is the sucky part that left me with a distaste as much as Kai Leng does in Mass Effect 3. a shame they did this in this game.
Another gripe is an Action QTE event that happens in Kings Bay  because of the Camera angle and unknown layout of the streets you can only figure out what you need to do after dying multiple times, this ruined the flow I had up to that point.

The Puzzles are fun and of the usual Uncharted type.

Overall it is as good IMHO as my fave Uncharted 2 game. Its cinematic, engaging FUN and a worthy closure of the series. Highly recommend if you enjoy Light RPG Action adventure games where gunplay is kind of minor to the overal game itself but can be fun. I personally enjoyed the difficult conundrum of how to stealth kill multiple enemies that all had over lapping view of each other that required considerable patience and studying their  patrolling patterns ( not the same as they kept varying their route with unseen enemies) You could of course go all guns blazing against 10 Plus enemies see how that turns out for you ( I managed a couple of times ) passing unseen taking down every one without being detected.

I just wish more games where made with such love and care. even if the port wasn't perfect on release. As long as you set in game settings to match your system build it should run well enough.

The cutscenes are better than the gameplay

How the historical stuff is shown is almost magical, the places are beyond beautiful and the music is on point. Also most dialogues are great in the first game (of the two in this collection), specially Sullivan's, followed close by Elena's. Both clever people with cool minds, never overreacting and putting priorities first while pushing the right buttons both on Drake and Sam. The 2nd game though, get some awkward (not to say cringe) dialogues, like not really funny jokes, boring preoccupations; idk, they might've over explained somethings along the game... Somehow the 1st beat the 2nd when it comes to dialogues withstanding the test of time;

Drake is drake and no need to talk about him here, you know him; now Chloe is a very cool character and I had a lot of fun playing her. I think there should be more games exploring her past but maybe that would just be a copy of Tomb Raider unfortunately. I had a great time while she was talking her way out of difficult situations. She's clever and fun.

Then it comes, the two main issues:

It is pretty bad how you get to see Sam Drake going from problematic and liar (almost stealing Nathan's spot sometimes) to a complete stupid and dumb comic relief on the next game right after. Maybe someone in NaughtyDog thought they had to push the only man in the group into being a total brain-dead in order for the two girls to appear properly.
And........ There's Nadine. By far the worst character in Uncharted. One that gets to be unbearable and break immersion every single time she appears: First game, she's the boss of a mercenary group and is completely thrown off when other mercenaries betray her for money (being the boss, she should know better), then there's her super strength to a point where you have two guys holding her down but they might have noodles for arms bc in one move she breaks free sending both of them almost flying. On the 2nd game she loses the super power and can't fight any significant fights if you're not helping. Also, she's mean, even with her friends, everything you say can and will be used against you in a conversation. Unfortunately she gets to be with you until the very last cutscene.

Gameplay:

The basic stuff is harder than it looks. Most of the time you have a companion and they do make the game a LOT more difficult by stealing your spot, crossing in front of you and blocking your path while you're shooting, or try to run from a bomb, also they walk in front of the enemies while you're being stealthy and all that, not to mention that taking cover and running near walls is a complete nightmare, the mc will just not obey commands. The characters wont move if the're near a wall, as if they needed 3 times their actual size to pass through a door or something. It is bad enough to make you nervous a lot, but the game itself is still worth it.

The whole Indiana Jones stuff is there, it's fun, maybe they kill some characters that would be cool on their own by shoving some agendas on your face, the moving part is very awkward and could/should be reworked if they plan on some remastered version or something similar, but in the end it's definitely a couple of games I'll finish at least once more each, for sure.

UNCHARTED: Legacy of Thieves Collection[/b] contains Uncharted 4: A Thief's End and its standalone expansion Uncharted: The Lost Legacy.

Unfortunately there are no Uncharted 1-2-3 on PC, not even this collection has them. So I played through the earlier games using the RPCS3 Emulator to catch up with the storyline and characters.

Playing through the earlier titles was a whole lot of fun. Getting to know the characters and their background stories, even on a deeper level, while also embarking on their adventures to here and there for lost treasures and cities was just overall a really great experience.

The best thing about this series is that it has humour, action and even drama packed into them. The way the characters talk with each other and react to various things is just pure fun to listen to.

Pros:
- The games are jaw droppingly beautiful
- The amount of tiny little details are mind blowingly insane
- Both game ran like a dream performance wise, top tier optimization
- Animations are as smooth as butter
- The characters are sooo well-written
- The storyline of both entries were intriguing, I just loved everything about them.
- The gameplay itself is really responsive and is just overall satisfying, both the gunplay and the exploration.
- You can either go stealth or guns blazing.
- Some sections of the games are semi-open world, great stuff
- Really great OST
- Photomode, which is an instant W in my book.
- Steam achievements

Neutral:
- I would have loved to play the Uncharted 4 multiplayer, but unfortunately, this collection does not have multiplayer in it.

I don't think this game is bad, just somewhat mediocre, but unfortunately Steam doesn't have a neutral option.Let's start with technical. I played this game on a Ryzen 3700X with a Radeon 5700, connected to an 38" ultra-wide display. Rendered resolution was set to 1920x800, upscaled to the native 3840x1600. This can be configured directly in the game's options, no messing about with AMD's Adrenaline software required. After initial crashing issues that where resolved by setting the texture quality to 'high' (I probably ran out of VRAM on 'ultra'), the game ran fine with no performance issues. Note that the game does not have a field of view setting, though it does expand the FOV if you play it on an ultra-wide monitor.Where the game fails for me is the gameplay, which alternates between climbing puzzles and combat. The climbing puzzles aren't terrible, but not as interesting as those in last three Tomb Raider games. The combat is pretty terrible though. The guns are all rather inaccurate, and the enemies are somewhat bullet spongy unless you land a headshot. The game also loves throwing multiple waves of enemies at you that appear out of nowhere. Again, the last three Tomb Raider games do this much better.TL;DR - if you haven't played the last three Tomb Raider games yet, get those instead.

It makes you lose the feeling of handling a couple tons boat completely.Then comes the shooting - scoping's OK, but there's almost no impact when you hit the enemies.During the rest of the prologue I've really missed the flow feel I am expecting from a game like this. For example, I was being taught to do a roll between two covers. I was expecting Nathan to lean against the second cover automatically but the animation left me standing few steps from the destination.Climbing feels janky since you are being stuck all the time. The character refuses to move to the next ledge unless you are on the very edge of the current one. However, you stick should be turned at precise direction to move on which causes unnecessary pauses and kills the feel of the flow. In addition, I've had a couple of situations when the character was leaning to some random walls during the pursuit scene. The plot is good, but some tragic events which happened to our character during the prologue have little impact on myself since I am not familiar with the original trilogy.To sum up, the game doesn't feel like masterpiece I was lead to believe from all the positive reviews. You would like it if you are into popcorn movies I presume (no offence) since main components are there. However, if you are seeking some interesting gameplay mechanics - they are either not here or hidden somewhere outside of the prologue.

I'm a bit on the fence about this game but I'll give it a thumbs up. Uncharted 4 has far too much narrative content that takes away from the game. It's practically at the point where it's like Quantum Break for the first half of the game. The puzzles are also too simplistic. In general, the gameplay is very smoothbrained and autopilot. The game also plays terribly with M+KB because of weird input delays due to trying to create realistic movement, and it's even worse than RDR2 with this. The Tomb Raider games have extremely similar gameplay and control perfect with M+KB. That said, having PS5 controller support does work great with haptics and adaptive triggers. I would have rather played with M+KB still, but the game is just not playable like that. The combat is pretty fun and allows for experimentation, but experimentation is really not very rewarding and combat encounters tend to play out very similarly since most the guns don't do anything game changing, and they're over almost as soon as they begin for the most part.

The Lost Legacy is, however, far better in its balance of gameplay to narrative and has actually rewarding puzzles, with combat encounters happening often enough that you do get more of a playful feeling from them.

The narratives themselves are pretty cringe. The writing is okay but the overall narratives just don't hold together well.

I certainly do recommend the game itself: Uncharted 4 is one of the best games ever made - but only on Playstation. The PC version, unfortunately, is unstable and crashes constantly and should be avoided. 

I'm trying to run it on an i5 12400F with 32GB RAM and an RTX 3060 where it always crashes. In my personal experience the game is more stable on a notebook with an AMD Ryzen 5 4600H APU with 16GB RAM - but the graphics performance of that AMD APU just isn't good enough for this game; it's playable in low settings, but if you want to really enjoy Uncharted, you need to run it in ultra settings and at least in Full HD resolution. Sorry - but in this game, the graphics are extremely important; they create the dense atmosphere that is vital to the story that is being told. It just doesn't work without the graphical details.

But on PC that is all an academic discussion anyway: The game is broken on a technical level. When you're lucky, it only crashes back to the Windows desktop. But very often, it either freezes the whole system or produces actual blue screens (making it the only software that I've seen in the last decade that still has such an effect on Windows).

Don't play it on PC, it will ruin the game for you. Get a Playstation instead and play it there. The Uncharted series is so good, it justifies buying a console just to play Nathan Drake's story.

This review contains spoilers regarding the plot. I conditionally recommend this game. 

By default, the game looks like horsesh*t garbage because it uses post-processing filter that looks like Vaseline speared over your eye balls. In order to mitigate this, you need to download "Photo Realistic Re-Shade" from the Nexus, install it, start the game, press Home, and check "adaptive sharpening." Otherwise, the game has some performance issues where, for me, the frame rate varied between 165+ and 65 fps (on an RTX 4080 at 1440p, if you're wondering). That's a pretty unreasonable variation in frame rate that can be pretty jarring. I don't know if this reflects an undisciplined attention to resource use at the development level, or if it's a problem with the port. The original theme song, which I consider to be among the best in the industry, is absent from the main menu and elsewhere in the game until the credits, which is disappointing, even if I understand the artistic reason for its omission.  Finally, the plot lacks any supernatural element other than Nathan Drakes unreasonable upper body strength. This was disappointing, as the supernatural elements of the other games were among my favorite parts of the stories. 

Other than these gripes, the game is great. The visuals are often beautiful, even if the set pieces are all things we've seen before. The climbing animations have been further refined. The dialogue serves its purpose adequately and the characters are well realized. The prologue and epilogue are entirely wholesome.  The in-game flavor-music is similar to, and just as excellent, as prior installments. This installment is basically more of the same, which I consider to be a good thing.

If you liked Uncharteed before, then you'll like this fourth installment. If you didn't like Uncharted before, then this installment won't change your mind.

IS THE PORT GOOD?

When transitioning to a new area, or when there are new assets rendering for the very first time, there is often a very noticeable stutter for a few seconds. Then it goes away. This happens in cutscenes only; gameplay is uninterrupted. This is an Uncharted game, after all, so all gameplay is bookended by cutscenes.

Alright so, I did complete the game (including the expansion) entirely quite a while ago. 
So might as well give a proper review for the game and share my overall experience with it.

As a quick mention, Uncharted 4 isn't a new game at all. it was released for the first time in 2016 as a PS4 exclusive and of course. Sony did see it as a good opportunity to release the game for the PC in late 2022 with improved graphics and frame rate to give PC gamers a taste of the Sony universe and try to get them into the PlayStation ecosystems. its the same case with God of War 2018.

I always did plan to play the game and even went as far as considering to get a PS4 just to play the game as looking at the game back in the day was a unique experience for sure. But thankfully this isn't the case anymore and instead we can play the game as it was intended to be.

Graphics/Visuals is already one of those things that will stand out in this game.
Despite coming back in 2016. its definitely one of the best looking games I have played in recent memory and I would certainly say that it has aged like fine wine. if I gotta be honest, even on the baseline PS4. the game looked good but playing it on a high end PC just adds up to the whole experience
Lighting, dynamic environments and usage of effects is done amazingly while also being unique.

Story? I don't think there was a moment that I wanted to skip the cutscenes.
Dialogs are done really well, The environment speaks for itself and the story building has clearly a good direction and it does manage to get the right moments correctly with the balancing of the in game characters.

Controls? Uncharted by its core. is a third person action game just as most other Sony titles through history. While I respect such idea, it also brings an annoying set of controls for both controller and keyboard+mice players and that alone can be irritating.
On top of it, the game dynamically changes the camera based on the what is going on in the game at the time. its done for the purpose of increasing the immersion to the levels you see in movies. but I don't believe it serves a purpose in video games

Gameplay? the game is a throw back to simpler days. no complex skill set system or upgrades but rather everything is simple as it should be. You also pick weapons that were dropped by enemies and Uncharted also being unique by not telling you directly what you should do but it does let you figure it out alone until you get stuck for lomh and then it tells you word by word.

So my overall final verdict is 8/10. 
Uncharted 4 and its DLC was genuinely a refreshing experience compared to the games that came out as of recently and I'm glad that I got to experience the game
and just like with God of War 2018. I'm looking forward for Sony to release more former exclusives to the PC.

One of the best games I've played in years. We all love our little indie games, but this one really gives you that blockbuster AAA magic that only big budget titles like this can bring. The graphics are jaw dropping still in 2023 and the scenes you play in, the places you visit, and the vistas you feast your eyes on are just something to behold. The characters are brilliantly written, charming and memorable. You know nowadays it seems like every character in every video game is a sarcastic smart-arse. This one isn't like this. Nathan, Elena, Sam, Sully, they are all great characters that you care about and relate with. Btw I'm playing the Harry Prick game at the moment, and the characters there, the little brats, are absolutely garbage in comparison.

If there is some weakness to this game, I'd say the gameplay can be repetitive at times. Climbing a cliff can be fun, but at some point you just keep smashing the A button with your eyes shut and hope for the next cutscene or shootout. The shooting, however, is fun. I must report that I probably had more fun shooting at people in Uncharted 4 than I did with the last few CODs.

One more petty gripe: this game suffers from the same ridiculousness that you see in the Tomb Raider series, Like, in these abandoned caves in the middle of the Indian ocean where nobody has visited for centuries, there just so happens to be some carefully placed crates out of nowhere just for you to use to climb onto a cliff or something. Like wtf...  You just can't take the game too seriously. It's action-comedy. The story is decent but nothing to write home about. Typical Hollywood sort of story, a mixture of bull$hit and humour. Cliche as it may be, I feel it works well for this kind of game.

But overall, this one is absolutely worth the price and the time. I only played one of the two titles and I think I've more than got my money back.

A fine sendoff to the series, and I'm delighted that Naughty Dog's catalogue is finally coming to PC. It's truly one of the few studios left making triple-A action games worthy of the title.

This collection is mostly just more of what made UC 1-3 great--loose, acrobatic combat; an Indiana Jones-style awe of the aesthetics of ancient history; a cast of lovable scoundrels; and bombastic action setpieces. Nate's zingers are still 50/50 chuckle/groan, and fan-favorite Sully shows up exactly when he needs to. Nate's brother Sam fits in well and has good chemistry with the rest of the cast. Asav and especially Rafe are insufferable jerks, maintaining the Uncharted postulate that the character least able to take a joke is the most likely villain.

Incremental improvements include some mild stealth mechanics, which encourage (but don't require!) the player to approach most encounters a little more tactically than in previous games. This was fun! Also, it might just be my imagination, but Naughty Dog seems to have taken taken criticisms of the series' ludo-narrative dissonance to heart. It feels like there's a lot less combat--I think I went home with the blood of only several hundred men on my hands, rather than the thousand-ish from previous games. And they were all some manner of commonwealth-accented paramilitary thug type. We're still a long way from the Uncharted game that is just a pacifist walking sim, but at least Naughty Dog is keeping up with society's idea of who is expendable. And, the colonialist theft of ancient history from indigenous people, while still present--and, frankly, hard to avoid when you're channeling Indiana Jones this hard--also takes a back seat to more personal objectives through most of these two games. 

The Lost Legacy deserves special mention for ejecting Nate and still being a good time. The Chloe-&-Nadine-Do-Hoysala is a fun, refreshing odd-couple (and low-key feminist!) story, and shows how all of Uncharted's cast are strong enough to carry their own games.

There are some weird narrative choices in both games that feel kind of synthetic. Nate's initial lie to Elena, and Sam's initial lie to Nate, seem very out-of-character and largely shoehorned into the plot to manufacture drama later. In TLL, Chloe keeps vaguebooking about unresolved daddy issues in a subplot that never pays off. But, look at me, complaining about character drama in a videogame! In almost any other game, nitpicks like this would be silly; they only feel relevant in Uncharted because the general characterization is otherwise so dang luscious. Naughty Dog's commitment to blocking & mo-capping all of its character moments really pays off--even though Uncharted's drama is rarely serious and the mood is almost always breezy & fun, these characters live, breathe, and emote in a way rarely found in videogames. 

Naughty Dog has said that they're now finished with the series, and that makes sense. After you've suffered through a brutal fistfight hanging on a net trailing behind a cargo jet, as in Uncharted 3, what set pieces are left? I'd be fine if we never play as Nate again. But, TLL offers a glimpse into what kind of stories the universe has to offer sans its hero, and I think there's a lot of potential there. If ND decides down the road that there's still more to chart in this series, I'd gladly come back.

This was the first time I revisited Uncharted 4 since it first came out on PS4 in 2016, my first time playing Lost Legacy, and my first time playing either on PC.

And its Uncharted, what isnt there to love? Games that are basically a long interactive movie, but that doesnt make them bad in fact Id argue its what makes them so fantastic. Uncharted games have always been more about visuals and spectacle than anything else and it excels at it. The character interactions have and always will be a large part of what makes the games so enjoyable too.

In terms of completion time Uncharted 4 took me around 15 hours to play from start to end, and Lost legacy took me around 7 or 8 hours (including some of the open area side stuff)

Uncharted 4 in particular is probably the best in the series, it has the best narrative and character writing. Gameplay is the most well refined and all around its just good. The Lost Legacy whilst weaker than 4 IMO, is still really good in its own right (better than 1 and 3 for sure still) and it keeps all of the gameplay improvements from 4. It feels like an in between of a DLC story add on and a game of its own, its hard for me to place which side it leans more on.

It is worth saying though that whilst the content of these games is incredible I cant ignore the elephant in the room which is my experience with game crashes whilst playing. They happened pretty often for me. Not often enough that they actively ruined the game experience but enough for it to be noticeable and mildly annoying when they did happen (luckily this game has frequent enough checkpoints you don't usually have to replay much when you do crash.) I've seen others with this issue mention they are using an AMD GPU, so I figured Id mention that I'm the same (Raedon RX 5600 XT) Just a bit of a warning if you also have an AMD GPU before buying.

TLDR: A double pack of incredible games that are definitely worth experiencing, other than potential technical issues with crashes on AMD hardware. Now if only Sony would port over the first 3 Uncharted games too. That would be amazing.

It can be frustrating at times not knowing whether you're supposed to be watching a cutscene or performing a quick time event. If you've played Uncharted before, you know what to expect, but for me, this was my first time with the series and I was simultaneously impressed and disappointed.

Also, the Lost Legacy DLC is pretty trash from a story perspective. The villain is generic af, and the two female leads are unlikable and annoying. They essentially just act like (childish) men trying to constantly one-up each other and brag about how strong and independent they are. But I couldn't give a shit about them as people. They have no depth or character flaws, just "daddy issues."

Unfortunately, although I've enjoyed this game, I can't recommend it for one simple reason - crashing to desktop.

Having reached Chapter 12, At Sea, the game crashes to desktop at random points, at the very beginning of the level, between finding the arrows to entering the cave. It had worked flawlessly up to that chapter. All of the usual steps have been performed such as updating Windows, GPU drivers, verifying game files and reinstalling the game as well as clearing out any app data folders relating to the game. At this point I'm unable to progress with the story or the game.

In terms of graphics and game-play, the game looks stunning. Underwater scenes are very enjoyable, the volumetric lighting when underwater is fantastic. Great environment and very well built maps. The gun play and driving are awful, though I think this much is known from the Uncharted series. Guns have a weapon sway added that's very exaggerated. The free climbing is among the smoothest of games that have this mechanic, such as Dying Light.

Story wise, it does get extremely repetitive. While it has been enjoyable, I doubt I'd return to play it again (not that I can with the CTDs). The story can be summarised down to a basic formula of
- Let's find treasure and fight bad guys
- Arrive at destination of supposed treasure
- No treasure to be found
- Overcome with sadness, let's all decide to give up
- Suddenly, Nathan or somebody else realises it's a map or puzzle
- Move to the next chapter where it's all repeated

An outstanding port from console. The nostalgia it brought back is uncanny. Thank you PS for porting over some of the best games to PC. I highly recommend this edition to your collection. However, if you have yet yo play an Uncharted game this is only Uncharted 4 and Lost Legacy. It does not comes with Uncharted 1 - 3.

[h1] Introduction [/h1]

Uncharted games were Sony’s exclusive games for PlayStation and were a business card for a long time. This series of games ruled sales for years. Uncharted Legacy of Thieves was released in October 2022-nd for PC is technically Uncharted 4: A thieves and, which has been released in 2016-th for PS4 and Uncharted: lost legacy (DLC) which has been released in 2017.

I haven’t played in any Uncharted, and as most PC gamers - was disappointed about part 4, without knowing what happened in previous parts. Uncharted Legacy of Thieves looks very similar to Shadow of the Tomb Raider - two games from the same genre with similar game mechanics. But while I was playing Uncharted I had a mind - so that’s how [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/harkozavr/recommended/750920/] Shadow of Tomb Raider used to look like (may see review by the link). [/url]

Most reviews don’t pay much attention to Lost Legacy, but I think it’s a big mistake. Because when you buy the game - you pay for both Uncharted 4 and DLC, and don’t have a chance to buy them separately. That’s why I will review both of them.

[h1] Main Plot [/h1]

[b] Uncharted 4 [/b]
The plot is fascinating, from first minutes I was interested in understanding what’s going on. The beginning is trinket, because first few hours of gameplay are made in three different time periods. Climax is very explicit, and plot denouement leaves positive feelings. The characters look alive and there is real chemistry between them all. After finishing the game, the main plot leaves some questions, which points scenario gaps, but overall you may just not pay attention.

Despite it’s the 4-th part, the plot is independent, I have seen only a few references to previous parts. In general, the game doesn’t tell you - ‘Go and play previous parts to understand what’s going on’, and it’s good.

[b] Uncharted Lost Legacy [/b]
The plot looks crumpled. The main aim showed in first 30 minutes, and if at this time you are not completely attentive, then the whole game would create a bunch of questions. But in general the game’s plot seems to be quite coherent.

This DLC has much more references to previous parts, because the main character is a big reference. And for players who haven’t played previous parts it may look taken out of context.

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]

In both parts gameplay is combination of cinematic cutscenes (which are done perfectly), solving puzzles, climbing ledges and hills, shooters and some QTE. Uncharted 4 is more shooter, while the DLC has much more puzzles in it. Both games are based on climbing mechanics, and personally I was not annoyed from them, the game switches to other game mechanics in a very timely manner and I was not tired from climbing even they are very similar to each other. Both games have really easy puzzles, while Uncharted 4 have only few, the DLC has much more of them.

Both games are linear, but they have locations which may look as open world. Uncharted 4 has few big locations, and I got lost on them, I can’t find the right path and constantly walked in circles. The Lost Legacy has only only one big location, but I had no such problems with lost, because game gave a map.

[h1] Bugs and problems [/h1]

To play uncharted and don’t have problems - you need to have a good PC. Uncharted has some problems with optimization, but they are not huge. You may see some bugs, while you play - the game may freeze and write ‘Downloading %’. When moving to new locations, the game does not constantly display the loading screen, but loading after a break takes a very long time.
For all the time I spent in the game (25 hours) - the game crashed only 5 times, and usually it was after I systematically died at the same level for several times.

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

Uncharted Legacy of thieves is a good game. Yes it’s not new, but is still very good. Both games have good main plot, good story telling and cinematic cutscenes. I spent 19 hours in Uncharted 4 and 8 hours in DLC, and I enjoyed both of them. While Uncharted 4 is really good, per contra DLC is not bad. If you are thinking what to play between Shadow of the Tomb Raider and Uncharted, then definitely go for Uncharted.

Do you know what a handcar is? It's one of those wheeled carts that sits on railroad tracks, and you crank the lever and propel it forward. You get some nice scenery, but soon you're exhausted from cranking and are looking forward to getting to the end of the line. This is the handcar of games. You basically tap the same button and move along the rails and the characters make noises at you and you basically do the tedious work of performing out the role you've been assigned in this D movie. They know how bland this whole experience is, so they switch the button to do the one basic action occasionally just to annoy you.

I hated everything about this game. There was nothing redeeming about it. This like Tombraider is the work of people who want to make a movie, and the player is just there to suffer through it. Nathan Drake continually says things that are meaningless talking to himself. The cutscenes are painfully tedious and awkwardly slow. Then there's the in-game cutscenes you cannot skip, where you can't move for half a minute after it ends or you are forced to walk akingly slow and it lasts for a  minute or two sometimes until the game works out that the quasi-unskippable cutscene is over. I regret completing the first game in this collection just to get my moneys worth, if I had been able to get a refund I would have.

Devs please allow turning off Drake's boring rambling. Remove the slow walking. Make it so that you can skip the cutscenes and get a highlight of what you missed, so you don't have to sit through 20 minutes of low grade soap opera every 5 minutes. Cut the flashbacks, they are pointless make-work filler. For that matter cut this game back to 120 minutes and get rid of the filler. And then quit and move to hollywood to make the movies you really want to make because you secretly hate computer games. This is the worst game I have ever played, it felt like torture to complete it.

Genuinely baffles me as to how this got such rave reviews given it's basically an interactive movie. It's very little action and most of the 'adventure' feels scripted and forced.

(I only played to the end of chapter 5 so review based on this)

Graphics are fantastic (this shouldn't be a massive plus point, this is a AAA game in 2022 that costs £45, it's the expected) and the story is decent if not slightly predictable. The cinematic events look great, although given the game is about 80% cinematic cutscenes they should look great.

Controls are absolute trash. Given the amount of time you spend jumping to ledges it blows my mind you have to press the button once to jump and then again to climb up - either 'hold' the button when jumping to climb up automatically or push the joystick forward is a feature games discovered 10+ years ago, so why it was omitted in a game featuring so much climbing is mind blowing. Of course get to with in 3ft of the edge of a ledge and the game is more than happy to auto jump down. Default controls are just odd - 'X' is reload for every other game in the world, why not this one?

For the hand to hand combat there is no 'counter' or 'reverse' for strikes. You just have to roll, like some kind of idiot, around and around - it looks stupid and breaks immersion. How a AAA game in this day and age doesn't have such basic functionality is beyond me and there's no game play reason not to have it. The scenes where a ledge slightly crumbles or a beam creaks doesn't add any suspense to the game because you know that you have zero control over it - if you're hanging out a window and the ledge crumbles slightly you know it won't break because if it did you'd fall to your death as you don't have control outside the QTE prompts.

As I said at the start, this is an interactive movie loaded with QTE's, scripted events and scenarios designed to make you feel like you're doing something but really you have very little impact on what's going on. This feels more like another AAA game that's more interested in going 'we can make this in to a film and/or TV series!' instead of being a fun game with interesting gameplay and mechanics.

My rating: 9/10

* Uncharted 4: A Thiefs End
	- With a great yet mostly predictable story it's saved by the cast being backed by some of the best MoCap and voice talents I have seen in a long time. With typical Sony picturesque environments with no expense spared. Many of the issues stealing away a perfect rating from this game boil down to the shifty port for the PC; Many key binds are either not bindable or are locked together to one key, and platforming (which you do a lot of) is made annoying as there is no auto climb feature or W key auto climb so every move you are required to hit the jump key making the overall experience tiresome, coupled with a few missing standards on pc such as exclusive fullscreen meaning if you have a screen saver or auto sleep enabled you better keep your mouse moving during cutscenes, No ability to disable motion blur or adjust FOV without editing a CFG file and a few crashes and the occasional bird flying backward. Other than that the game is an all-around fantastic entry for the franchise that I highly recommend you experience especially if the idea of a Tomb raider meets Pirates of the Caribbean story sounds enticing to you. I hope Sony keeps bringing console exclusives over to PC but with maybe a little extra polish next time. Horizon: Forbidden West would be a dream come true!
	
Uncharted: Lost Legacy
	- While a subtle departure from Nathan Drake's story you assume the role of a familiar Chloe Frazer and follow her along on her journey to recover an ancient horn within a temple located somewhere in the Western Ghats mountain range. While this title does not stray too far from Uncharted 4's mechanics it does introduce a few new weapons along with a small yet satisfying lock-picking mini-game used throughout your time as Chloe Frazer. This title does slightly stray away from the overuse of climbing for more mesmerizing set pieces, combined with its shorter story and grand finale ending it's a perfect example of a proper expansion to an already amazing franchise. Who knows what else is on the horizon for the Uncharted IP?

Sony ports to PC are fast becoming the titles I look forward to the most, not only does Sony do a remarkable job porting - but the games themselves stand the test of time , standing head and shoulder above the current AAA titles - 8.8/10

Graphics 
I’ll split this into two parts ;

A Thief’s End is an older title and subsequently undergoes the most in terms of technology enhancements. For the most part, this is done extremely well, 4K, HDR, DLSS, RTX and extremely high res textures make this game look absolutely fantastic. The most stunning thing is the epic landscapes that Nathan find himself scaling - the mountains particularly where awesome. However this title had quite a lot of bugs and artefacts. The thunder in the opening sequence was awful, and many times I had shadow texture issues. Restarts helped but this really broke the immersion 

The Lost Legacy was made more recently and it’s immediately noticeable , there is far more detail within the world and characters. Though both leverage the same technologies, the Lost Legacy performed without a hitch and I only had 1 crash through my whole play through 

The games both do a wonderful job telling of the adventures of Chloe Frazer and Nathan Drake- from jungles, to ruins, mountains to cities - each is insanely detailed and immersive. Ultra wide support and high frame rate make these titles gorgeous to play. Each character is equally detailed and well animated 

Story 

Both stories are incredibly rich with detail, I preferred the tale of Nathan, I found the adventure more organic and unpredictable. Intertwined is the backstory of Sam, Nathan’s brother and their childhood. 

The Lost Legacy is much shorter and perhaps there wasn’t the time to fill in all the backstory- but I hope more of Chloe’s history is told on a future port. 

A thief’s End follows Nathan as he tries to find the treasure of Captain Henry Avery, a legendary pirate from long ago. The story closely follows Nathan’s adventure but also his personal relationship with his girlfriend and brother - the development of the characters is organic and rich in detail. 

Gameplay 

Both adventures bring together the climbing from Assassins creed and the combat from Tomb Raider. The Lost Legacy also steals some of Laura Croft’s attitude and hunger for the unknown. It’s impossible to play and not think of the epic Tomb Raider franchise 

The combat is basic, but no less fun. Many times I restarted a section just to see if I could do it silently - but I’ll save you hassle , there are only a handful of achievements that reward you for this (so check in advance!) 

There are no upgrades or character perks, instead the game throws the occasional QuickTime event and you have to mash “y” or “a”

The game really focussed on story and doesn’t overcomplicate what it wants to be. Both games want to tell an amazing story - and use the combat and QuickTime events to break up the movie experience 

Music

The music is good but not the best I’ve experienced in a AAA title. Generally the design is there to follow suit, but the games wants you to focus on the character, the dialogue and the adventure. So music swells with combat, it’s soft during emotional moment s - but it’s not extraordinary 

SFX js superb, the guns felt loud- the grenades really did go BOOM! But one thing I did notice is the effort to add detail (in the sound) in the different landscapes. Different types of birds and animals tweeted and squawked in the temples while the clatter of the machinery was audible as Nathan flew from corner of the world to another in the clattered out plane. 

The team did a great job pushing the immersion through this- and makes Uncharted 4 truly one of the best titles PlayStation titles to hit PC in the last few years

Very disappointing. This game, like many other recent AAA titles, has sacrificed responsiveness for animation realism. You feel like you're stuck in molasses mid-fight, and you'll simply be ignored if you press a button at the wrong time mid-animation, such as a roll, and there's no acknowledgement of the input. He stops running at random times so you feel like you're also being ignored in that regard too.

Aiming on M+K does not feel good. The aim keeps shifting to the left, because it does a subtle transition to where you were aiming prior to ADSing, so at the start of the ADS you subconsciously notice that the crosshair is to the right and begin adjusting, and then it's suddenly to the left after the ADS animation completes because of that. Really confusing.

Early on you're presented with forced stealth sections that last almost two hours. Then it throws you into a giant gunfight where the only way out is through the door the enemies come through (in multiple waves). So you just have to try getting through hoards of enemies without any challenging gunfights prior to that. Way to work up to it. 

The AI is unremarkable, and I've been shot through solid walls a couple times. Often companions will spout of stuff like "I don't think it's this way" or something, but at the wrong times, and it often just confuses you further when you were actually on the right track.

I played the first two games, and they felt FAR better than this does. 

Please stop sacrificing gameplay for the sake of realistic but unresponsive animations. It's almost as bad as RDR2.

The Uncharted series is an incredible series of video games, seamlessly blending cutscenes with gameplay, they offer a cinematic experience that rivals blockbuster movies in the same genre. If you like the Indiana Jones films and the Tomb Raider games you’ll love these. This is yet another great console port from Sony, I highly recommend you give them a go. 
After completing both games in the collection several times on my PC I booted the game up on my Steam Deck. Unfortunately the game cannot maintain a stable 30fps on medium settings with FSR set to balanced. Sadly, despite the verified setting on Steam I can’t recommend anyone play the game on Valve’s handheld. 
I’d also like to point out that this is indeed the 4th and 5th mainline game in a narrative driven franchise. You’ll be shortchanging yourself if you start here without playing Uncharted 1-3 first. I've just finished Uncharted 4 and the first word that is coming ot me is BOOOOORING. 
Actually I did say it loud a bunch of time while playing. 
Let's start with the graphics, it's ok, quite pretty looking but there some glitches here and there (like Nathan headless for instance). 
The controls are awful, it's clearly meant to be played with a controller, like a 10yo kid, but real gamer (hi yakuza ^^), those playing with keyboard and mouse, will feel heavy pain with this. 
The story is quite deep and pleasant, BUT, the PACE is horrific. You alternate between moment of pure FPS (badly done, very badly done, please do not try to make a fps), stealth mode (badly done too, please, forget about it, it's stupid to see your buddy running* in front of enemy and not being spotted, and anyway when after 30 minutes of stealth when you see you must clear the area whatever, you understand the stealth part is just to make you lose time) and exploration. 
I want to be clear, I bought this game because I thought it was mostly exploration. It's not. You are even incitate NOT to explore area, if you start looking everywhere your partner will start to press you and the game will ask you if you want some hint, in case you didn't understand the only linear pathway you must follow ... When I see how few people got the achievement for 50 treasures (and there's more than 100 in the game) I understand nobody play the exploration part. Too bad. 
Puzzles are childish, you don't have to think about anything more than 2 seconds. And there's only 2 puzzles in the game, so yeah, the fun exploration part is to forget. 
So to be back to the pace thing, it's simple: you explore (and it's slow, Nathan cannot run and speak at the same time or when he found an item, he cannot find an item when one is peaking to him too, so you have to wait ages for the blabla to end before moving on, it's boring) and you hide and you fight and you speak, so you have moment of intense action and moment of very very very endless scripted dialog. 
Pace is awful and the game is boring. The bro' robbering part is the worst by the way.
Speaking of brother, I never wanted so badly a npc to die. I think that game is ruined by the fact that you are (almost) always with this moron. 
Before my conclusion, I want to add that the saving is useless. When you load your save, it will bring you at the latest saving checkpoint (it shows that the console to PC port is very poorly done)
Well, huge disappointment, I've been waiting to play this game since it was on PSX, and now that Sony agreed to release on real platform, it's a failure :/

This has been my favorite game that has ever released (Uncharted 4) but now that its on PC its even better. I would recommend this game to anyone who hasn't tried any of the Uncharted games on PlayStation consoles. Its an immersive, story-driven game that will keep your attention for many hours to come.  Uncharted 4 has a more realism to it, while its past games has a supernatural aspect to it (monsters of some kind), in Uncharted 4, it does not have zombies or creatures of that kind.

I think maybe the uncharted games are not for me.

The platforming segments feel like fake game play. There's no challenge. You just move forward and press the jump button. Tons of game time is taken up by cut-scenes, interactive cut-scenes where you walk thru a hallway, fake gameplay platforming segments, and then the inevitable cover shooting.

If the cover shooting was fun then maybe that would be enough, but instead the PC is incredibly clunky to move, there is tons of kickback with the guns and there are imprecise shooting mechanics. 

Boring unrewarding cover shooting ends up being the only real game play the game has to offer.  I don't understand how these games became popular.

The Lost Legacy clearly marks the beginning of Naughty Dog's decent into ideologically driven narrative and character writing.  The character Sam for example, who once played a competent, knowledgeable, but somewhat dark foil to Nathan Drake, is turned into a bumbling fool who is the butt of every joke, and is used almost exclusively for comic relief.  Naughty Dog's writers are apparently eager to buy into the Hollywood trope of deconstructing formerly admirable male characters - an inexplicably fashionable trend in a world where only a third of college graduates are men.

Nevertheless, like Uncharted 4, the The Lost Legacy is a technical achievement which also excels in its gameplay.  Uncharted 4 is the standout experience in this bundle, containing a captivating narrative and likeable characters on top of its technical excellence.  Overall this bundle is worth the price of admission for Uncharted 4 alone, with The Lost Legacy providing a bit of value for the extra gameplay and impressive set pieces it provides, even if it falls very short in the writing department.

[h1] Warning to Naughty Dog hardcore fans: Please avoid reading this review because it is critically negative. [/h1]

Let's clear out one thing this review is not negative because of the bad quality of the port because it is mentioned by 90% of the users how frequent crashes are and the T posing in the cutscenes time to time and so on. It is only and only for the gameplay and the story.

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]
I played this game on hardest difficulty and I tell you what, don't do it. The combat and stealth mechanism in this game is absolutely garbage and very mediocore. The enemies are bullet sponge and your insane recoil with very limited ammo available makes it impossible to win the forced firefights out of cover which 90% of the covers in this game are breakable and in most missions it is a scripted fight where you can only shoot without being able to move to cover.

Another issue with the level/game design is you are forced to repeat the same thing over and over and over again in every chapter. 90% of the game is climbing simulator and trust me people, every time you assist your AI teammate to jump from somewhere or climb from somewhere expect that there is a cutscene where the platform falls and your character falls down and has to find a different route. I Am not joking this happens all the time to the point it gets extremely frustrating and predictable, I had a friend sitting by me and I told her let's make a bet this is where you help Sam or Elena to jump then the roof/platform/bridge breaks and Nathan has to find a different route. It is not a joke if I tell you this happens like 8 times in a row in just one chapter.

The chapters are way too long and way too boring, if you want my advice only play the game in explorer mode. The combat is nothing special to miss it.

Also I know that Tomb Raider reboot is copy paste of Uncharted but that game is actually much more interesting than this one because you are not forced to climb the same mountain in different skins for like 2 hours straight just to trigger a cutscene. The enemies are all same in this game, Sniper + RPG + Heavy trooper + Normal enemies with grenades and cars. Nothing changes in their tactics, it is just the same formula over and over again and a very mediocore boss fight at the end which tried to be a downgraded MGS 2 Raiden vs Solidus copy paste.

[h1] Story and Characters [/h1]
When I heard the hype about Naughty Dog story telling I couldn't wait to play this game and check it out for the story. But GOD, how annoying how cheap and how cheesy it is... The characters are bunch of lame jokers with zero passion or empathy or character development. Anything happens and all of them make a joke about it... Please, look at Mortal Kombat, a fighting game where story is not even the focus, only one character is the joker (Johnny Cage) and rest of the mare serious people. There is personality and variation there but in Uncharted you could easily swap Nathan with any other guy in the game even the villains and nothing would change.

Another thing that really annoyed me is the "Plot Armour", it is there for all characters who are good. You just know nothing will happen to them "just because". They get caught in explosion? It is fine they gonna walk out with a "joke". They are under heavy fire? No worries they have a joke in their sleeve to say. They thought they lost one guy? Nah no no no he is just playing dead to joke. This should be called Fast and Furious clone... cause guess what there is "family" in this one too, oh and every second a surprise brother or wife suddenly spawns somewhere.

Another seriously annoying thing is that you end up solving 1000 death traps + puzzles + clues just to open one door but then the bad guys are already there without a breach, so why on earth Sam and Nathan are even needed to be alive when they just get where these two stupid ones have to solve 100000 puzzles to get inside while for enemy it is "just because we are here before you"?

And one thing I don't understand this Shoreline with all these modern technology and everything, couldn't they just get a helicopter and land on the treasure spot which was not even in a closed space????

One serious plot hole is Sam lies to Nathan about his escape and gets him into all the trouble and when Nathan finds out about it absolutely nothing happens when they encounter each other. It is like "whatever" even after all the things he was about to lose. Have you guys who rate this game super high played any Splinter Cell game? In Conviction when Sam Fisher finds out about the lie which actually SAVED him and not put him in danger unlike Uncharted, he goes emotional like a legend he reacts like a real human being (watch it on YouTube). And when I see those games with such magnificent story telling are not even mentioned and some PS Exclusive garbage is all over the place being praised for a super mediocore writing it just goes on my nervous.

Just to make you understand what you are going to watch in the story, imagine Toy Story 4 where Sam is Forky and everyone else is Woody. You know how bad that film was? That is literally Uncharted 4 story, one guy loves to go into trouble and others insist on saving him for his stupidity.

I don't know maybe I have lost my taste but I grew up with games like Brothers in Arms + Metal Gear Solid 1-2-3 + All old Tom Clancy titles + Max Payne + Old Tomb Raider games and many other legendary titles which were Story Rich. How is this garbage even considered as a masterpiece when gameplay has no quality and story is one absolute piece of misery?

Come on people where is your standards? Don't praise everything they throw at you just because it is over hyped in the magazine and media. The result is other companies literally copy pasting it because of the "hype sale" and Tomb raider reboot is the fruit of what we get, a lost identity game one after another.

Thanks for reading and sorry for being a boomer but that was my opinion!

The game is genuinely awful. I thought I'd stick around to figure out if something in the gameplay eventually clicked but it is so deeply flawed there is not much to salvage except for the graphics.

The game is basically split in three: climbing, stealth and combat. Climbing is forgettable, hold W and mash space, if you've played assassin's creed for a minute you've seen everything this game has to offer here.

Stealth is ruined by the laziness of the devs to decide to code reactive AI instead of laid-out movement patterns, which means AI is unpredictable (and stupid) and will get into situations such as walking into each other and effectively having a 360° fov to spot you. You also get no silenced weapons, meaning you have to take down every target in stealth. This is obviously not feasible because the AI will spot you because of the aforementioned lack of movement pattern, and this leads into combat.

Combat basically ticks every bad PC FPS box that was ironed out in the last decade : abusive AI movement (get flanked while being suppressed, can't shoot while ducked behind cover), tanky AI (headshots barely matter an hour into the game bc I guess helmets make you impervious to rifle rounds?), inaccuracy and aim punch. It is a more optimal solution to go for bodyshots as the AI will punish you with aim punch the second you go for headshots, meaning the only viable strategy is to spam grenades and hose down enemies with body shots.

It doesn't help that the level design for those areas was meant for stealth (but the AI wasn't... go figure) so there is no progression to make through cover. If you move you die, all weapons are hitscan, and enemies spam grenades with perfect accuracy.

If you weren't yet deterred by the gameplay being abysmal whatever way you look at it, this would be a good moment to point out that half the game is cutscenes, a small portion of which you're forced to play through while having no bearings on what's happening. When you force me into fight scenes where each punch is scripted to miss, I stop playing. I guess you should've skipped the game trilogy and made a movie from the get go if you're so hell bent on making a game without gameplay.

As for the story it's exceptionally mundane, a series of bait and switch go-there-wait-no, with one-dimensional characters with zero progression and introspection. Think Indiana Jones but without spielberg and harrison ford. I guess the actors make do with the shitty dialogue they're handed.

Buy for the graphics, stay for the QTE... Or play an actual game instead.

[b] I'll try to keep it without spoilers (I played on Moderate Difficulty): [/b]


[h1] 1) Pro's: [/h1]
- Beautiful landscapes and areas (I really mean it, it's crazy!)
- Hooking story with interesting character building
- Cool puzzles
- Mostly fun platforming
- Mostly bug free
- Game is just the right length
- Going stealth on enemy encounters is really fun and satisfying

[h1] 2) Con's: [/h1]
- Missions are a bit repetitive
- Platforming is sometimes really janky (I've fallen off cliffs and died more than once which is hella annoying. It also messed up some of my enemy encounters -> when I tried to go stealth e.g.)
- I would've preferred if in the Lost Legacy the enemies would've spoken in their language as well instead of accented English -> it was like that in A Thiefs Legacy with the guards and locals

[h1] 3) Controversial Point: [/h1]
Although the puzzles were a bit difficult sometimes, I really liked the challenge. There was one puzzle though I just couldn't solve without a guide and when I found out how you could've solved it I still considered it way too hard (without spoilering it was the Ganesh Puzzle)

[h1] 4) Conclusion: [/h1]
All in all it's a really fun game and if you like Tomb Raider you'll definitely enjoy this one. Graphics are pretty up to date and considering it's a PC Port it's pretty stable. I had a bit of a hard time getting hooked in the beginning but after around 4-5 hours I really got into it. "The Lost Legacy" picks up a bit faster but I recommend you play "A Thiefs End" first. It takes around 14h + 6h = 20 hours to go through both parts whilst focusing mainly on the story. For the content the 50 bucks is worth it.

[b] Gameplay Approximation: [/b]

10% is cutscenes
20% is puzzles
30% is shooting
40% is platforming & exploring

Me and the Uncharted series go way back. I may have a more warped or biased opinion on Uncharted 4 but after playing it back on PS4, I went and bought the original 3 in the Nathan Drake Collection so it clearly had an impact on me.

I remember being in an awful and toxic relationship, living in some horrendous apartment and having no job. I would live off cereal and weighed about 9 stone. I had to borrow money for electric and gas and couldn't even afford a haircut with a dog ripping my clothes up because it was untrained which I wore whenever I went outside. You know what was there for me? Uncharted 4. I would turn the TV on mute, put my headphones on so it wouldn't wake up my partner as she would scream at me for being awake past midnight and I would go through each and every mission on this game fully immersed and living an amazing life within the story of Nathan Drake, this good looking dude on an adventure with his brother and his friend/father figure Sully. It was truly amazing and it will always hold a good place in my library and its just as good playing it now as it was back then.

As for Uncharted: The Lost Legacy, it felt strange. No Nathan Drake, just the serious Nadine Ross and the cocky Chloe Frazer. It was an interesting story and I suppose in a way, Uncharted doesn't have to have Nate to make it what it is but I still felt like it was missing something all the way through. If anything, it feels like an expansive DLC to Uncharted 4 with only one crash and a few minor glitches so the port wasn't too bad to play. I'd give this collection a try when it's on sale as it really is worth playing. Thank you for reading and enjoy your day!

The UNCHARTED: Legacy of Thieves Collection includes UNCHARTED 4: A Thief's End and UNCHARTED: The Lost Legacy. A Thief’s End is the main game with about 10 to 15 hours of playtime and The Lost Legacy with about 5 to 8 hours. Even though the games originally came out a few years ago they still hold up again any new game and are definably worth the purchase.

Both games have a great story with related characters and a good dose of humor. The gameplay is both enjoyable and challenging without being too hard to the point of being too stressful. On Explorer difficulty, you can cruise through the game enjoying the game's story without too much worry about dying. While on crushing difficulty you will be challenged and die lots, but with a few tries and some learning the enemy’s ways you can work your way through without feeling like it’s completely impossible. The graphics in both games are amazing, although I think The Lost Legacy is slightly better. I found myself getting distracted by the beauty and then realizing I didn’t hear anything the characters were just saying. Even better, they both support Ultrawide, Super Ultrawide, and HDR.

I went into them expecting something like Tomb Raider and while they are similar, they are better. It’s hard to say why but I enjoyed them more than the Tomb Raider games and want to play them again even though I have already played them a few times. One of only a few games I’ve liked enough to get 100% of the achievements. Absolutely worth the buy, Get it! If you are worried, stick it on your wish list and get it on sale, but Get it!

TL;DR Fantastic games with great a story, graphics, and gameplay. Get it. If you’re unsure then get it on sale, but get it. You won’t regret it.

I usually wait until I complete a game before reviewing it, but I’ll make an exception for this one. First off, beautiful game. Having played previous Uncharted games, I know I’ll be in for a joyride with this. Pokémon sort of side tracked me at the moment, so I’ll savor this experience a bit while I wait two years for FF7 Rebirth (RIP). If you’re a fan of Tomb Raider, then Uncharted will enthrall you, especially on higher resolutions with either good headphones or surround sound. I can’t say how long the gameplay is yet, but for the asking price or on a sale, I’d say it’s worth a buy.

I would like to add one thing though. Having the opportunity to reflect on this thus far, I wish Naughty Dog would focus more on bringing back and/or expanding on their older IPs. In my personal opinion, Last of Us 2 was nowhere near as good as the first, but even then, regardless, Last of Us in general as a series paled in comparison to Uncharted and Jak and Daxter. I’ll gladly hope and wait for the Uncharted Collection to come to PC. Maybe one day we can even get to experience the fabled Jak 4.

Anyway, if you like adventure platformers, I’d say this game is definitely worth checking out. You don’t necessarily need to have played the originals to be able to enjoy it either.
