One of the great PS franchises lands on PC. Performance is pretty slick, setting some occasional graphical glitches with god rays/shadows/water/reflections aside. 

For those new to the series, I recommend for playthrough #1, don't worry about being pro, just get the full uninterrupted experience. Play this game on easy and enjoy the story and beat most everything in the first go. It's like playing through a 6 hour interactive movie. The puzzles are the same on all difficulties. Gunfights are dramatically improved on PC with M+K controls, but still have some serious difficulty spikes on higher difficulties that will break your momentum and the flow of the narrative as you figure out how you're being killed.

This is one of the first games I've played on my new-ish OLED TV, and I have to say for a game that first wowed me on the base ps4, the visuals are still just simply stunning. Certainly not the most technically advanced in terms of ray-tracing and next gen features. But, the game closes this gap with such varied, vibrant and well-realized game worlds you can't help but gawk and look around everytime you reach an elevated surface.

Worth mentioning - Audiophiles out there will love the high dynamic range options...talk about realistic. I had to condense the range because the maximum was just too jarring. Folks looking for more immersion will love that, though.

As for the two included games: Uncharted 4 can stand on its own for folks unfamiliar with the series, but could have benefitted from a little more background/recap. Legacy really surprised me the first time I played it - I enjoyed it as thoroughly as the other Uncharted adventures. Getting both of these on deep discount feels like robbery, even if the combined runtime is only 25 hours. This is a game that, if you enjoy, you'll revisit every now and then...there's just nothing quite like it in my experience.

In the end, this is just a fun, non-threatening adventure game that I find I keep coming back to for a particular brand of harmless and comforting escapism. Recommended thoroughly if you just want to kick back and enjoy a cool story and locations. Gunplay feels pretty snappy on PC, and could even tickle the fancy of challenge seekers.

Great game!

The story is interesting and the characters are very well written and voice acted. The graphics are great, obviously, and the settings are truly stunning, no matter where in the game you are. The gameplay is very nice and smooth, no matter if you're just walking around exploring or if you're in a firefight, and I love the fact that you can approach situations from different perspectives.

Minor glitches here and there but nothing at all that's game breaking or that really affects the gameplay in any way. The only critique I have is the jumping; it feels very poorly thought out for a game that relies so heavily on jumping and climbing. There's no problem when it comes to calculating your jump and the trajectory, I almost always landed where I predicted, but it felt and looked very unreal when jumping to grab a cliff or a mountain. It's like the physics engine was a bit off during those sections, which again is very odd considering the amount of jumping and climbing. Again, nothing game breaking but just a minor detail I felt odd.

All in all, I highly recommend the game if you like story driven adventure games. It's very good!

[h1]A Thief’s End[/h1]

This is the absolute best video game I have ever played, toppling even [b]The Last of Us[/b] and [b]Horizon Zero Dawn[/b]. Wikipedia was right. The writing, cinematics, and directing are unbelievable. Even the chapter names are clever and have carefully thought out meanings. I can’t begin to imagine how much time and resources they spent on the script to have made it this rich and seamless. It was able to hit all emotions: excitement, humour, sadness, shock, guilt, horror, disgust, elation, anger, curiosity, the whole spectrum. I can go on and on about it, but just as with the many people who have experienced this game, I am lost for words how incredible it is in every facet. Even listening to the soundtrack brings me back to experience it again in memory.

[h1]The Lost Legacy[/h1]

This one could not match the main game. It is in a ballpark…in another state. The impressive storytelling, dialog, and character relationships are absent from this DLC. We are back to a regular old game that doesn’t take anything too seriously. The storyline is something that has been done a million times before with cartoonish elements. I wish they never made this DLC because I feel that it sours the lasting memory of [b]A Thief’s End[/b]. [b]The Lost Legacy[/b] isn’t a bad game per se, but [b]A Thief’s End[/b] set the bar really high, and by being associated to it as its successor without meeting or exceeding this bar, it just makes me sad that it had to end on a low note.

A review from someone who played through all the previous Uncarted games.
Long story short: aside from improved graphics, we've got pretty much the same we had before in parts 2 and 3.  And that inclues both the good and the bad from the series.

What is good:
- nicely directed scenes throughout the game such as that one when you got dragged behind the truck on you rope while shooting back;
- graphics, especially facial annimations
- optimization (but you should adjust the game right in the first place - therefore this thing will be mentioned in the bad things too)
- fun arenas where you need to eliminate a number of enemies using stealth or shoot-them-all aproach
- still charismatic and fun main protagonist

What is bad:
- The gameplay is quite repetitieve overall: walking - solving a puzzle - cleaning up small arena with bunch of thugs - repeat;
- At some point the scripted episodes when something breaks or fall apart while you're climbing, jumping onto, or just passing by really starts to become rather annoying
- The story is just ok. Enough to keep you going but it was always (meaning throughout the series) falling short of being really captivating and touching adventure. 
- The amount of climbing. I know that's one of the key things of the series but it was way too much. 
- Optimization. Here I had my struggle in a way that often in the middle of the game I was having my fps drop and never go back. That, after lots of googling, was eventually fixed when I started to run the game from under Steam's big picture (which had lower bearable resolution for my system).

To sum up, despite all the downsides and the fact that I couldn't finish the Lost Legacy add-on due to those same repetitive things, I'd still recommend this as you won't get any better adventure game at the moment (new Lara was similar and took inspiration form the Uncharted, but still not quite there) and if you haven't played previous episides - this might be quite enterntaining.

Since Steam doesn't allow ratings that stray from a "yes" or a "no", I will be tough here. I would have given it a "middle": "yes" for the game, "no" for the Windows version.

The game is great: a wonderful cinematic action game, no need to spend more words. Fun, dynamic, accessible but not exceedingly easy or "guided", and eye popping.

But... the Windows conversion is crap. I have an i7 with 32 GB of RAM, an M2 SSD, an RTX 3070 card. And while the framerate is good, and graphics are great, there are several instances where this game (even on the latest patch) has audio stuttering, especially severe in action sequences, that completely ruins the experience. The programmers clearly don't know how to make a PC conversion: I have played several MUCH heavier games that run flawlessly. Uncharted on the other hand is not particularly heavy: CPU and GPU stay at reasonable occupation levels, while maintaining steady 60 fps effortlessly. The absurd thing is that, in spite of this, the audio stutters, crackles, stumbles, has microfreezes whenever there's a lot of action going around. As if the developers had no idea on how to manage latency and audiovisual streams (I  am a programmer, so I know what I am talking about), and I see that many others with powerful machines have the same issues. Both CPU and GPU still have power to spare, and yet the game in certain situation is very stuttery.

And, add injury to the offense, the game is GREEDY. With 32 GBs of RAM, I had my system set to use only 4 GBs of virtual memory. You would expect a PS4 game to be perfectly satisfied with 32+4 GBs of memory, right? WRONG. At a certain point (market scene) it miserably crashes "because of not enough virtual memory". The crash is solved by letting Windows 10 freely manage virtual memory, resulting in a 20 GB pagefile. This is the first time such a thing has happened to me, and a further sign of AWFUL, lazy, ridiculous coding skills.

So, I repeat: great game, awful porting. Stay away until fixed.

Before I write about my own ‘view’ of this game, I’d like to state something very important to you all about this ‘Legacy of Thieves Collection’ first.
As the title describes, the game is a collection, there’re two different ‘projects’ under the same title in the game with different directors directing the stories. One’s called ‘ A Thief’s End’ which is an adventure of seeking legendary pirate’s treasure with Nathan Drake being the protagonist in the story. The other one is called’ The Lost Legacy’ which is based on Indian mythology, the protagonist in this journey is Chole Frazer. Despite ‘the Two’ have some certain casts appearing in both campaigns, the two protagonists: Nathan and Chole will never bump into each other because it’s not the same story with a different time. Moreover, the gameplay also differs, A Thief’s End is a linear campaign with 60% focusing on gunplay, hand-to hand combat, 40% with exploration the environment such as climbing, puzzle solving, item collecting, etc. The Lost Legacy is a mixture of open world and linear(point to point) adventure that giving you a chance to spend more time on exploring the world they’ve crafted with side missions, complex puzzles, collectibles etc. The gunplay and battles in the other hand, are less heavier, less often.

OK, now we’re clear about the different concepts of the campaigns, let’s talk about them with my own insights. I am being completely honest to say, when I did A Thief’s End, I wasn’t planning writing a review for it at all simply I wasn’t impressed. Why? Despite the game delivers stunning visuals, cinematic cut-scenes, they’re triple A standard, no question here. However, A Thief’s End, had a very disappointing story right from the start, ‘Seeking a pirate treasure’(I don’t go to the point beyond this, spoilers free review). Believe me, as a 30+ years old full-grown man, I’ve at least heard & watched & played more than couples of similar stuffs from radio programs to films and video games, though the details could be different, the idea itself isn’t original. It will be quite hard to impress me by this idea I’ve known pretty too well. I had my gut feeling at the start and it failed as I guessed. What’s worse? Compare to Chole Frazer, Nathan was pretty boring to me ( sorry boys) for the most of time. If this wasn’t enough, in his story, certain characters’ certain decisions and actions they’ve done, I found it’s difficult to acknowledge. Can’t go with the detail, in short, the story was a big letdown. The gameplay is linear, it wasn’t the problem bothering me, the real problem is: the game’s very repetitive aside from sightseeing, all you do is reaching to a place, found a clue, fighting some enemies in a frequent bases. Once short objective was reached, repeating the process in a different place. I’d only recommend this game (if it were A Thief’s End alone), to players who enjoying sightseeing(a beast rig is a must to achieve this goal), gun-fighting, cinematic visuals. Unfortunately, this is not my definition of a magnificent game should be. In quite the opposite, they can simply design a pixel graphic game with some original creative ideas with a well-written story that could easily win my recommendation, none triple A standard were required. On the contrary, all these eyes candies were bring together with a dull story is like talking to a beautiful woman with a boring soul, I don’t think she will keep my attention on her for long, so it was the same with Nathan’s adventure.

The ultimate fact that alternatively changed my mind to write a recommendation for Uncharted: Legacy of Thieves Collection is Chole Frazier’s story alone: The Lost Legacy. I must say, girls have done an excellent job this time than boys had. 1st, as I mentioned a little above, her campaign is based on Indian mythology with directors’ own visions of creativity. The idea itself is very original, I’ve never heard nor seen a sophisticate story of this in the first place. I’ve searched my memories, in Tomb Raider III, Lara Croft went to Indian jungle, but aside from some fights and minimum sightseeing, nothing deep down to the mythology or Indian culture itself, nothing in comparison. In TR Underworld, Lara went to Thailand, despite sharing some similar landscapes like South-East Asia mountains, jungles, Buddha(Shiva)statues, again, barely scratched anything under the surface of Buddhism or Indian mythology. The Lost Legacy however, have done it terrifically, not only with the excellent storytelling, but also the amazing landscape to travel around. 2nd, compare to Nathan Drake, Chole Frazer is a much more interesting protagonist to play with, I enjoyed her British accent which woke some good memories of my old days, with a sense of her dark humor, characteristic personality, she was nothing short of fun to tag along. Just as she said,’ no one is perfect’, the good and bad thing she had done, made her ‘a real person’ who walked into my heart in her own way. She reminds me of Catherine Zeta Jones’ performance in the film: Entrapment, though the subjects were not the same. When a game somehow managed to establish a link connecting my real life events, I would no longer treat it as if it were someone else’s story, it undoubtedly got my full attention now. 3rd, gameplay-wise speaking, unlike A Thief’s End, The Lost Legacy approached players by a different path: by encouraging players to explore the world with some clever design’s help, the game came together as a whole new world to adventure. For example, by completing some certain side missions which will reward you ‘an easy way’ to find all the missable treasures scattering across the land. While in ATE, all 100+ treasures have no hints,  it’s impossible to find them all on your first run unless you have a guide at hand. E.g. Reducing repetitive combat which weren’t much creative room there to work with. Instead, focusing on well-crafted puzzles that take some serious time to study with then solve. These examples showed the development team does seem to take some time experimenting if they were players, what would be fun to do in the game? (When you design some hidden treasures in the game, you don’t want players eventually couldn’t find them, do you?) Little by little, this was what makes the difference in the end. 4th, I could even say, A Lost Legacy has done better than any piece of new Tomb Raider Trilogy had done. It’s a quite difficult compliment to earn. Especially comes from someone who have played TR first, not the other way around due to Sony’s delusion of what exclusives could have brought to them. 

But one thing A Thief’s End did better than The Lost Legacy is: it has few crashing issues for the entire long game and none of them are game-breaking. TLL in the other hand, have some serious issues I have to mention here as a fare warning. It crashes to desktop so often, literally in the 2nd half of the game, every water scenarios, it would crash for unknown reason. Some of them are close to game- breaking because they did happen in the same spots multiple times in a row which almost stuck me from progressing the story. This is a red flag no kidding. I have a high-end PC, 4K unlimited FPS with Render Scale set to 180%, I have no idea what kind of advanced setting inside could have caused this, likely, the problem is not on my end. Look, I am not saying crash issues definitely will happen to you too, but just in case, there’s a potential risk here if you ended up purchasing this game right now. Just keep this in mind. Well, it doesn’t affect my purchase decision by now since I have already completed the game, but it will do for my future orders from Sony: e.g I won’t buy The Last of Us Part.1 in advance knowing full well from the same studio, I could experience the same issue which ultimately could break my game if I were not so lucky next time. I surely have no desire to take the risk.

Technically marvelous, beautiful, and occasionally fun, but just not that good of a game:
* Boring writing. This might (unfortunately) be as good as AAA game writing gets, but you're still left with a derivative plot, generic characters, and a narrative that makes little sense. The story beats are tropey and completely predictable, and most of the "witty banter" is just lame jokes. If we were judging this by movie standards, the writing would not even be on the level of a Michael Bay script.
* Extreme ludonarrative dissonance. All the protagonists are mass murderers. In dialogue, they seem dismayed at killing, and yet when they mow down waves of enemies, they just laugh it off and continue as if the entire area were not littered with corpses. You just can't go for movie-style writing while also having arcade shooter gameplay. It's completely looney and immersion-breaking.
* Poor legibility. The game leans too hard into realism, and as a result, critical game cues such as where a handhold is, or whether you're in cover, are difficult to read. It's also not always clear where you're supposed to be going, save for some vague instructions given in dialogue. (But don't mistake this for non-linearity: the game will often block backtracking with little warning.)
* Arbitrary fencing. See that pool of water a few feet down? Jump in it and you'll instantly die, even though you've been to that area before, because you passed through an invisible gate.
* Too much emphasis on being cinematic. There are several sections in the game where you're being chased by something that can kill you in a few seconds. It's supposed to be intense, but it ends up just being frustrating: partly because it's not always clear where you're supposed to go, partly because you sometimes HAVE to die to know that you can't go somewhere, and partly because the camera often ENDS UP FACING YOU in these sections. Who thought this was fun?
* Psychic enemies. As soon as you're discovered, everyone immediately knows where you are, making stealth gameplay frustrating. Enemies also have unrealistically excellent aim, especially with grenades. (Some enemy chucked a grenade 5 stories up and landed it at my feet.)
* Frustrating combat (on Hard). Magic grenades, spongey enemies, Nate constantly picking the wrong cover or grabbing the wrong handhold, bullets magically going through cover, perfect enemy aim even when you're swinging through the air. (What's even the point of those hookholds? All they do is get you killed.) I'd attribute a good quarter of my deaths to poor controls or Nate randomly doing something stupid.
* Offensively simple puzzles. This is "square block in square hole" level stuff. I never had a eureka moment for any of them, just annoyance at the grunt work I'd have to do to get to the next section.
* Ridiculous companion behavior. Your buddies will routinely run into enemy line of sight without them noticing. Nobody ever bothers to shoot or even follow them. They are seemingly incapable of hitting anything. Why are they even there? (There's a chase scene where one of my companions is under direct fire for about 5 minutes without a scratch. I almost had to laugh.)
* Pointless exploration. Sometimes, you'll find a shiny trinket hidden in a cave. That's about it.

This game reminds me why I invest so much time in indie games. Uncharted is shiny on the surface, but ultimately soulless, and the fact that critics gush over it points to the immaturity of gaming as an artistic medium.

EDIT: The epilogue was really well done. I just wish the rest of the game was up to that standard.

It's a good triple A experience and does not seem to suffer from a lot of the problems other triple A games often do. There definitely is the linearity and the mechanisms to keep the game moving, but it's not like characters are spamming hints at you incessantly. The dialog is well done, it does not insult the player's intelligence making them feel like the lowest common denominator too much (I mean it's still like that don't get me wrong, just not nearly as bad as other games). The puzzles are also medium/low on difficulty. Still triple A fodder puzzles, but not awful or anger inducing, and good looking enough to make you not get bored too badly before they're over.

The set pieces are what make the game worth it, however. The insane, over the top action moments after long periods of calm are a real spectacle and an impressive feat in game development. You can feel the millions of dollars that were put into producing this stuff. That makes it worth it to play, just to see what's possible in this medium. The limits are constantly pushed, insane situations you thought were already teetering on the brink get cranked up to levels you did not expect to be reachable; it just keeps pushing. For that reason, and the fact that the other Triple A tropes are not all that bad here, make this a better experience than most other games in this tier and genre. I would recommend it, especially if it's on sale. There's a lot of bang for your buck here.

I don't even know what to say. Uncharted 4 is a masterpiece, even all of these years later, it still holds up incredibly well.

SOME SPOILERS

My review was originally just a generated review but instead I decided to write a actually legit review off my experience with this magnificent collection

My Settings & What I played on 

I played on my default PC with a GTX 1660 Ti and a i7-9770k with 16gigs of DDR4 2666mhz ram

my settings in-game were all ULTRA with Enhanced Models turned on. I did have my Texture Quality to MEDIUM, the game was totally playable on all ULTRA except there was significant frame drops in huge open areas going to 40 to 50s FPS with my textures on MEDIUM I had 60+ FPS almost threw out the entire game.


GAME-PLAY 

The game play was very enjoyable I loved the parkour and the grappling hook the best parts were scaling the huge cliffs or the huge building such as the clock tower or the tower in Libertalia that collapses, it also has some great screenshot worth views (check my screenshot s to see!)

The game is also enhanced coming from PS4 so it ultimately looks WAAAYY better than what is looked like on there I wouldn't recommenced playing it on a low end pc cause part of the game is how good it looks

There is also quite a but of gunfights with shoreline, the game also features a variety of weapons and enemy types such as Juggernauts which you see later in the game

the Fist fighting is also pretty fun, gunplay is nothing special is kinda like your typical third person shooter with cover mechanics, BUT some areas have grapple spots where you can swing around and shoot enemies or jump onto them for a take down. the stealth mechanics are also great, i never really had a encounter where a enemy seen me out of nowhere

LENGTH

the game is quite long, it can take up to 15 hours to beat Uncharted 4, especially if you take your time and not rush through it. it also does have some pretty difficult puzzles with captain avery, and clues which you can find from notes that you put in your journal. 

BUGS

I never had any significant game breaking bugs except a lot of texture issues, a few of my sesions the textures bugged out on the character models and would have icons all over them or even change them a different color completely. the wind physics hitting clothes would also bug out causing them to freak out 

PRICE

the game is quite expensive especially considering it is just 2 campaign games, no multiplayer or nothing. I'd say wait for a good sale to pick this up instead of spending a full $60 


Overall I enjoyed the game A LOT and recommend it :)

Runs and looks good enough on Steamdeck. Two things to keep in mind, when you start the game:
- There are two games that you can choose to start in the main menu: "Uncharted 4: Thieves End" or "Uncharted: Legacy". I looked up which to play first and generally saw people recommend starting with Uncharted 4 because it has the backstory for Legacy and makes more sense that way.
- After you choose "Thieves End", the first time you run the game, you need to let the game compile shaders. There is a little loading percent indicator which says "Building Shaders". Just wait about 15 minutes for this to complete. Make a coffee or something, while this one-time setup is happening and be patient. Do not click around the menu, looking for a way to skip this. 

The game is totally worth the huge 120 GB install size and 15 minute wait on first-time setup. The graphics, gameplay, voice acting and massive amount of content are simply top-tier. If you have a decent PC to play this, get it. If it's on sale, it's a steal and you will fit right in with the thieves ;-)

Uncharted 4: A Thief's End:

The ambitious end to a long running franchise, Uncharted 4: A Thief's End is a very fascinating game.
The gunplay is enjoyable, the puzzles are decent and the humor is pretty good, there are some hilarious character interactions.

The story though, isn't very deep but I liked the darker approach and the flashbacks, it's interesting enough to keep you playing, and it really makes you care for the characters.

Exploration works decently, but it could've been better, there are documents you can read or find collectibles. The open area in Madagascar was one of the best parts of the game in my opinion, the car handles very well and the driving feels phenomenal.

Lastly, climbing is a very big part of the game, and even though the climbing mechanics are very smooth, I really had to force myself to enjoy it some times, and I wish there was less of it.

The action sequences are easily the best thing about this game, some jaw-dropping set-pieces keep you on the edge of your seat.

Uncharted 4 is the definition of a "Movie Videogame".
It's absolutely gorgeous, the cinematography is outstanding, the performances are fantastic and the soundtrack fits well, but gameplay-wise it's just... exhausting, not because of the controls or the gunplay, but because of the hand-holding and the linearity.

Uncharted the Lost Legacy:

Uncharted the Lost Legacy is proof that Uncharted can great even without Nathan Drake. The Lost Legacy is essentially just more Uncharted 4, it's something like a stand-alone expansion, and a good one at that.

Honestly, I am surprised, I enjoyed this more than I expected. Even though the gameplay is more of the same, there's less climbing, and the fact that the game is relatively short is mostly a positive.

The game rarely feels repetitive, every puzzle is different from each other, and there is also an open area in the middle of the game where you can explore, which was implemented very well.

As for Chloe and Nadine, they make a pretty nice duo, where's Chloe is likeable and a goofball, Nadine is the opposite, she's aggressive and focuses on her mission. I liked their chemistry and I think both characters work very well together.

And now for the negatives, the story isn't necessarily bad, it's just very generic and there are no stakes. Also, in my personal opinion, the biggest flaw the game has is that there are barely any highlights in it, almost no action except from the last chapter, which is a complete letdown considering how the action is literally the best part about this series.

Overall it's very solid, and for its size it's definitely worth checking out, a great stand-alone expansion.

Conclusion:

Thank you Sony! Both games runs surprisingly well and overall very fun games. Uncharted 2 is still my favorite tho, but i'm happy to see Uncharted 4 and the Lost Legacy finally on PC, Uncharted 1,2,3 when?

I really liked `thier house` from the beginning of the game, yet you spend so little time there that I wonder how the developers could have justified detailing it to this high degree - it must've been advertising. Now that I am typing it, that little Crash Bandicoot intro couldn't describe this game in any better way.
You're running along the path, doing your little spin attack, not knowing exactly why you're there. Then you jump a little. But unlike Crash Bandicoot, Uncharted seems to try and hide the fact that it is a Railroad Adventure Game.

I am tempted to call this a masterpiece. In my opinion this is undoubtedly the best Uncharted game in the series not just because of the superior graphics but also the story and gameplay. I may be biased because this was the first game I played in the series but I have now also completed the second and third games and while impressive for being on the PS3, they do not come close to rivaling Uncharted 4. 

With the power of the PS4, this game has larger areas. There is a lot to explore and with the stunning locations and attention to detail, this is a joy. There are notes to be found throughout the game which expand the world and present stories outside of the main story. The gameplay also benefits from the larger areas and allows for multiple paths to reach the same end goal. The areas are also more three dimensional and the grapple hook is a welcome addition. 

Most importantly I had the most fun playing this game hands down. The addition of the alert indicator on enemies and being able to mark enemies makes stealth a very viable and fun option in a lot of areas and is very satisfying to pull off. The guns feel much better in this game compared to the previous games and the controls feel very natural and easy. 

The story is both thrilling and heartfelt, the characters feel very real and everyone's motivations are clear. These are all lovable characters. The main villain isn't overly macho and "villainy" and even his motivations also provoke some sympathy. There is good female representation here as well. The dialogue throughout the game is witty and fun.

The pacing of the game is great. A good balance between exploring, climbing and encounters with enemies. The puzzles are quite simple and straight forward but feel fun. There are some epic set pieces but that are still grounded in reality. Some sequences really makes this feel like playing a very good action/adventure film. The "supernatural" element was left out of this game, which I thought was a welcome choice. There is more focus on character development instead. The story felt more realistic but at the same time extraordinary. 

The music is great. A mixture of epic orchestral music but also some tender emotional moments as well. 

Acting, voice acting all superb and natural. 

From beginning to end this is an absolute joy to play. A truly epic adventure with a very satisfying ending. Would highly recommend this to anyone!

Edit 2:  So my previous assessment of the Steam Deck performance was based on the Lost Legacy campaign, which doesn’t run as well on Steam Deck.  The main game actually runs quite well.  So I do recommend this game for Steam Deck as long as you’re aware Lost Legacy runs pretty bad compared to Uncharted 4 on the Steam Deck for some reason.  You can actually run the game at full 720P in the main game on Steam Deck, Lost Legacy is more like 540P, it’s a big difference in frame rate and visuals.  Something to keep in mind.

Edit:  Actually you can run DSR, if you set the desktop resolution to your target resolution using a PC DSR resolution setting and not an HDTV setting.  There is also a resolution scaling option allowing you to render up to 8K apparently, basically rendering the DSR option somewhat redundant.  This is all stuff that was added after launch, kinda wish I had waited to play the game at this point.
On a side note, this game as listed as Steam Deck ready.  I installed it on my Steam Deck and checked it out and the performance is horrendous.  I mean, I don't know who optimized the settings for this game because they need to be fired.  Whoever set up the games settings has the game running sub 30 FPS using an FSR setting.  You can actually go in and using the resolution scaling setting set a lower than 720P resolution that will maintain at least 30 FPS, but the experience is horrible.  You can barely tell what you're looking at everything is so blurry from running such a low resolution.  I don't recommend this game for Steam Deck at all.  Personally I only really play mostly older games that run very well on the Steam Deck.
Performance wise with a 4090 and up to 8K resolution, the 4090 can play the game at 8K max settings around 40 FPS, at 7K roughly, you can get closer to 60 FPS.  I'm running G Sync so even in the mid 50's it's very smooth.

So much better than especially the PS4 and PS5 version.  I was trying to play the PS5 version on the fidelity graphics option, but the horrendous frame rate just made it unenjoyable.  I'm currently running an RTX 4090 on stock settings and it's running the game at 4K 120 FPS with plenty of room to spare, about 80% GPU utilization on average.  However there are areas of the game where it does dip into the low 100's.
But, you pretty much need a 4090 to play this game at a solid 4K120.  I upgraded from a 3090 and I'm guessing you'll probably get around 90-100 FPS with a 3090 at 4K most of the time.  It is so nice to get the maximum quality from this game with the smoothness of 120 FPS, it's still is a great looking game, runs really well.  I'm currently playing it with an Xbox 1 controller, but you can't change the control scheme for some reason.  I would like to get reload mapped to X instead of Y.  One of the major issues I have with this game is there is no full screen mode, same as Final Fantasy 7 Remake for PC if you've played that.  There is a borderless fullscreen mode and a windowed mode.  So you're stuck at whatever your monitors native resolution is, no DSR if that's a feature you were hoping to use, I was.  I was hoping to play the game at a higher resolution at 60 FPS.  I was hoping there would be support for Dolby Atmos, I thought the PS5 version had that, but I guess I was mistaken, there is no option for it in the menu.  Or at least it's not labeled Atmos, it just says sound field.
As a game, yeah, this game is great, you should definitely check it out if you're into Tomb Raider style games.  For the PC version 9 out of 10, lacks a few features.  Why there is no fullscreen option is just strange to me.  I have run into a few bugs with characters getting stuck in walls or not progressing a quest.  Fortunately the game has tons of checkpoints and returning to one usually only costs you a few minutes.

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead, murdered by my brother-in-law Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, Hank came to me with a rather, shocking proposition. He asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using his connections in the drug world. Connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded, I... I always thought that Hank was a very moral man and I was... thrown, confused, but I was also particularly vulnerable at the time, something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me on a ride along, and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin so I agreed. Every day, I think back at that moment with regret. I quickly realized that I was in way over my head, and Hank had a partner, a man named Gustavo Fring, a businessman. Hank essentially sold me into servitude to this man, and when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn. Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling out. From what I can gather, Hank was always pushing for a greater share of the business, to which Fring flatly refused to give him, and things escalated. Fring was able to arrange, uh I guess I guess you call it a "hit" on my brother-in-law, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured, and I wound up paying his medical bills which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge, working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring, and did so. In fact, the bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen in the ranks to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA, and about that time, to keep me in line, he took my children from me. For 3 months he kept them. My wife, who up until that point, had no idea of my criminal activities, was horrified to learn what I had done, why Hank had taken our children. We were scared. I was in Hell, I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, to end this nightmare, and in response, he gave me this. I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. I... All I could think to do was to make this video in hope that the world will finally see this man, for what he really is.

This review is specifically for Uncharted 4. I haven't played lost legacy and have no plans to. This isn't a bad game, but it IS the most overrated game I've ever played. The graphics are great and the story is solid enough to keep you interested. There are some pretty impressive set pieces, but the gameplay and level design feel like they got ripped straight out of a PS2 game. Walk here. Shoot some guys. Repeat. They could have at least added some variety to the combat in some way but it's literally just shooting and tossing grenades with nothing at all to spice things up. It feels so basic and dated. The traversal is boring as sin. Climbing is slow and boils down to just holding up while mashing the jump button. It's awful. There is no way to even fall. It is literally impossible, you cant even jump off mid way through a climbing section. In the 5 hours i played, the only puzzle i did was pushing a crate like 10 feet to jump to a ledge. I'll probably get hate for this review since this series is pretty much legendary, but I feel like I gave the game a fair chance and this is my honest opinion.

Seek your fortune and leave your mark on the map in the UNCHARTED: Legacy of Thieves Collection. Uncover the thrilling cinematic storytelling and the largest blockbuster action set pieces in the UNCHARTED franchise, packed with all the wit, cunning, and over-the-top moments of the beloved thieves – Nathan Drake and Chloe Frazer.

Visual:

One thing I will say about this game is visually, this is so insane that you will fall in love with the game environment. Every location in this game was extremely eye soothing and beautiful.  The level design was too good. Huge shout out to NAUGHTY DOG for delivering us the insane visual in this game. 

Gameplay:

Now Let's talk about the gameplay. In both games, gameplay was fun. You can stealth your way or go guns blazing. Puzzle's were too good. Every puzzle was unique and fun. Had so much fun solving those puzzles. Loved the cinematic action-packed gameplay also.

Story: (Uncharted 4) On the hunt for Captain Henry Avery’s long-lost treasure, Sam and Drake set off to find Libertalia, the pirate utopia deep in the forests of Madagascar – leading to a journey around the globe through jungle isles, far-flung cities, and snow capped peaks on the search for Avery’s fortune.

Lost Legacy - In order to recover an ancient artifact and keep it out of the hands of a ruthless warmonger, Chloe Frazer must enlist the aid of renowned mercenary Nadine Ross and venture to India’s Western Ghats to locate the Golden Tusk of Ganesh. On Chloe’s greatest journey yet, she must confront her past and decide what she’s willing to sacrifice to forge her own legacy.

Conclusion:

Overall enjoyed the story on both games. But highly recommended to play the Uncharted Trilogy before playing this one. I played the first two on emulator and the third one was unplayable, so I watched it on Youtube for the story. Hopefully ND will bring the trilogy to PC in the near future.

The PC port is smooth. Played smoothly on my rig.

Final Verdict: 

Lastly, The achievements are fun. You can perfect this game if you have patience. I am a fan of the action-adventure genre, so as a Tomb Raider Fan this game is a must-play.

+ Good Story
+ Insane Visual
+ Insane Level Design
+ Fun Combat
+ Interesting Puzzles
+ Good Port
+ Fun Achievements

- None.

10/10. Recommended.

[b]UNCHARTED™ 4: A THIEF’S END[/b]; I played this title for the first time. The story of [u]Nathan Drake[/u] and [u]Sam[/u] It drew me in incredibly I will not write much so as not to give away their story, because if someone were to read this review and I could write a great deal about this game with in turn I would be betraying some part of its History and believe me it will be better to play it for yourself and feel that atmosphere, see those wonderful graphics, those realistic lighting and that one of the best done Stories and I might even be tempted to write not one of the best, and frankly in my opinion the best game I've ever managed to play in my life, and I'm already preparing for the next pass. One more thing I have to admit that [i]Naughty Dog[/i] knows how to play on our emotions perfectly. And I regret that I did not have the opportunity to play its previous parts ☹
[b]UNCHARTED™ THE LOST LEGACY[/b]: The story of [u]Chloe Frazer[/u] and [u]Nadine Ross[/u] also in part, [u]Sam's[/u] story is also wonderfully crafted. The game is simply beautiful, The landscapes of the Western Ghats are somewhat associated with the picturesque views of Madagascar from "four". Of course, there was also no shortage of truly cinematic scene direction, which gives the gameplay the right amount of momentum. Especially during chilling chases and action scenes. By the game's closing scenes one feels like clapping standing up from admiration. So is the story of [b]Chloe[/b] and [b]Nadine[/b] worth exploring? Fans of the series certainly know the answer, which in their case is "YES". The rest of the players need to keep in mind that while we are still dealing with a technical masterpiece, in terms of narrative and gameplay the game does not match the quality of the excellent [b]UNCHARTED™ 4[/b], but it is also a great game. Still, especially considering the price, this is a title worth reaching for if you are looking for a simple and entertaining adventure. All the more so because the package is exceedingly complete, because investing in the [b]Lost Legacy[/b] you will also receive in the set the entire content of the network mode from "[u]four[/u]" along with the latest patches.

Having played the early uncharted games on a PS3 many years ago it was quite nice revisiting the franchise. The ports are good. Note that you have to let the shaders load when you first launch the game. On the title screen it will indicate they are loading in the bottom right hand corner. You can launch the game prior to the shaders loading but you will have problems with the game crashing. Also I had to use an older Nvidia driver as again kept having game crashes.

However once my technical glitches were out of the way the game ran really smooth.

Graphically its a really nice game. Story rich. You can bypass the story but if you did I dont know if the game play would cut it alone.

The game play is good. Lots of combat with perhaps dated mechanics but still enjoyable. Plenty of weapon choices but you cant mod them. Lots of climbing, jumping and rope swinging in fantastic surroundings. Its quite a forgiving game in that its hard to die but it makes the game quite fluid.

Most of the chapters are linear with an exception in each game where you are introduced into a fairly large open world area. You can do tasks in a random order but note it is easy to miss stuff if you are going for a quick game completion.

I would say allow 20hrs max for each game and you will be done. You can obviously do it much quicker. I think people do it in 6hrs but if you want to savour it allow about 20hrs.

The second game off the two is shorter and hollowed out a bit compared to the first and I suspect cost saving was a factor in development  but still well worth playing,

These are  top notch games at a good price at release.

Another Playstation exclusive comes to PC with one of the most charming adventure series out there. Nathan Drake, life long thief, finally decides to settle down after a life full of adventures, lost treasure and countless close calls. Along with his wife Elena, he lives a pretty quiet life, has a pretty quiet job and overall seem to finally have put his travels behind ... or has he? It is clear that adventure is still in his mind and he fears that he might go back to the life of crime he once knew if he's not careful. But one day, when a ghost from his past shows up to his door with a request for help he can't help but put everything he has achieved on the line for one last job.

[PERFORMANCE]
First off, I have to open up saying this: This game runs like a dream. The graphics are as impressive if not more than what I remember. It runs smooth (I had maybe 1 hiccup at most). And I don't know what magic they worked but even at 1080 this game looks impeccable, not a pixel out of place. It has made a very polished integration to PC, adding a lot of options to graphics, controls and even integration with Logitech devices and NVIDIA features. It's always impressive when a console game gets ported to PC and doesn't break after running past 60 frames. I feel like I found only 1 bug in the entire experience (I drove a jeep against a wall and accidentally vaulted over the jeep, clipping the wall and falling out of the map), besides that this game is built very solid. This feels like a standard in how ports should be handled almost.

[GAMEPLAY]
The gameplay in Uncharted games has always been in the lighter side. What I mean is that what carries this game is its charming characters and crazy adventures. The puzzles are interesting but not too hard, and there are not too many of them. There aren't many combat scenarios but I'm kind of thankful for that because the combat in this game is probably my least favorite part. Don't get me wrong, is not bad, but it feels like it gets in the way of the story and the exploration. The exploration takes a massive improvement with the integration of vehicles and semi-open hubs to explore to your own pace. Even if the vehicles aren't used much they feel pretty good to drive, and are integrated in the gameplay as well in what must be one of the best chase sequences I have ever seen in a videogame to date. It literally has to be seen to be believed.
Overall the gameplay retains the formula used in past Uncharted titles. If you're looking for a very deep gameplay loop or mechanics you won't get them here, this is more of a casual ride with a very fun story.

[ACHIEVEMENTS]
This game doesn't come with the multiplayer, so all achievements are offline. They are not easy tho, I finished a full playthrough and only got 14 out of 101. Some include very specific things, getting off the beaten path to find extra dialogue, take a picture of Sully when you're supposed to be taking a picture of an old pirate artifact, stand still for 30 seconds to replicate the blooper at the E3 presentation of this game. Get your plan journals for this one, it's gonna be a long one.

Overall this is everything I've ever wanted from a port of Uncharted 4 to PC. If anything it makes me wish they ported the old ones as well. Very solid performance, very solid story, very solid game. The story of Nathan Drake ending is a very bittersweet experience for many people, but luckily it was a very fun ride from beginning to end. Take comfort in the fact that this port does the story justice.

I began the Uncharted franchise with Uncharted 4. That's not the ideal experience because I lacked the background to appreciate all the references to earlier games. Despite that, I still thought it was an outstanding adventure game; awesome gunfight encounters with a dynamic combat system that lets players enter and exit stealth, epic set pieces, fantastic VA and the pirate-themed storyline made it such an incredible achievement. This PC port captures all of that. Negative reviews mention forced mouse acceleration-but I'm one of those people who don't notice that (or motion blur). I only notice forced inverted controls. Towards the end, I did notice the graphics lagging during busy animated sequences, but Uncharted 4 feels pretty much exactly the same as on PS4. The only difference is I was able to aim a lot better (PS4 was my first console after Gamecube and I had no experience with modern shooters) but Avery's Mansion, the shipwreck beach and exploding mummy section were still insanely hard on crushing, so a big tick for preserving difficulty. When Sony made Uncharted 1-3 freely available during covid lockdowns, I took the opportunity to fill in the gaps in my knowledge. Uncharted 1 was a rough third-person shooter I didn't really enjoy, but Uncharted 2 fixed a lot of combat issues and had an excellent story that's on par with Uncharted 4. Uncharted 3's confusing plot (Talbot has powers how??) and messier combat (except being able to throw grenades back) failed to impress. After platinuming all these games (and Uncharted 4) I naturally became curious about Lost Legacy. Although I was initially skeptical (an Uncharted game without Nathan??) I took the plunge. Gradually, the absorbing writing, awe-inspiring exploration and magnificent chemistry between Chloe and Nadine really won me over. Lost Legacy is (sadly) a more compact game, but on the plus side, every puzzle and skirmish is carefully tailored so nothing feels overly drawn out. The APC fight on crushing is still extremely difficult yet satisfying; the darkness, rain and stealth elements make it one of the best encounters in the game. I wish there were more like it. After completing the game I noticed some bizarre glitches(??) where some environments turned into rainbow blocks with no bonus menu filters activated, although I now suspect this is a graphics/rendering issue specific to PC. Lost Legacy crashed once while Uncharted 4 had no crashes. Overall, I think both games perform more consistently on PS4 but the PC ports are great. Logic would dictate that the next reasonable step is to port Uncharted 1-3 onto PC.

Uncharted Legacy of thieves is as of November 22, 2022 a pretty phenomenal port of Uncharted 4 and The Lost legacy, with no bugs or crashes to report in my most recent play-through. Running maxed out at 1080p at 1.4x resolution in the in game settings on a 5800x, 32GB RAM, and RTX 3080 there was fairly consistent frames of around 90 up to 144 giving that smooth feeling that pc players love when playing shooters. 

As for the games themselves, they are the perfect blend of story, third person shooting and platforming that are as good in those three distinctive elements as they are all combined together. If you haven't played the original trilogy, I would still recommend picking this up even at the original price. 

I will mention that at launch there were issues for keyboard and mouse users, and after the first patch those were totally unusable without tweaking your peripheral sofware (G-Hub, iCUE etc). The second patch brought crashes and instability, and the third and fourth patches seem to have fixed everything though your mileage may vary. One gripe that I guess can't be fixed is the 126GB Storage requirement.

Sony has put "Uncharted: The Legend of Thieves Collection" which includes "Uncharted 4: A Thief's End" and "Uncharted: The Lost Legacy" on PC, and it is the same next-generation upgraded version as on PS5, obviously for Let more PC players feel the charm of Sony's first-party game "cinematic narrative". From this point of view, if "Uncharted: The Drake Collection" is ported to the PC platform first, the players' interest may not be so strong. For today's PC players, even though "Uncharted 4: A Thief's End" and "Uncharted: The Lost Legacy" are games from six or seven years ago, the experience is no better than the current popular 3A games. The game is inferior.

From the perspective of the actual screen, "Uncharted: The Legend of Thieves Collection" transplanted to the PC, compared with the PS4 version and the upgraded PS5 version, does not have much visual quality improvement that is visible to the naked eye. On the one hand, because of the quality performance of the original "Uncharted: A Thief's Legend Collection", even today it is still at the top level of the game industry; on the other hand, this transplant version has spent more energy on picture optimization And performance scheduling, to ensure that players can play this game with a lower configuration standard.

Compared with the alternation of generations on the screen, the gameplay of the "Uncharted" series has always been conservative - either climbing walls and fighting, or solving puzzles and watching performances. But "Uncharted 4: A Thief's End" and "Uncharted: The Lost Legacy" still bring some different elements to players. Such as the stealth battle in the grass, the semi-open box garden map level, and the application of new props such as claws and wall nails in different environments. Although it has not changed the original level design and gameplay of the "Uncharted" series in essence, it has indeed enriched the game experience in the game except for fighting and solving puzzles.

The story of "Uncharted 4: A Thief's End" takes place after "Uncharted 3: Drake's Deception", Nathan washes his hands and lives a happy life with Elena. But the long-lost brother Sam suddenly appeared, begging him to come out again to help him continue to search for the treasure of the famous pirate Avery. Drake, who is mixed between the two identities of brother and husband, once again embarked on a journey across mountains and mountains. At the same time, he has to face various problems brought about by his family and career, and find himself again.

A solid 7/10.

Good graphics, fun puzzles, amazing set pieces and some of the best facial animations.  The story is okay, but the adventure is akin to an action packed Indiana Jones movie.  I had never played an Uncharted prior to this and still enjoyed it and the characters without knowing any of their backstory.

So why isn't it a 10/10 for me?  The combat is annoying and quite bad.  You stick to cover too much, there were aiming issues, and the enemy type is not varied at all.  There are a couple boring chapters mixed in which almost caused me to quit.  Some of the dialogue is pretty cheesy.

Performance for me was rock solid.  Max settings, 2560x1080p at 75FPS on an XFX 6600.
Overall very good port. Game itself is extremely detailed and game play is butter smooth. Further optimization is needed though, currently the view movement cause alot of screen lags.

This is an amazing game but the performance is abysmal, I've been suffering from intermittent hitching throughout my entire playthrough that has persisted regardless of graphical settings, regardless of capped or uncapped frame rate, regardless of whether it's on an SSD or and HDD, regardless of GPU updates, and regardless of allowing the shaders to cache.  I think it has something to do with the port's absurd hunger for CPU bandwidth, but now that I've capped the frame rate to 60, my usage is hovering around 80% and it's still hitching, with none of my other system resources pushing the redline, so I just don't know at this point.  
I've genuinely tried everything I can think of and every solution I can find, but considering I can run virtually anything else on the market maxed without issue, including fellow PS port Spiderman Remastered, I think it's reasonable to blame the port at this stage, particularly given its other issues (the broken mouse aiming thing is the big one).
I don't know if it's just not playing nice with a 7700k or what - should be plenty of brawn despite its age but I've heard people with newer processors are having a better time.  Maybe it'll get patched.

Update: I've managed to get it running acceptably by moving the installation back to my SSD and maintaining the 60fps cap but it [i]still[/i] hitches on occasion when it's streaming in new sections of the level - I get that my rig is a few years out of date but a game this old should [i]not[/i] be running this poorly on a PC that can run anything else I throw at it.

Absolutely incredible game. I have just played through the first trilogy and can't believe how masterfully this was made. Being able to play it at 40 fps on my steam deck while still being beautiful to behold is an extra bonus. Gun play is very satisfying but a little less frequent than previous entries.

Weird-ish port of NaughtyDog's less problematic, less pretentious series. This game loves it's chromatic aberration for some reason, resulting in weird artifacting images. I'm sure with some configuration, you can get it looking good.

Glad to see more exclusive games come to PC, but I really wish they started with the other three games. Uncharted 4 is clearly the end of a storyline that's been built up for three games, and giving it to what could be a fresh new audience doesn't make a whole lot of sense. They only brought 4 + Lost Legacy over due to the graphical fidelity of those games, and while, yes, 1-3 are PS3 era games, they still hold up visually. Only putting 4 up because "gwafix" is valid, but also dumb, people with powerhouse PCs are still playing older games.

It's a shame, because Uncharted on a keyboard feels perfect. The other three games would be amazing on PC, and with the nature of the story, it'd benefit the new PC crowd who's jumping on.

If you're like me and missed out on the PS4 generation as a whole but also played the first three games, I'd recommend picking this up.

UNCHARTED™: Legacy of Thieves Collection contains the remastered versions of Uncharted 4: A Thief's End and Uncharted: The Lost Legacy. After having retired into a normal and quiet life, Nathan Drake finds himself at odds with destiny and is forced to embark on an epic globe-trotting journey to locate Henry Avery's lost treasure.

It is difficult to make good sequels, especially with story-driven games, but Naughty Dog was able to strike gold yet again. The story is very well put together, with an interesting narrative and filled with thrilling set-pieces. The characters are witty, the writing is solid, and the voice actors are outstanding.

While the core gameplay remains largely similar compared to the previous games, with a third-person perspective and a big focus on platforming and combat, some chapters are now open-ended, requiring you to drive a vehicle in order to explore them.

The graphics and animation quality are simply jaw-dropping, featuring some mesmerizing landscapes.

UNCHARTED™: Legacy of Thieves Collection is an amazing conclusion to a great franchise and the epitome of the action-adventure genre!

[h1]Great games, rough ports[/h1]

UNCHARTED™: Legacy of Thieves Collection is yet another Playstation exclusive package making its way on PC. Developed by Naughty Dog originally and brought to PC by well known player in the porting scene, Iron Galaxy Studios. The company is no stranger to both great ports and some poor ones, this collection sadly steers a bit to the latter. Some tweaking of drivers and in-game settings should provide sufficient results on most systems, though players should not have to resort to that in order to have an enjoyable experience.

[h2]Uncharted 4: A Thief's End[/h2]

The ending of Nathan Drake's story is a thrilling narrative and cinematic experience, sprinkled with the classic Uncharted action. The game features fan-favorite returning characters, as well as some newly introduced ones, which are a great addition to the overall narrative. It is one of the best games in the series, in my opinion, taking full advantage of the Playstation 4 hardware. The port might leave a sour taste in your mouth but the game itself definitely won't.

[b]Positives:[/b]
+ The search for Henry Avery's treasure and long lost utopia is one of the best stories in the franchise. It is not only a treasure hunt story but also one of complicated personal relationships between brothers. The newly introduced characters provide a fresh layer of depth to the narrative, while still keeping in line with the past events of the previous four games. Returning ones are as great as they were in all previous titles. It is a satisfying end to Nathan's journey.
+ A true cinematic experience on all fronts. Like most games of this genre, it is a rather linear and scripted experience full of amazing moments. Some might view this as a negative but I feel like it is an important part of the franchise and key to the whole cinematic style, after all this is not an open-world game.
+ Truly beautiful game and a strong showcase of the Playstation 4's capabilities back in 2016. These PC ports are based on the Playstation 5 remasters but the original version of Uncharted 4 still looks good even today. It was especially noticeable when compared to the previous 3 games released on the Playstation 3 and the prequel Golden Abyss, released on the Playstation Vita.
+ Stellar soundtrack composed by newcomer to the series, Henry Jackman.
+ Solid performance capture by Nolan North, Troy Baker and the rest of the wonderful cast.

[b]Negatives:[/b]
- One obvious negative is the fact that this is the 5th game in the franchise and the only Nathan Drake adventure available on PC. This puts new players who want to get into the world of Uncharted in an awkward spot as they cannot start from the beginning if PC is their only platform. In order to experience the first 3 games you need to own either a Playstation 3 or a Playstation 4, as far as the prequel goes you need to own a Playstation Vita. Naughty Dog's explanation is that players can easily get into Uncharted 4's story without prior knowledge of the previous games. It is true that this game has a decent beginning and end, making it possible to stand on its own but I still feel like playing the previous games is very much required as there are just some characters who will have much more depth if you have prior knowledge. Starting with the final game of a series is simply not a good idea and this is likely the biggest negative regarding the collection.
- Generally a rough port compared to all other Playstation exclusives we have received on PC so far. Stuttering problems, frame drops and mouse issues all paint a negative picture. I am not running the latest in PC hardware but Marvel's Spider-Man which is slightly newer than both these games ran much better. Support has also been lacking with only 3 patches to date. The first patch completely broke mouse sensitivity and it took the developers over 5 days to release a second patch addressing the problem. During those 5 days there was also no communication or acknowledgement of the issue whatsoever, players were waiting in the dark for an update.
- Gun combat is really frustrating and hard to do on a mouse. Enemies constantly twitch around causing you to miss a shot. This might just be me being bad but it felt really annoying at times.

[b]Overall:[/b]
Uncharted 4: A Thief's End is huge hit in terms of narrative, graphics and cinematic moments. Playing the original game or even the same remaster on Playstation consoles is absolutely recommended. PC on the other hand is a different story. The fact that you are forced to start with the final game in the series, have to suffer through multiple technical issues and deal with the developers' lack of communication and support make this not worth the buy. If I have to be consistent and give a rating it would basically be a [b]7.5/10[/b]. A [b]9[/b] for the game itself and a [b]6[/b] for the port to keep it simple.

[h2]Uncharted: The Lost Legacy[/h2]

[b]Many negative and some positive points in regards to the technical aspects of Uncharted 4 also apply to the Lost Legacy expansion since they are both part of the same package and are basically the same ports under the hood.[/b]

[b]Positives:[/b]
+ Compact and thrilling story that takes just about 7 hours to complete. While there are characters from Uncharted 4 appearing here this is definitely a standalone story and it has its own set of new figures. It does a fantastic job at being its own thing despite some familiar faces.
+ Chloe Frazer finally gets her own game. Despite being a long-running character in the series this is her debut as a main protagonist. Even for its relatively short time, the expansion manages to provide decent development of her character arc and keep her interesting even with Nathan's absence from her life.
+ The final chapter of The Lost Legacy is my favorite part of the collection. Full of action and great cinematic moments. Overall much better than the final chapter of Uncharted 4. It is one of my favorite final missions in the whole franchise.
+ Another stellar soundtrack composed by Henry Jackman.

[b]Negatives:[/b]
- More frame drops in this game compared to Uncharted 4. I have no idea if this is only the case with me or if it's a universal thing.

[b]Overall:[/b]
Uncharted: The Lost Legacy is a solid expansion and another decent entry in the series. Absolutely recommended if you play on a console and not PC. The PC version is not worth buying due to the exact same reasons as the other game and the score of [b]7.5/10[/b] also applies here.

[h1]Final Verdict[/h1]
UNCHARTED™: Legacy of Thieves Collection is the first Playstation port I cannot recommend. Multiple technical issues and poor business decisions led to the downfall of this collection and I hope Naughty Dog and Sony realize this and do better in the future. It is the worst-selling port to date and seeing the state of it, it is no surprise at all. Such a shame as these games are absolutely worth playing and this was a golden opportunity to introduce PC players to the franchise properly. I really hope The Last of Us Part I and II will be handled with much more care and passion.

A Thief's End is the single best send-off to a beloved a series I've ever played, and yet it somehow also serves as the perfect stepping stone into the Uncharted series for any person who hasn't played the first three games, to get to know these iconic characters and all of their many complicated facets.

Both my siblings were interested in playing Uncharted 4 but were worried because they hadn't played the first three games. Still, I encouraged them to try it- it genuinely doesn't require knowing every bit of lore from the first three games, it explains when and where context is necessary. After beating Uncharted 4, both siblings ended up seeking out the first three games, as well, because they ended up enjoying the characters so much.

In terms of Cinematography, the game is unparalleled. It really does feel like you're watching a movie a lot of the time, and the accessibility settings the game includes are intuitive enough to help a wide audience of people with different ranges of motion and abilities to still experience this incredible story.

The Lost Legacy is a perfect compliment for fans of the first three games, and fans of A Thief's End, incorporating characters from both to create a wonderful new blend of character interaction that adds a lot of depth to characters that longtime fans already adored.

If you're on the fence, I'd really recommend giving the series a try. It's one of my favorites.

As someone who played the first three games on PS, I never really liked the direction they took in Uncharted 4, supposedly the last entry in Nathan Drake's story, by focusing on the relationship with a new character instead of the already beloved dynamic between Nate, Elena and Sully. I really wanted to spend more time with them in what's meant to be the last "main" game. I was also not keen on having ANOTHER pirate-themed adventure after how awesome Ubar and especially Shambala was. But I gotta admit that even in 2022, Uncharted 4 is a top-tier cinematic experience with incredible acting and enjoyable, if somewhat unremarkable, gameplay. The villain, as usual with the Uncharted games, is pretty forgettable but the spectacles and set-pieces were incredible while being, dare I say, bordering on the absurd. All in all, it works.

I think I might have enjoyed the laser focused story, the in-deep exploration of South India and the new dynamic between Chloe and Nadine in The Lost Legacy more actually. As I said, I was never really infatuated with the direction of the story in Uncharted 4 so playing as a different character and buddying up with a former antagonist was more rewarding than I expected.

However, I'm baffled that Sony didn't choose to port over the first 3 Uncharted games. Those games, and especially Among Thieves, is what's most fondly remembered by the fans IMO and it seems pretty strange that they chose to have the finale and a side plot be the main entry point for the PC community. Also, I genuinely dislike the collectibles in this game. They're numerous, tedious to gather and offer very little in the way of knowledge, satisfaction or amusement. The achievements are a pain too. The port isn't super great either with lots of "building shaders" and microstutters. Frankly, I'm shocked that companies still hire Iron Galaxy after their disastrous Arkham Knight port. In any case, I'm still pretty happy that Sony is continuing this trend of PC ports and I'll keep supporting it for as long as it continues.

Classic PS4 exclusive that has been ported to the PC. "Uncharted" follows the Tomb Raider / Indiana Jones formula and does it well. Even 6 years after release the graphics remain impressive and the core gameplay is solid. You climb around cool places, solve the occasional puzzle and engage in some gunplay.

The story is standard genre stuff with lost cities and clues strewn around the world. To make things more interesting the devs give you three different sidekicks to do character development with. The sidekicks also serve to create conflict for the protagonist in that he has to choose between competing loyalties.

The game's production values are through the roof and every set-piece and location looks spectacular. The game is probably as fun to watch as it is to play.

The weaknesses are a kind of muddled combat and cutscenes overload to the point where the game sometimes feels like an interactive movie. Though I guess that's the point.

While Sony is doing ports maybe they can also port Uncharted 2&3 and Shadow of the Colossus, would be great. As for Uncharted 4, it's pretty good, 9/10 thanks for porting.

Nice to finally check out these lauded Sony first-party games. Great story, gorgeous visuals, a few interesting (but relatively simplistic) puzzles, and a whole lot of repetition. Cut scene, follow the path, "oh look bad guys", shoot bad guys, need to climb but can't quite reach, move a crate so you can jump up, next cut scene, follow path, more (identical) bad guys, need to climb but can't quite reach, move an (identical) crate so you can jump up, rinse and repeat. Plot holes abound as well, as you find some key item/detail that means only you should know how to get to the next secret place, only to find it full of bad guys who somehow, miraculously got there first without any of the insight you have obtained. It's Tomb Raider with a (slightly) better story, but more linear and with fewer things to do. Definitely enjoyed it, but walked away wanting for more interesting gameplay.

This is a PC port from a playstation console creation.  A successful port adapts the game to the native operating environment.  

After the recent patch, the native controls for this port (keyboard and mouse aka kb&m) are totally wrecked.  i have seen several people complain about the kb&m only to get the flamed response: "getta controller!"  that would an appropriate response if we were playing on a playstation console.  but we are not; i am not.  the native controls for a pc are mouse and keyboard.  the game must acknowledge them correctly for the game to succeed.  the controls were correct the previous patch; it is a shame they are taking so long to correct this gross error.    

while this game was fun before the latest patch, this was not the best port.    mouse tracking/ gyro scope issues since launch in specific instances.  I also noticed strange consistent non-significant graphical errors (like gumby limbs).

i would mention the selling points of the game, but the current state the game is unplayable.  i am disappointed, i had higher expectation than this.  

do not buy until issue is addressed.

[h1]Steam Deck[/h1]
[hr][/hr]
Works out of box on the Steam Deck at about 45-50FPS with locking it to 28-30FPS with the hard/in-game "30FPS cap" is pretty impressive. What isn't impressive, is the heat output. It's really worrying how hot the Deck gets. It's a good sign that the game runs on Linux (given... the PS4 and PS5 are FreeBSD/Unix based like Linux is), but I wouldn't recommend playing it on the Deck unless you make some fan changes in the menus because the default/post-fan speed update that Valve made defaults aren't enough [for me personally] to be comfortable running the game on the Deck hardware for extended periods of times.
[hr][/hr]

[h1]The Desktop Experience/actual gaming PC[/h1]

125Gigs with about 69Gigs of "Junk" (read: Other language audio/subtitle files you may never use) files. Then throw in Naughty Dog's PS3-4-5 era Blu-ray Disc streaming tech that they have to use on consoles for the ability to load things faster than the disc drive via the hard-drive.

...Which also asks for more drive-space than the minimum recommends... ...Which wants to stream from another drive than the drive that the game is installed on...

...Which also has a RAM problem (probably due to Iron Galaxy?) that will cause your OS to chug or the game to soft-lock/hard-lock and crash eventually...

Besides that, the port (when it runs well for me) is "great." I went through the campaigns and enjoyed them, despite the frame-dips and loading-tech getting in the way of cutscenes and gameplay at times.

Iron Galaxy is apparently infamous for poor PC ports. I only know them for [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/244730/Divekick/]Memekick[/url] and [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/577940/Killer_Instinct/]Killer Instinct X-box[/url] which are alright ports. This one is "servicable" but the issues right now (and no patches in the ~1-2 weeks from launch) really doesn't inspire confidence in me to recommend the game to anyone but the hardcore series fans (like me) who don't own a PS4 (like me) that want to play this entry/finale to the series.

[hr][/hr]

[h1]The game itself[/h1]
[hr][/hr]
Gentle reminder that Uncharted 4 is [url=https://imgur.com/gallery/xcA0Y]Amy Hennig's baby[/url] and she was working on it and trying to do gameplay changes from the PS3 era Uncharted entries before Neil Druckmann pushed her out.

With that said, bar the obvious Druckmann-isms from the Last of Us being put into the Uncharted series (the stealth system in Uncharted 3 which was only for like 1-2 scenes is expanded here and made the main focus like it was for the Last of Us. Blech. The less said about U4 Nadine the better in terms of wasted character slots.), the game is a "good" (not GREAT, just good) entry and finale for the series from a studio that generally does not count past 3 (unlike Valve which does not count past 2) and generally makes a kart racing game for the I.P. they're retiring (UnKarted when, ND?).

I enjoyed the game... HOWEVER, veterans thinking of going into Crushing vanilla and first playthrough: DON'T. Worst mistake of my life (Chapter 18 finale, Chapter 20 opening, infamous examples here) and the Crushing difficulty is based around using Cheats [which you get for collectibles gained and beating the game] like infinite ammo (which gets around Crushings quarter-half ammo on pick up gains) and slow motion (for helping with armored enemies, and tight areas) to beat the game and get the achievement(s) tied to that.

Which is funny and a point that Neil Druckmann doesn't get the series: Because while U1-3 had certain tough areas, they weren't hard to beat on Crushing given you could have "kill boxes" and obvious "this is going to be a fight area" triggers on the journey to prepare yourself for.

U4? As soon as you hear "SHORELINE!!!!" on Crushing you're like "Oh, god, why..." because the game grinds to a halt (without the cheats) due to it forcing you to use Stealth or be beaten by reinforcement numbers eventually or getting frustrated by the AI  partner[s] getting in your way of cover and battling the enemies during these segments.

Is it beatable "vanilla"/no cheats? Absolutely, I did it. BUT I DON'T RECOMMEND IT.
[hr][/hr]
Lost Legacy was better. Crushing could get a little trouble-y (the Chapter 8 boss, notable) at points, but not to the point where battles were like "OH GOD, PLEASE NO MORE COMBAT. THIS IS TERRIBLE!" and the story is generally better and more engaging and "Uncharted"-Hennig feeling than Druckmann [taking cues from Hennig's planned 4 story beats but kind of ruining them] did. Whoever was the directors of Lost Legacy need to be promoted because they had a more enjoyable adventure and length and pacing feel than U4 did.

PLUS, they made Nadine slightly more likeable and at least not a total worthless addition to the story by having her tag along with Chloe though be prepared for a lot of "JA!!"ing from Nadine.

It's final segment is one of Uncharted 2's on steroids. I loved it.

So: U4? Pass beyond seeing what Hennig was trying to do and wish she could've stuck the landing better. LL: Absolutely worth going through and hoping ND promoted these dude/ttes to leads to further the series.
