I wanted to write a short Review for this Game because I consider it important for the future of Playstation Titles that are coming to PC.
Many people were not happy that the Legacy of Thieves Collection was released before we got the Chance to play through Uncharted 1-3 and I can totally understand that.
I myself usually don't want to play a Sequel when I didn't have the Chance to play the prequels that came before.
But after playing Uncharted: Legacy of Thieves Collection I am just glad that I got to experience the 2 Games included (A Thiefs End - basically Uncharted 4 - and the Standalone DLC The Lost Legacy).

Also I saw many people complaining about the pricing because those Games are a few years old. Let me just say for the amount of Game Time and Quality of the Game, the pricing is more than fair and even worth buying without waiting for a sale.

I try to keep the Review Short.

The Game looks absolutely stunning, amazing and georgeous and also it runs really well on my PC.
i5-9600K / RTX 2060 Super / 16GB RAM and I could play on Ultra 1080p with only a few minor drops to 48fps in a few areas.
I got no problems with microstuttering or whatever other problems some people describe. That's not to say that those problems don't exist for some, we are talking about PC Gaming here anyway. Differs from setup to setup. 
Overall I'd say this is a great PC Port. Minor gripe from my side is that sometimes the "Building Shaders" in the menu took too long. Also be aware of a few bugs and glitches, but it was nothing Gamebreaking.
In Cutscenes more than once I had characters warping in and out or just weirdly T-posing and also I had to die a few times to reset the checkpoint, because I broke a sequence and the Game wouldn't let me progress.

The Sound is very good, the Voice Acting is awesome, the story is very entertaining (you actually root for most of the characters and feel for them, even though you may not have played the previous Games like myself), the setpieces are gorgeous and bombastic at times, same goes for the action (think Call of Duty Campaigns and equally or sometimes even more memorable), so yes, it is worth it.

Control wise as of the time writing this, they have made the Mouse issues worse, but I played with a XBox1 Controller anyways (even though I still have problems aiming with a controller, but it got better over time...).

I really do hope that Sony will not someday stop porting over great PS Games to the PC only because this Game was the least selling Game for them.

My Verdict: Great Game, give it a shot even though you didn't play 1-3. Maybe in the future we get a chance for that...There is a lot to play and like here.

I recommend this, since I enjoy the Uncharted franchise. This "review" focuses mostly on somewhat negative aspects, so if you're on the fence you'll know if this helped with your decision.

If I had to score it - I would give it a 8-9 out of 10 for the story and characters, 8 for world building, 6 for gunplay, 7 for sound and 5 for the PC port. The story is great, characters are done pretty well. Action sequences are unmached (although silly). Gunplay is meh - enemies are aimbots on higher difficulties and it takes quite some time to get a headshot from a distance. Getting hit makes the camera go crazy and aiming is really difficult (wish it was the same for enemies, but nope - aimbot no matter what). There are quite a few achievements you can sink a lot of time in. Just finished the game on the hardest difficulty available (there's one more that unlocked) and that took 20 hours with almost all collectables.

There are some technical issues (honestly, wish the same people that ported God of War ported this game). Long load times, models not loading, T posing, broken mouse aim, audio glitching here and there, audio lower volume during cinematics and a bunch more. Due to the slow load times, the game sometimes shows a scene that you wouldn't normally see (like a bunch of enemies gathered in the air) while it loads, or the whole level goes dark with T posing people - it's funny.

Keep in mind, that this game just released, and is bound to get a few patches to iron out some bugs.

A small rant below...

At times, the way the world is built doesn't make sense (caves mostly). The way rocks are formed just makes it jarring when looking at them... It's almost as the devs built it not so you can look at it, but rather be passable to... pass through it and not be that boring. There were quite a few places where you could see through the map, purple missing textures, models floating - things you would expect to see only in an unpolished game. I don't remember having this many issues in my first playthrough back in 2016. Oh that Nate sure is made out of some sturdy stuff. I mean - he constantly falls from great heights, gets shot, [spoiler]survives weather that is sure to give you pneumonia at the least and a really bad blow to the head[/spoiler]. Talk about suspension of disbelief sheesh. But hey - it's a game and I love it.

Anyway - if you like games like Tomb Raider, you'll like this one as well.

I was interested in Uncharted 4 ever since it first came out, however I was a PC and Xbox guy so I was never fortunate enough to give the Playstation exclusives a try. When this popped up on my radar, I was obviously very surprised that Sony is beginning to bring its exclusives to PC.

However after running through the first 10 chapters of Uncharted 4, I can honestly say that I am quite disappointed, and am perplexed as to why it is such a well reviewed game.

Dont get me wrong, the game is very high quality. It is beautiful, the mechanisms are generally very smooth, there are incredible small details like the way a rope will wrap around trees that adds a lot of immersion to the game. The voice acting is great and the writing is pretty good as well, the story is decent as well.

But something about it just doesnt keep me interested, it all feels so ... cliche?

The gameplay is quite simple, the pacing feels a bit slow and inconsistent, the mechanics get old quite quickly, the story is just decent - it feels like I will forget this 1 week after I finish the game.

If I could summarise it I would basically call it the video game equivalent of one of the recent Star Wars movies. Good quality, technically, obviously big budget, good for a run-through, but ultimately forgettable.

I give it overall a 7/10

Story - 6/10 (decent story for a game, ultimately forgettable)

Gameplay - 7/10 (nothing too innovative)

Writing - 6/10 (one thing that really bothered me is the way Sam and Nathan casually joke repeatedly after killing literally hundreds of people)

Graphics - 8/10 (quite pretty, even for an older game)

World/atmosphere - 9/10 (I think this is done very well)

I used to have a Playstation and I was able to play the first 3 games on release and absolutely loved them. I haven't had a Playstation since the fourth one game out and I was so excited when I found out this game was coming to steam. When writing this I have only played A Thief's End and I don't know if the other has similar/more issues, so keep that in mind. 

FOR ME, the game ran great. I have a 1080, and the game was able to hold constant 60+ fps for the entire game. I could count on 1 hand the amount of time I had less than 60 and those times were very brief (less than 5 seconds). Crashing happened but wasn't an issue. The game auto saves very frequently and the only time crashing would occur was after tabbing out of the game. Still infrequent and only happened about 5 times. The final issue I experienced was during rendered cut scenes. During the rendered cut scenes, character models would occasionally morph into another position and almost instantly revert back to what it is suppose to be. To me this is very minor and sometimes funny, but to others it might be a little immersion breaking and annoying. The worst case of this happening was actually in the final chapter of the game, and this happened. Not only the character model bugging out, but the big baddie of the game had their entire dialogue cut out. The subtitles didn't appear either. This was fixed by opening the menu and replaying the cinematic. I found it odd that the pre rendered cut scenes were the ones to be buggy and not the in game engine cut scenes, but I also had a similar thing happen to me in Spider-man Remastered.

If you have played the first three games then I can easily recommend this game. It does a great job of wrapping up the story and it is very fun. 

MAYBE SPOILER (IDK): If you have played the other 3 games or even the Tomb Raider games you would know there always seems to be some super natural thing/people and the end of the games. I went on the last 4ish chapters waited for something super natural to happen (several times I felt it was teased something super natural was going on) and it never happened. I'm not saying this is bad, but the fact it wasn't simply threw me off a bit. Seeing that this is the conclusion and a purely character driven story (as far as motivations go), I feel adding something super natural would have been worst for the story and ending.

Strangely enough, The Lost Legacy expansion is a far better game than Uncharted 4 is. Pacing was spot on, and the almost claustrophobic linearity of the 4th game was fixed with a very well implemented hub world with unordered objectives and even an optional side-mission. Climbing and shooting sequences are delivered in just the right proportions, whereas the 4th game often uses these sequences as padding for what would otherwise be a fairly short game. The 4th game has an edge in terms of the writing and story, but they seem to have focused more on the dramatic cutscenes than the gameplay for some reason. Mind you, It's still well worth playing both.

I am tempted to call this a masterpiece. In my opinion this is undoubtedly the best Uncharted game in the series not just because of the superior graphics but also the story and gameplay. I may be biased because this was the first game I played in the series but I have now also completed the second and third games and while impressive for being on the PS3, they do not come close to rivaling Uncharted 4.

This game has larger areas than previous uncharted games. There is a lot to explore and with the stunning locations and attention to detail, this is a joy. There are notes to be found throughout the game which expand the world and present stories outside of the main story. The gameplay also benefits from the larger areas and allows for multiple paths to reach the same end goal. The areas are also more three dimensional and the grapple hook is a welcome addition. 

Most importantly I had the most fun playing this game hands down. The addition of the alert indicator on enemies and being able to mark enemies makes stealth a very viable and fun option in a lot of areas and is very satisfying to pull off. The guns feel much better in this game compared to the previous games and the controls feel very natural and easy. 

The story is both thrilling and heartfelt, the characters feel very real and everyone's motivations are clear. These are all lovable characters. The main villain isn't overly macho and "villainy" and even his motivations also provoke some sympathy. There is good female representation here as well. The dialogue throughout the game is witty and fun.

The pacing of the game is great. A good balance between exploring, climbing and encounters with enemies. The puzzles are quite simple and straight forward but feel fun. There are some epic set pieces but that are still grounded in reality. Some sequences really makes this feel like playing a very good action/adventure film. The "supernatural" element was left out of this game, which I thought was a welcome choice. There is more focus on character development instead. The story felt more realistic but at the same time extraordinary. 

The music is great. A mixture of epic orchestral music but also some tender emotional moments as well. 

Acting, voice acting all superb and natural. 

From beginning to end this is an absolute joy to play. A truly epic adventure with a very satisfying ending. Would highly recommend this to anyone!

Lastly I would like to thank Naughty Dog studios & Playstation Studios for letting us enjoy this hell of a gem in pc & i have to say that waiting 6 years for this masterpiece was really worth it to every last bit of my money, I hope Naughty Dog brings Last of Us 1 & 2 to PC as soon as possible because after playing this my hype has been doubled for that games !!

I'll review the game and the port as separates, but overall I recommend this port and game.

The Port: It's good enough, there are performance issues in some parts, specially loading the cutscenes causing T-posing and dissapearing hair at times, luckily there's a "restart cutscene" option on the menu that you can use to restart it without issues. The performance issues I found mostly on the "Lost Legacy" game, more exactly during the late hours of the play through in a certain temple the frame rate started to become unstable, but outside of that it was always pretty stable and smooth. Overall, this is not the best possible port but is playable to an acceptable degree, meaning that there are no major issues with it, only small ones that don't ruin the experience.

The game: It's freaking good. It lasts enough to avoid getting old and avoid being too short. I'd say it's the perfect length and has a really good pacing, no chapter overstays its welcome and the ending is really good (for both games in the collection). My only issue is with the mission design in the last chapters of both games, were there are chapters that either change your perspective (camera) or simply require too much of a good timing and lead to repeated deaths because the game wants you to do things a way and ONLY that way; I'm my opinion that's a rookie mistake that almost ruins the experience... it doesn't matter how good an ending is, if you have to start repeating it over and over again because there's this part that might as well be a quick-time event due to it's timing but terribly implemented... well, you get the idea. Still, I said "almost" because it's doesn't get that bad, but it's enough to be annoying. Still, amazing ending on both games.

TL;DR:
Games: 9/10
-> Characters: 10/10
-> Story: 9/10
-> Execution: 9/10
-> Mission Design: 8/10
Port: 8/10
-> Graphics: 9/10 (rain looks freaking bad)
-> Performance: 7/10

Both games exceeded my expectations. Good stuff!

Uncharted 4 has a really cool pirate story with excellent character writing and character arcs. The gameplay is honestly nothing special, your regular 3rd-person cover shooter, but it has been refined and is much better than in UC 1, UC2, or UC3.

Nathan Drake has his journal as always, and it's always cool to check it every once in a while for hints or cool commentary and scribbles.

Uncharted 4 actually has a cool villain; someone who has something to prove, is a psychopath, but also gives the protagonists plenty of leeway to back off, which is kinda cool.

The animation detail is top notch, one really cool thing I noticed is that if you point your flashlight, they either turn their head, squint a bit, or use their hand to screen themselves from the light. Lost Legacy has even more detailed animations.

Another cool thing I loved is that stealth worked against heavy/armored enemies, but had more steps, which is nice for a full stealth run!

Now for the bad:

The collectibles are downright garbage in comparison to the recent Tomb Raider trilogy. Uninspired vases or jewelry that barely connects to the story or setting at hand, with no description or commentary from the protagonist. Major missed opportunity. They do seem to unlock cheats, skins, and gameplay modes after finishing the game.

The linearity of the game can sometimes be jarring; you can clearly see the right way to go, but you need to go to somewhere else to trigger a dumb cutscene and then you'll be able to go the right way.

I wish there was at least a limited us of silencers in the game, however, you do find a silenced gun in Lost Legacy that you can use in a couple of encounters.

All in all, this collection is a fun romp and I would recommend the game to anyone interested in it or similar games, however, I wish more was done in terms of collectibles, especially since there's no Multiplayer in the PC version in which you would be able to show off your skins.

Ok, I bought this game cuz i had heard a lot about my friends who have playstation and wanted to just experience it . Well its graphics is good for an old game but story wise this game is a masterpiece.

Oooook.  Time to evaluate this game eh?. 

First off PC performance. 

I run a Amd 5800X- 32GB 4200mhz ram- RTX 3080 10GB OG version- 2TB m2 ssd and a LG C2 42 inch OLED tv. 

Every setting @ultra + enhanced models + DLSS@balanced in 4K.  Through both games this has given me anything from 70 fps- 120 fps (max of the screen) Depending on outside/inside maps and how much is going on and i would say this game delivers like a baws concidering my hardware.  

No hickups, no bugs, no crashes and no nothing in a total playtime of 29 hours.  

Now over to both games themselves. 

I have earlier enjoyed uncharted on playstation but i never got 4 or 5.  Last one i had was a chipped 3 :P 

I have so long waited to yet again get to enjoy the uncharted series with sweet performance, HDR and 4k in 60 FPS +++++.  This has been a wild ride!  I had no pre knowledge about the story in either of these two games on purpose since i wanted to get a completely fresh playthrough without having any knowledge. 

Yet again Naughty dog delivers the high quality superb gaming they always have.  I loved the stories in both games although the 2nd one with Chloe and Nadine is quite a bit shorter (about 50% timewise).  

Great writing , fantastic action, gameplay itself is snappy and just works.  I like that you can adjust your own experience regarding difficulty and if you still want to play with a controller.  I have for the last 10 years been an avid PC gamer exclusively on mouse and keyboard but actually in these two games i had a blast using a controller through the whole thing. 

Took me 29 hours to complete both games (and yes i did ofc miss pickups here and there) But i like playing these for the story, banter and the fun between all the characters.  

I have loved all the tomb raider games all the way back to the OG playstation but uncharted...man there is just something special about Drake and Sully in particular.  

I higly recommend this game for anyone finally getting to play this on PC and crank the graphics up to the max and have a fantastic time exploring wonderful worlds.  

i do not rate anything in different categories but for me this game pack is an absolute solid 9/10. 
Much of that comes from nostalgia from the very first game and that i think drake is a cool puppy but also a flawless game totally bugfree with good graphics and gameplay.

UNCHARTED™: Legacy of Thieves Collection:
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 

Treasure hunters, are you ready? Because it’s time to step into the shoes of two accomplished fortune seekers. Some people call them thieves, but the terminology is totally up to you. Regardless, the two adventures you are about to experience will grab you from the start to finish. So, what are you waiting for? Pack your explorer gears, and don’t forget your gun and rope, as you will need them through both adventures of UNCHARTED™: Legacy of Thieves Collection.

UNCHARTED™: Legacy of Thieves Collection combines two single-player action-adventure games developed by Naughty Dog LLC and published by PlayStation PC LLC on the 20th of October 2022 on the Steam platform. 

I have always been tempted to play the UNCHARTED™ game series, but as a true PC gamer, I never got around to playing them as I don’t own a PlayStation (yes, I know it is odd, but there you go). I was delighted when the news of UNCHARTED™: Legacy of Thieves Collection was coming out on PC, and I couldn’t wait to play both games in the collection. After all, I had waited six years to play UNCHARTED 4: A Thief’s End (released on PlayStation in 2016) and the stand-alone expansion UNCHARTED: The Lost Legacy, which was released in 2017. So, will it be the end of the PlayStation exclusive, I wonder? In the last couple of years, several games were ported onto PC for our pleasure, and the ones I played were exquisite. So, what do I think about UNCHARTED™: Legacy of Thieves Collection?

In a nutshell, I was blown away and played both games from beginning to end within 25 hours. Naughty Dogs have managed to balance all aspects of these games. The stories are well-structured and compelling, with great dialogues, and the voice-overs are top-notch. You’ll laugh, be intrigued, and be on edge on several occasions provided by great cutscenes. Then you have amazing gameplay as you discover mind-blowing locations; the graphics are really good. There are plenty of collectables to find, which are pretty well hidden within the landscape, and they will only show as a small sparkling light as you walk or run by them. You’ll also climb a lot and use your rope a fair bit to access new spots within each chapter. Stealth is a big aspect of the games, as you’ll meet plenty of enemies in every chapter, and it will be totally up to you to sneak up behind and eliminate them without making too much noise. My favourite takedown is pulling them down while my character is hanging on the edge of a cliff, wall, or window. Or you can go in all guns blazing and have epic gun battles. There are plenty of guns and explosives to pick up along the way, which can be found on or in crates, and also when enemies have been killed as they will no longer need their weapons. You’ll experience wild escapes on foot and in vehicles too. The action in these games is brilliant, and when you will face the baddies at the end of the game it will be a spectacular fight. In addition, you have the puzzles aspect of the game.  There are several of them; they are not too difficult to complete, but just enough to make you think a bit. 

There are some issues, though, mainly graphical. However, I did experience a crash to my desktop while playing The Lost Legacy. The most frequent one was when my character jumped towards an edge at certain angles; one arm looked totally dislocated (it actually was funny when it happened). Amongst some minor glitches, the worst issue was the pixelation of one of the character’s faces, which was just odd. 

Despite these small issues, the graphics are fabulous. The story is well-structured, with great dialogues and voice-overs. I thoroughly enjoyed my time playing both games. You can play with your mouse and keyboard or with a gamepad. I waited six years to finish both of the games within 25 hours! Bugger, give me more treasure hunts!

Positives:
~~~~~~~ 
+	Great graphics with beautiful landscapes
+	Entertaining story with great dialogues and voice-overs
+	Good combat system
+	Good puzzles
+	Full controller support
+	 Achievements

Negatives:
~~~~~~~~ 

-	Several graphic issues
-	No trading cards as yet

UNCHARTED™: Legacy of Thieves Collection is truly a treasure to play on PC.

9/10

First time into Uncharted waters.

As an Xbox and PC gamer, I've never had the opportunity to play the Uncharted series until now. Boy, was I missing out! Uncharted 4 has incredible visuals, voice acting, writing, and overall game play. The game makes you think, challenging you to find new ways around enemies and traversal around the beautiful landscapes. Although this isn't "open world", there are many wide open spaces to explore on foot or by vehicle - all while sneakily pushing you to the main objective. 

There are deserts, mountains, forests, oceans and even a high class mansion or two to explore and fight in with an NPC "buddy" or even by yourself. The difficulty of the AI that you fight can be challenging if you don't play smart, even on the "moderate" setting. There is good variety in AI from pistol henchmen to rocket launcher wielding foes - yes, you can pick up that RPG-7 that dude dropped.

When finishing the main storyline (which took me about 15 hours), you unlock a "bonus" category to sort through weapons and give yourself at any moment. Also fun render options like turning the game into a rainbow patterned world, sepia toned or even giving yourself "bullet time" abilities and unlimited ammo. This was great to go back to your favorite chapters and activate silly bonus features to mess around with.

All in all, Uncharted 4 is a great PC version that runs fairly well on my system - 3060Ti, Ryzen 7 3700x, 32GB RAM Averaging about 90-110 frames on Ultra settings with DLSS turned on. Highly recommend to anyone wanting a fantastic story line with characters to become attached to - Especially the protagonist Nathan Drake.

Both "Uncharted" games in this collection bring back traditional nostalgia, which I had experienced with "Uncharted 1, 2, and 3" on PlayStation 3.  I am glad that Sony has given us (the PC owners) the ability to experience the fourth title and the expansion on our computers.  (This was my first time playing "Uncharted:  A Thief's End" and "Uncharted:  The Lost Legacy.")  There were no issues with game performance (I waited for the shaders to download before playing on several occasions, but that only took a few minutes each time).  Both titles ran 80-100 FPS on Ultra Settings with Intel Core i5 9600K and nVidia RTX 2060 Super 8GB, and the visuals looked stunning on a 2K 240hz G-Sync monitor.  

These games are perfect examples of what single-player games should be and require no additional software or memberships.  I really wish that more contemporary games would follow this suit.  As other reviewers have commented, it would be nice to experience the previous Uncharted games on the PC as a full Uncharted collection, but I am happy to have this game in my Steam Library along with other critically acclaimed games, such as "God of War" and "Horizon:  Zero Dawn."  I hope that Sony brings other famous titles to the PC platform.  Thank you.

This game is as close to being in a movie as a game can get and still be a game.  The script and acting is very good although a little predictable and occasionally the players make odd and somewhat illogical choices that you have no choice but to accept and move on.  

In terms of gameplay it is a combination of climbing parkour that has you jumping, climbing and swinging on ropes around old crumbling structures. It can strongly induce feelings of anxiety or vertigo as things are often sickeningly high and fall apart when you touch them. There is also a fair amount of first person shooter action which can be ramped up or toned down depending on how much you like that style of game.  Its pretty well done though and there is a large variety of weapon types that are fairly fun to use ranging from grenade launchers to silenced pistols. 

Nearly everything you do is mostly intuitive such as swimming under water, swinging on ropes, climbing etc.  The game does occasionally, however, insist on forcing a certain view angle as part of a sequence. For example, there is a sequence where you get chased by a vehicle and the game puts the camera in front of you watching them as they chase you.  It looks nice but requires you to reverse your controls with forward being backward and vice versa.  Its terribly disorienting and I died quite a few times trying to get it right although I did eventually figure it out. This only happened rarely and seemed to simply be a means of increasing your anxiety while giving a more cinematic view of the action.

Not everything is completely perfect, however, and there were a few things I did not care for although they weren't enough to ruin my enjoyment or recommendation as a good game.  

First, although the game appears to be an open world adventure this is not truly the case a lot of the time. There are many sequences where you chase someone (or are being chased) and it seems as if you are choosing where to drive, run etc.  You eventually realize though there is only one choice most of the time and if you choose wrong you will die. They simply conceal it and make the correct choice or path seem logical and appealing. Not a huge deal but if you are expecting a true open world to explore that isnt what this is.

Second, there are absolutely no dialogue choices.  When you interact with people you do so precisely as it is scripted. You cannot make any choices regarding who you talk to or what you say.  The game will even put a prompt up when it wants you to speak to someone.  As I previously said, some of the choices are a little questionable and make no sense but as long as you remember its more like a movie than an open world rpg its still entertaining and fun. Plus the acting is really good and the dialogue and story are as well so its fine most of the time.

Finally, I see very little replayability in this game. Maybe you could run through it a few more times and find some trinkets or enjoy some of the action sequences or something but once you solve all the riddles and mysteries that's pretty much it. You can't explore new areas, or make choices to get different outcomes or unlock secret dialogue. You are on a roller coaster and while its fun there is no mystery about where it starts, what it does or where it ends no matter how many times you ride it.

Bottom line is that this is a very good game and if you have never played it you really should.  A lot of fun with absolutely stunning visuals.  The acting is top notch and the dialogue and writing is excellent.  The parkour mechanics are occasionally frustrating but not terribly so and most everything is intuitive and works well. The combat is good and the AI of the npcs is pretty good as well although a little predictable sometimes.  The only suggestion I might make is to either play some of the prior games in series or at least watch a few videos summarizing the plots of those games because if you just start with this one as I did the characters have prior relationships and adventures that you don't easily understand. They talk about old missions and experiences and even peruse old memorabilia and pictures that probably mean something to people who played those games but to me they left me a little confused.

First off: This is the first time I play an UNCHARTED game, so I don't have any fond memories of the past or any other nostalgia to cling to. After roughly 4.5 hours (i.e. the average length of a full CoD campaign) I have arrived at the point that is presumably the end of the prologue and it's the first time I was given a gun to finally shoot at some bad guys in an open firefight -- and that's when I couldn't help but notice that this is a console game that was ported to the PC...

You see, as a console player, you can rely on "aim assist"/"auto aim" to put the bullets where the target's weak spot is, but as a PC player, the gold standard is using a mouse without any sort of aiming assistance. In consequence, guns in shooters have to be more accurate on the PC than on the consoles, because otherwise the player's aiming skills are nullified by the weapon's bullet spread -- and this is exactly what happens in this game. I really love sneaking around and putting a single well-aimed bullet into an enemies head, but the absolute insane bullet spread in this game makes any effort at aiming completely pointless -- I have to empty an entire magazine from a .45 pistol at a distance of 10 meters to bring down a single enemy and trying to serve headshots is pretty much a lottery...

Seriously, Goldeneye 64's Klobb is a sniper rifle compared to any of the guns that I have found in this game so far, and being forced to "spray-and-pray" in a game like this is really a downer for me... I don't see myself playing this game any further until Sony patches provides a patch that improves the bullet spread to a level that is also enjoyable for skilled no-aim-assist keyboard + mouse players. (Other console ports, like e.g. Horizon Zero Dawn, have done a lot better in this regard.)

If you intend to play with a joypad/gamepad/controller, then feel free to safely ignore this review -- be prepared for 4+ hours of foreplay though...

The amount of detail and care the developers took cultivating this world was just incredible. From the interactivity with objects which you wouldn't expect, to the large expansive scenes, to the small unscripted moments, to the detail of spittle on the sink taps from brushing teeth... just wow, incredible.

One of my personal memorable moments was just in a random part of a jungle, where I had stopped randomly while eating and I noticed a lemur in a tree, then my AI companion was just wandering around waiting for me to move and as it moved near the tree the lemur ran away when it got close - like the odds of anyone seeing that seems rare, let alone notice it, and yet the programmers/modelers/scripters/animators all took the extra effort to add that in.

I would have to say this is the first game in a very long time were I actually enjoyed the characters.
The relationship between Nate & Elena is well plotted and the story in general feels well fleshed out.

I would say the campaign in End of a Thief feels a little stretched, but this was true of the previous Uncharted games as well. Lost Legacy on the other hand feels a little squeezed in towards the end. Both were still enjoyable with what I felt were very warming endings.

My biggest gripe with both games, which once again, comes from the previous chapters as well, is the repetitive grind that the combat becomes after a short while, this is especially noticeable in End of a Thief with the longer storyline. There is a silenced pistol available to Chloe in Lost Legacy, which does help in this regard as well.

Lastly, especially if you take into account the obvious thought that went into the storyline, it boggles the mind as to how on earth they came to the chase sequences. It's just jarringly out of whack. Rubberbanding AI drivers, continuous respawns, roads and tracks that would make the airstrip in Fast & Furious proud. Maybe it's there for some fast paced action, I felt it was just tacky, boring and a let down when compared to the quality of the rest of the game.

All in all, I would definitely recommend the game, even more so if it goes on sale. Despite the few annoyances, I enjoyed my playthroughs very much.

UPDATE 10/20/22

Now I have had time to play and do a little bit of everything. Absolutely obvious they  upgraded the visuals. Runs smooth for me too. Keep in mind this game is a very good cross between game and cinematic experience. The best game play ever!!!!?? No. But serviceable. I enjoy it. Again, they mixed in cinematic seamlessly. Going hand to hand VS gun blazing is a press of a button and the moves glide together very well. Don't get me wrong, will the game sometimes break the laws of physics to string these fighting moves together? Yup! But you have a smirk and keep on moving. 

The Drake brothers are awesome! The type of duo you root for no matter what. The acting? Industry top tier. This game really does blend it all together into a action packed adventure. As a kid who loved Indiana Jones growing up, and was adventurous themselves, this series really spoke to me, even before I actually played video games. Sound design is pretty much the top of the entire industry. Graphics? Just look at them. Characters are played perfectly. 

I will say this. Sony goes for the last two entries in the entire series first is kind of crazy. This series is heavily dependent on your knowledge of past games to get the whole picture. Heck within the first 30 minutes of the game you go down memory lane from those past entries. If you played the past games, you'll enjoy. If not, you'll have an "OK...?" moment. I kind of get it. Sony wasn't about to RE Remake the first three games and they're obviously dropping their semi most recent banger's first. But I truly hope they just make the Drake Collection work on PC, drop it for like $30, and I think most will be understanding and thankful. Here is to hoping! 

I do not recommend going in blind. I would at least watch a story recap of the first three games, then give this game a go! If you're an action-adventure junkie like I am, give it a go! I think you'll enjoy! Within the first two hours, I'll be honest, you will not be far at all. By that time though you do get a taste of exploration, fighting, acting, puzzles, so you'll have a good grasp. However, the game doesn't really start pumping till about Chap 6/7. Watch your time closely for that refund. 

Hope you enjoy!

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead, murdered by my brother-in-law Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, Hank came to me with a rather, shocking proposition. He asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using his connections in the drug world. Connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded, I... I always thought that Hank was a very moral man and I was... thrown, confused, but I was also particularly vulnerable at the time, something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me on a ride along, and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin so I agreed. Every day, I think back at that moment with regret. I quickly realized that I was in way over my head, and Hank had a partner, a man named Gustavo Fring, a businessman. Hank essentially sold me into servitude to this man, and when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn.
Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling out. From what I can gather, Hank was always pushing for a greater share of the business, to which Fring flatly refused to give him, and things escalated. Fring was able to arrange, uh I guess I guess you call it a "hit" on my brother-in-law, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured, and I wound up paying his medical bills which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge, working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring, and did so. In fact, the bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen in the ranks to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA, and about that time, to keep me in line, he took my children from me. For 3 months he kept them. My wife, who up until that point, had no idea of my criminal activities, was horrified to learn what I had done, why Hank had taken our children. We were scared. I was in Hell, I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, to end this nightmare, and in response, he gave me this. I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. I... All I could think to do was to make this video in hope that the world will finally see this man, for what he really is.

It’s odd, isn’t it? To play Uncharted on PC. It’s far from the first big well known franchises to get from being a Sony console exclusive to PC, but something about Naughty Dog’s series that always made Sony hardware look like a magic box producing game flow and transitions no one else could achieve on any other hardware, makes this port feel extremely weird. But here we are, sadly, starting at the end of the franchise, or at least a big transition point, instead of the beginning. Uncharted 4: A Thief’s End, originally for PS4 from 2016 and Uncharted: The Lost Legacy, also for PS4 but from 2017, combined into one package and released first on PS5 at the start of 2022 and now on PC.

Uncharted didn’t become an instant success. The first game, Drake’s Fortune, from 2007 was impressive in many ways, but also deeply flawed and often frustrating. Sure, it was a generational leap of quality in comparison to Tomb Raider: Legend from a year before and even Anniversary from the same year, but the game was often more unfavorably compared to the adventures of Lara Croft, even if visuals, animation work and character banter were praised from the start. But then Uncharted 2: Among Thieves came out in 2009 and basically redefined what a cinematic action adventure can be. And the influence of what that title has achieved can still be felt in third person action adventures today.

Very importantly, people started to really like the characters of the series and them, and the situations they got in, were key to the popularity of the second and the third titles. The stories were always just there to created a sense of adventure and motivate characters to do stuff, they were never particularly great on their own. It was the characters, the situations and extremely fun mix of adventuring and action. Which is why it is so odd to think that Legacy of Thieves Collection might be the way some people will get to first experience the series. Because for all intents and purposes, Uncharted 4 is a goodbye to the characters of the original trilogy, with the emotional core of the title being the continuation and conclusion of all of the experiences they, and you the player, went through in the first three games. While The Lost Legacy is a transition into an idea of other characters being the main heroes now, the playable character also being a returning one.

If you didn’t experience the adventures from the previous games, it’s not like you won’t understand what’s going on. It’s that you won’t feel the same way. So… Unless Sony does make a new re-release of Uncharted: The Nathan Drake Collection for PC and you have no way to play the first three games, unless you’ve already played them, I would strongly suggest at least watching a longplay of them or a good let’s play, like ones from Chip and Ironicus.

With this out of the way, you really have to play Legacy of Thieves Collection if you like action adventure games. I mean, holy crap are these two titles amazing. They no longer “redefine” the genre quite as drastically and now, ironically, feature even more ideas from TR: Legend, Anniversary and Underworld, except polished to near perfection. But these titles are still many steps above the titles of the same type we get today.

The action, while in my opinion still the weakest part, is incredibly cool when everything clicks just right. You seamlessly switch between stealth, sitting in cover, jumping around, using a grappling hook to throw a grenade one one swing and then drop punching someone in the face on the opposite one, then blind shooting to the next enemy only to brawl with them a bit to grab their weapon and hide for a few moments to get into stealth again. Even when there are no set piece encounters happening and it’s just a more or less normal shootout, the action is exhilarating and fun. If you don’t die immediately when trying to do all that cool stuff. It still doesn’t have the precision and agility of greats by Japanese action game greats like, say, Capcom or Platinum Games, but at least it doesn’t feel “unfair” and checkpointing is very nicely thought out.

Platforming is fantastic and the way the levels are designed is incredible. The game manages to be linear, without feeling linear, completely avoiding the typical problem of the modern Tomb Raider and the like titles, where you have one clear path through the level, always providing many different ways to get to the same necessary spot, always leading you subtly to where you need to be, without you consciously feeling the hand holding. It’s amazing how they didn’t make the climbing fully freeform and systemic, like what, say, Assassin’s Creed or Breath of the Wild strives for, while still keeping the excitement and the feeling that you are making the path, not just following one. It helps that unlike recent Tomb Raider titles, it’s very rare where these fully contextual actions like jump distances and ledge grabs or distances at which you die or not feel “fake”, so the flow of player actions almost always goes naturally.

What’s really improved as well is the puzzle design. Unlike TR franchise, Uncharted was always slightly less focused on puzzle solving aspect and it’s changed for Uncharted 4 and especially The Lost Legacy, and the way they bring these more into the forefront is really cool. And where Uncharted 4 is still more interested in the flow and guiding the players during the puzzles, The Lost Legacy often goes fully TR and lets you figure things out without any hints or comments from the characters that spoil the puzzle solving. Speaking of, The Lost Legacy also includes a really cool wide open level with several sections that you explore in any order you want and that whole thing (and the game in general) honestly feels more like a Tomb Raider than the whole “Survivor trilogy” of the Tomb Raider.

The games still look and feel astonishing and almost no magic is lost in the transition to PC and high framerates and resolutions. It’s not quite flawless, for example the pre-rendered video segments that the game sporadically uses to introduce cool crossfades from one scene to the other or other little inserts are far more noticeable, because of their lower bitrate recording and set framerate. But it doesn’t detract from just how seamless the whole experience is as you go on a globe trotting adventure without a single visible loading screen in sight (apart from when you go from the main menu into the game). There are also occasional visual bugs that can pop up that are only fixed by going to the main menu and reloading again. Keyboard and mouse controls seem to be rather meh, though I’d highly recommend playing the game as intended on a controller. And the fact that you need to launch into the game and then switch the game instead of having an external game selector is really odd. But otherwise, it’s all fixable and Sony seem eager to support their PC titles for now.

Uncharted: Legacy of Thieves Collection is incredible. There’s still nothing quite like this as far as action adventure games are concerned. Some sequences feel impossible as you’re playing them, having (almost) full control of the craziness that’s happening on screen. It’s not perfect and it is probably not going to have quite the same impact if you have not played the first 3 games. But this is still an amazing experience that you should have.

Horizon Zero Dawn, Days Gone, God of War, Spider-Man and now Uncharted, isn’t that amazing? If you think about it, you would have probably not believed this in 2019, in just 3 years the industry changed so much that it’s almost unbelievable.

Some of you are already familiar with this saga but for those who are about to jump in for the first time let me tell you that this is a great moment to do so. You will miss some of the references but I think you will enjoy the adventures by themselves even if you don’t get the full punch of some scenes and moments by missing the previous games. Let’s see if Uncharted 4: A Thief’s End and Lost Legacy are worth your time.

Let’s start with Uncharted 4.

Nathan Drake has long left behind the adventures in order to settle with Elena and live an ordinary life together, however, the past catches us all sooner or later and a new adventure is about to start. Nathan and his, until this moment unknown, brother Sam will sail on a race against time in order to beat an old partner and, perhaps, something Sam is hiding, the goal of this race? The biggest and most legendary of all pirate treasures, Henry Every’s fortune and the lost pirate nation of Libertalia.

A Thief’s End sets a very different tone for the story, while bombastic and spectacular at moments, it’s far more personal and deeper than previous entries, there’s a huge emphasis on how characters are living this adventure, for example, Nathan’s struggle between his desire of keeping a more calmed lifestyle with Elena and the pure desire of returning to the adventure of the unknown, which ends up happening, but the way he’s facing it is completely different to previous expeditions. All characters have enough time to develop themselves within the game thanks to an incredible narrative and performances, the scenes do really help building the characters, here’s my favorite example by the end of the game, [spoiler]Nathan’s performance on Every’s mansion[/spoiler], that scene alone creates a moment in which we can see a level of affection they have to each other, simply wonderful.

When it comes to Libertalia things are a bit different than previous games, while Shangri-La or Ubar had a supernatural element behind them, Libertalia feels like something more coherent for the story Naughty Dog wanted to tell here. The more we explore and learn about the city, the more detailed everything becomes, the conflict that happened, how the most prolific pirates of the era ended up building this place, etc. There's a huge narrative element about this place and its previous owners that is absolutely fascinating, probably my favorite of this saga.

What about Lost Legacy?

We will be following the steps of Nadine from Uncharted 4 and Chloe from Uncharted 2, this adventure will place us on the edge of a civil conflict in India caused by Asav, a nostalgic and ruthless warlord that wants to obtain an ancient object from the Indian culture, the Tusk of Ganesh. We will have to find it before Asav does in order to save the ancient object and perhaps stop his madness.

I would say that Lost Legacy story is a bit simpler than A Thief’s End because it feels more like a classic Uncharted game but at the same time you can feel how the team behind learned a lot from the main game. Lost Legacy was supposed to be a DLC for the main game but got too big and became its own thing and the final result is a mix between the old concepts and the new concepts in terms of scale and pace. I’m glad to see Chloe back as she was a character that had a lot of potential and I think this game truly gives her the attention she deserves. Nadine is also a very interesting one as we saw her as one of the villains from the previous game but here we can actually learn a lot from her, giving enough time and depth to all characters in order to really shine. Asav however, I think it’s a good villain but felt somewhat disconnected from the story most of the time. While it had some potential, it ended up being a flatter character than expected.

The story is good, India was an unknown place for the saga up to this day and there was so much potential, not only it has a very rich and interesting culture, but also had a lot of background that truly highlights thanks to the amazing locations we can see in this game, the temples, the jungles, it feels similar to A Thief’s End but in a more ancient scenography.

There’s absolutely no doubt that A Thief’s End and Lost Legacy are stunning games so I think it’s about time we jump into the visuals because trust me, it’s worth it.

Both Uncharted 4 and Lost Legacy are the type of games in which you will most likely take a few seconds taking a picture every few minutes because every environment is stunning. In the case of Uncharted 4, each area of the game is distinctive from each other, we go from urban areas to dense jungles and tropical islands with coral reefs. It’s no secret that Naughty Dog is top tier when it comes to visuals but the amount of detail and care they put into building something that feels natural but at the same time functional is stunning.There’s also an open area for the first time in the saga, Madagascar, and while it’s a good idea in concept, it doesn’t work especially well in this entry given that it has a different pace than the rest of the game but fortunately the concept evolved and Lost Legacy was built around this kind of world structure.

When it comes to Lost Legacy, visuals aren’t less impressive, on the contrary, while there’s less variety of biomes as the story takes place in a very specific part of India, which has a lot of vegetation and forests, we find here something that we don’t see in Uncharted 4, impossibly big structures, which, at a personal level, gives this games a lot of positive points.

What about gameplay?

U4/LL’s gameplay loop is the same as  in previous entries of the saga, however the number of possibilities and animations have been vastly improved over the previous generation of games, not only animations feel more natural but also the addition of the grappling hook has improved both exploration and combat by adding a certain amount of verticality to the areas without being exclusively climbing dependant.

Gunplay is still something that I do not really like, it’s not about how it works but how it feels and I have always had this problem with ND games, that’s why I’m not saying it’s a problem but a personal perception of it, however, while the gunplay isn’t something that I like, the combats became more exciting by letting you approach it from different angles and using different approaches; Stealth, direct combat, jumping, climbing, using covers, etc… There’s a certain combat in U4 (ship graveyard, you will know the one) that sure is intensive, damn!

KB+M control is ok, weird at first but you will get used to it.

Story, visuals and gameplay have been discussed, I think it’s time to talk about sound and music. Music ain’t nothing special, sadly it doesn’t really shine as we would all have hoped, there are great tracks but overall it’s not something that stands up. Voice acting and surrounding sound design is good, the cast did an amazing job with their performances.

As for PC performance, aside from the Shader compilation process (keep that one in mind in case your temps go crazy with such processes) the PC conversion seems to be great. Steady performance and great visuals. While the game is demanding, I didn’t have problems with my rig but please keep in mind that your experience can be different.

In conclusion for this review, I’m extremely happy to see that Uncharted came to Steam. After revisiting this title for its PC debut I realized that this is in fact my favorite entry of the saga and Lost Legacy is a very worthy product too. I think you will enjoy this one a lot as a newcomer to the franchise, here’s hope to see the previous ones coming at some point too but don’t miss this packaging.

I've never played an Uncharted game before (I was an Xbox and PC kid), so this is my first venture into the world of Nathan Drake. What I'm seeing so far is amazing, it's clear why so many people fell in love with these characters and this story. Problem is, this is the only Uncharted game on PC and it's the forth game in the series. It feels akin to going to a party at a college I don't attend. I don't know the people, I don't know the stories, and I certainly don't get the jokes. I can always continue playing as I have been, enjoy what's there with the knowledge that there will be plenty of things I won't understand. But as I progress, this seems like a game that was made as tasteful fan service. Something in the same vein as Mass Effect's Citadel DLC. Uncharted 4 seems fantastically self aware and willing to poke fun at its story and its characters, while knowing when to have slow it down and have sincere moments. The more I play, the more I feel like I'm missing out. So, in the meantime, I'm going to hold out hope that Sony ports the other Uncharted games to PC (if not, I guess I'll watch some walkthrough videos on Youtube lol). Because these characters and this world have instantly hooked me, and I don't want to miss out on a single moment.

[h1] A solid PC Port [/h1]

I played Uncharted 4 to completion when it launched back in 2016 on PS4. Playing it in this state @ native 4k with a 3090 and solid 60 fps on my TV feels great

[h1] Major Pros [/h1]

 [b] Unlocked frame rate and hugely improved visuals coming from the PS4  [/b]
 [b] Xbox controller support is spectacular. I heard a PS5 controller can be used as well for an enhanced experience  [/b]
 [b] 2 Engaging stories. It will keep you hooked to completion.  [/b]
 [b] Amazing gameplay. This includes gunplay, climbing/traversal, combat etc.,  [/b]

[h1] Major Cons [/h1]

 [b] No exclusive fullscreen [/b]
 [b] Keyboard and mouse support is quite poor. Especially mouse movement (at this time) [/b]
 [b] Cutscenes abruptly transition from video file to gameplay and it is quite abrupt. Certain cutscenes also exhibit noticeable stuttering [/b]
 [b] No multiplayer component. This remains exclusive to the PS4 version [/b]

Also, the game makes references to previous entries in the franchise (Uncharted 1,2,3) which were an integral part of Drake's story (especially Uncharted 2). I hope the original trilogy is brought to PC, so players can experience that too.

 [h1] Final Rating: 8/10 [/h1]

 [h1] TLDR: A solid PC port. Great way to experience it for the first time. You can skip this PC version, if you have already played it elsewhere (PS5 or PS4). Buy this PC version, if you have never played an Uncharted game before, or Uncharted 4 in particular. It is a masterpiece, now available on PC. Few bugs/issues that I have explained in the cons section [/h1]

So far, a great port of a great game. Can recommend.

[h1]Performance[/h1]
The performance is good. Running the game on Ultra graphics, with DLSS on Quality. The game runs at a smooth FPS of 60+ as a minimum. Most of the time the FPS is 100+. (see specs below)

There are a few microstutters when loading a new chapter/scene which lasts a couple seconds. After that, the rest of the scene is buttery smooth. Maybe they'll fix it in an upcoming patch. (note, I'm not talking stutters every cutscene here. I mean when loading into a new chapter of the game).

[b]Specs[/b]
CPU: i5-8400
GPU: RTX 3070 Ti
RAM: 24 GB

[h1]Controls[/h1]
The controls are fine. It's obviously build for controllers, but keyboard & Mouse work perfectly fine. Aiming with a mouse is a huge improvement. I did remap a couple keys and increase the mouse-sensitivity, but these are personal preferences.

[h1]Note[/h1]
When first starting the game, it will be installing shaders. This will cause severe stuttering and framedrops. I would recommend waiting in the Main Menu for it to fully install (there is a progress bar of sorts). It didn't take too long, but didn't go fast either. For me it took 15 minutes or so, maybe a bit quicker.

From what I've heard, DLSS only takes affect after relaunching the game. So do this before starting your playthrough (if you want to use DLSS that is).

I now understand why Naughty Dog's games are so highly praised.
Uncharted 4 brings action, witty dialogues, amazing characters and top notch animation to the table.

-It feels like I'm legit watching a high production movie while simultaneously playing it.
-The characters so far who I have been introduced to are hilarious and have a lot of depth. They don't feel like "video game" characters who just serve their purpose for my story.
-I love how my companions keep talking to me while I'm climbing or in combat.  In other games, my companion would say one or two line and shut up. But these companions feel like real people. They would comment on a lot of things that I'm doing and a lot times make fun of it.
-The animation quality is also something else in Uncharted 4. There was a time where Nathan scratched his ear and then scratched his nose and his nostrils also swelled up for a moment. It seems silly but these are the things that happen all the time in real life but nobody puts them in games. The animators are really on another level on this game.
- The pacing is also very good. The transition between cutscene to gameplay to cutscene again feels very very smooth. This is why it's so hard to put down this game.

-Speaking of combat. I kind of am not a fan of it. It's mediocre.

That being said I am absolutely loving this game. It's just so fun.

First off I'd like to say that Uncharted : Legacy of Thieves Collection was the first and the last game that I'll ever purchase as a preload title. It took me 4 hours...four hours to unpack this game on my PC, which is a powerhouse rig before I could play it. It actually unpacked slightly faster on my Steam Deck, which was surprising. 

With that gripe out of the way...Uncharted 4 is one of my favorite games since it released on the PS4 half a decade ago. This port to PC is pretty good but not without some issues. As every PC is different, including those with the exact same hardware that I have in my PC, everyone will have different performance or bug issues so, I'm basing my review on my own personal issues with the game. One thing I've been hearing from a lot of PC players is the mouse acceleration problem that needs patched immediately. I play using a PS5 controller so this isn't an issue for me. However, it is for others who prefer KB and mouse. Whoever thought this was a good idea? Second, as for me I'm having some visual glitching going on where characters are either hitching up or moving oddly on the screen during cut scenes. This is the only buggy issue I've experienced this far being about 3.5 hrs into the game. As for performance...it's been a mixed bag "for me." My PC consists of an i7 12700K w/32 GB memory and an RTX 3070. Up till the part where you climb the mountains and go to the auction, the game ran fine, with high FPS.  Since I've been here, performance has tanked for no good reason and I went from 80+ FPS at high settings @3440x1440 to low 40's and sometimes into the high 30's. I'm also getting a good bit of stuttering here. Everything ran fine up to this point. 

As for the graphics and visuals...they look great but, I can't tell much difference between the PC version and my PS5 upgraded version. Here, I only speak for myself and this is more my opinion than anything else. However, its nice to see the game be brought to PC and not be a damned Epic exclusive or a complete trainwreck. It would be awesome if they would also bring Uncharted 1,2 and 3 to PC as well. Now, if only SONY would bring Bloodborne and Demon's Souls to PC as well, I think a lot of PC players would be extremely happy. Now, do I recommend Uncharted : Legacy Of Thieves Collection? Absolutely. Especially if you play using a controller. And despite the buggy cut scene issues I've been having a long with something going on performance wise in the Chapter I'm in, I've had a blast. As for performance over on my Steam Deck....its a mixed bag. I need to tweak the game a bit and mess around with it before I give my judgement on the Steam Deck playability of the game. One thing I forgot to mention is that I wish they would have given us more in depth graphics tweaking options. They aren't the worst but aren't the best we've seen.

[b]The game is good, but let me tell you guys about Chicago-style hog dog[/b]

This hot dog is a Windy City classic and a big favorite with sports fans! The frank must be all-beef, the bun must be poppy seed, and the ingredients must be piled onto the bun in the order specified. And whatever you do, don't spoil the splendor of this Chicago dog with ketchup!

[b] Ingredients: [/b]
1 all-beef hot dog
> 1 poppy seed hot dog bun
> 1 tablespoon yellow mustard
> 1 tablespoon sweet green pickle relish
> 1 tablespoon chopped onion
> 4 tomato wedges
> 1 dill pickle spear
> 2 sport peppers
> 1 dash celery salt

[b]Directions: [/b]
[i] Step 1 ) [/i] Bring a pot of water to a boil over high heat. Reduce heat to low, place hot dog in water, and cook until warmed through, about 5 minutes. Remove hot dog from water and set aside.

[i]Step 2 )[/i] Place a steamer basket into the pot and steam poppy seed bun until warm, about 2 minutes.

[i]Step 3)[/i] Place hot dog in steamed bun. Pile on toppings in this order: mustard, relish, onion, tomato, pickle, peppers, and celery salt. The tomato wedges should be nestled between hot dog and top of bun on one side. Place pickle between hot dog and bottom of bun on the other side. Don't even think about ketchup!

[i] Enjoy your Chicago-style hog dog![/i]

Dear PC brethren... Often times I'm reminded why gaming has become such a staple in my life. There is comfort in this lifelong passion we grew up loving. It's been with us through the thick of life, often times offering a place of solitude in the hardest of times. Given the decades of gaming "experiences" we have all been exposed to, it's rare to find something that truly leaves a lasting impact on you. "We've seen it all" mindset tends to seep in as we desperately and mindlessly stumble through the steam store looking for that next big fix. Anything to satiate that desire to wet our gaming palettes grown numb over the years. I'm here to tell you that Uncharted is that game. You'll remember this exploit for the remainder of your days, smiling reminiscently as you tell your future families of the first time you stepped into the shoes of Nathan Drake and the adventures you had together. Cutting through the humid dense forest... Speeding your boat towards the sun-drenched shores as the waves splash playfully against the hull... The glint of excitement in your eyes as you realize you're about to set off on an adventure of a lifetime...  I worry sometimes that I have lost that passion for gaming, but every once in a while, you find a game that reaffirms your love and passion has not been ill placed. Maybe you too can open your stone-cold hearts; exposed and stained from the weather of disappointment, empty promises, and Developers who aren't Sean Murray and give this game a chance. I hope you find solace in the warm embrace of Nathan and the thrill of the hunt as I did. May Elana Fisher never be forgotten and may she live forever in our hearts.

I consider all of the games in the Uncharted series to be the greatest games of all time. Nothing I have ever played really compares to the memories I've had in this game.  Once you play Uncharted, your real life will become a game and this will become your new reality. If you are not in a position to go on vacations to exotic faraway lands, this is the next best thing. If you ever wanted to go on an epic adventure including: hiking, parkour, rock climbing, exploring jungles, crawling through caverns, stumbling upon abandoned ruins, flying planes across oceans, climbing steep surfaces of buildings, treasure hunting, uncovering ancient mysteries, and unearthing rare artifacts, this is the game for you. It makes everyday life seem like a marvelous grand adventure where you get to play the rightful gaming heir to Indiana Jones, and Lara Croft. The adventures you get to go on in this game are something everyone with an adventurous spirit should be able to experience at least once in their lifetime. 

One of the best things about Uncharted is the cinematic gameplay. Every moment seems like a perfectly framed scene from a movie, only you get to be the main star. The supporting characters in the game are excellent and well developed. A companion system while you are playing makes it so you never feel alone and are immersed completely. The chit chat and banter makes it feel like you are actually playing a multiplayer game with friends rather than a single player game. The Npc's are not just typical cardboard cutouts of human beings.  

This is a a great game for people who like 2d platformers but want something more realistic. It is also the best parkour game along with Mirrors Edge, Dying Light, and perhaps some of the Assassins creed games. The 3D Platforming and climbing from ledge to ledge convey a sense of danger and you have to figure out how best to climb the rock face safely. The feeling that you might fall from great heights only adds to the exhilaration. There is also a duck and cover combat system and some really cool weapons. You can also play stealthy if that is your thing. There are puzzles to solve that are reasonable and they don't get in the way of the action or adventure. The soundtrack only adds to the immersion and gives inspiration to the meaning and wonder you experience along the way. The game is by far the best adventure I have ever experienced. The experiences I've had in this game are now part of my own life experiences.

If you like the Tomb Raider series, Mirrors Edge, Dying Light, Assassins Creed Black Flag, 2d Platformers like Spelunky, or Indian Jones style movies you will love this game. I have thousands of hours total in this series including Uncharted 1,2,3 and 4 on Ps3 and ps4. And I now get to enjoy the latest remasterd installment of Uncharted 4 on pc.

Uncharted captures the mystery and wonder at the very heart of being human. And it puts you in touch with that sense of discovery and the indescribable feeling that there are still amazing things left in the world for you to discover.
One of the greatest games.

I've played the Uncharted Series multiple times on my PS4. I actually recently replayed the entire series just a few weeks ago - so needless to say it's probably one of my favorite game franchises. 

I enjoy open world games but these days it's become so saturated with games that talk up about an open world experience but in actuality it's just a huge map with tedious and repetitive missions and mundane side-quests. I would much rather play a linear game, and Naughty Dog has perfected this genre with Uncharted and Last of Us, and no other series really comes to mind when it comes to linear games besides maybe Tomb Raider (which is basically a repackaged poor man's Uncharted anyways).

For the PC port specifically, I didn't think the difference would be that huge but since I have a PS4 slim and not pro, it was pretty noticeable for me. Graphics looks much better and detailed, and most importantly the framerate is great on Ultra settings and I'm still on a 1080gtx. This is my third PC port of a playstation title and thus far they have all ran incredibly smooth without really asking for a lot of hardware in return.

I'm sure there are people that have not played the first three Uncharted games and don't have a console. I would say you can still play 4 as your first Uncharted game, you will just miss certain references and easter eggs that refer to things from the first three games. For the story of Uncharted 4 itself tho it won't be a huge problem and I would still recommend you try it, and hopefully Sony will port the rest of the series later.

The PC version of Uncharted: Legacy of Thieves Collection is definitely the best way to experience the treasure hunt of Nathan Drake and company, with little to criticise, showing that the greatness of the title predates the launch of this collection. On a performance level, both Sony and Naughty Dog have done an incredible job of turning a game (already six years old) into a thoroughly enjoyable experience in 2022, both graphically and in terms of performance.

Indeed, we can't ignore the fact that this is just a release of two titles that many PlayStation console owners have already played, but for any fan of the series, regardless of whether they've already played the title on PlayStation, this is an entry not to be missed.

So Sony, you like money, we Steam community want games, please remaster Bloodborne with variable framerate and ultrawide support, port it to PC and we are absolutely down.

P/S: Never imagined in my life would I play a Playstation exclusive with XBOX Controller (and on PC), but this happens and it's smooth like butter, well life is such unpredictable. Anyway, nice port.
